description:
I visited Balompie Cafe during my trip to San Francisco and was glad I went. Their Pupusas were filling: not too doughy. 

To drink, we ordered Horchatas and Tamarindo's. Refreshing, sweet, and delicious, they paired really well with the food.

I also ordered their breakfast dish, which came with plátanos, casamiento, queso and crema. While Balompie ends up getting pricey at $4/per Pupusa, the quality and nostalgia it brings warrants the price.

The service was quick, and helpful. The atmosphere is great, they have a wonderful space and I think they use it well. Can't wait to go back!
author: Charles R.

description:
A solid venue for a variety of traditional Salvadoran dishes.

I'd stopped by long ago in a previous iteration of the venue (it looks like it's been renovated since) and had enjoyed the pupusas, and on a more recent visit I was quite surprised with a large, reasonably priced ($15.95) plato tipico for dinner that featured a deliciously prepared slab of carne asada (steak), an equally delicious helping of chorizo (sausage), plus sides of casamiento (rice and beans) and queso (cheese). Simply yummy, filling, down-home comfort food.

Service is fast, friendly, and proactive, and it was reassuring to see that 90% of the patrons when I stopped by weren't gringos - a sign of authenticity. In this gentrifying pocket of the West Bay where boutiques selling overpriced and overhyped craft-artisanal-handmade-whatever is the norm, quality, diverse local businesses like this one are well worth supporting!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Dreaming of the day I get to go back and enjoy some pupusas and sangria! 

My friends and I had dinner at Balompie on a Thursday night just before a show at the Victoria Theater down the street. My boyfriend and I had 4 pupusas between the 2 of us and the table shared 2 pitchers of sangria. The food and drinks hit the spot and did not hurt the wallet. The pupusas are only $3.50 each and will definitely fill you up.

The restaurant is open for breakfast too - we hope to come back and try more items from the menu.
author: Camille B.

description: Excellent, fresh pupusas. Good service. Decent coffee. This place is excellent. The building recently had a major renovation. The charm of this place is till there. I also like their casamientos (a combination of rice and beans mixed together). I can't say enough about this place. Once you order your pupusas, listen for that telltale slapping in the kitchen. That means they are making yours fresh. This is one of my favorite places to go for breakfast. Or when I have a pupusa craving.
author: Jason P.

description: Pretty good papusas. I was looking for a quick breakfast before a flight and was in the area so I picked up two flavors to go, a pork and cheese one and a shrimp one with cheese. They had a good amount of cheese. The food was nice and fresh and very filling. I really liked the pickled slaw and sauce that was included. I'd come back and try some of the other foods.
author: Nina H.

description:
Finally found a spot that makes an authentic gooey cheesy pupusa. Bought 5 different assortments for a potluck at my job. However my supervisor's opinion was the only one that matter to me and she loved them. 

Ordered: I am a big fan of jalapeño/cheese, next I order steak, and chorizo. It melted in my mouth as I devoured just one. I was full off of just two. It was a little greasy, but you can expect that when you order any pupusa. Im stunned at how many different kinds they make here. The pickle cabbage on the side, along with the tomate sauce to dunk my pupusa out of this world


For each pupusa they charge $3.50. A little high. I guess it's your choice on whether you want to travel further somewhere else in Mission and pay only $2.50. I think it's worth the extra dollar

I've notice this restaurant revolves around soccer, and is a big deal here.
author: Elijajuan F.

description:
A variety of pupusas to choose from!  Modern dining for the Latin American taste affair!  I chose the Lorocco Con Queso delightful pupusa and they have other fillings to choose from.  That was my unique favorite, I'm sure. 

Salsa and pickled cabbage I do like as they provide on the side. 

Yuca fries are fresh and goes well with the condiments.  Pork chunks were wholesome.  This entree lacked flavor for the most part.

Service was great.  Slow for the orders to come out.  Soccer games are on for the most part if not at all times!

Spot on place for pupusas!
author: Tiffany D.

description: I recently moved to the area and was looking for a new place to get pupusas. This was my third, maybe fourth visit since I moved to SF in March. I absolutely love it and would definitely recommend it! I usually go for the pupusas revueltas. The prices are good, service is great, and atmosphere is nice. If you're looking for quick, cheap pupusas this is the place!
author: R I.

description: Balompie is a hidden gem. Best papusas in the Mission. Their fried plantains are always perfect. Their fresh home made tortillas are nice & thick. This is my go-to El Salvadorian Restaurant.
author: H. L.

description:
Nice pupusas selection (each for 3.50, 2 minimum per person)

Soccer themed restaurant with
author: Sarah M.

description: Came for dinner and was surprised it wasn't more crowded! Good service, good food! Feels super authentic and home-y here. I got the whole fried fish, for the price, it was a good heaping of food! Came with tortillas as well. Would definitely return!
author: Vivian D.

description:
Bad for big groups even if reserved in advanced. Didn't give us water for nearly 20 minutes

Food is good but takes a long time and sometimes they will give your drinks to people who came in well after you.
author: Pratik P.

description: I walked past this cafe on my last day in SF looking for some warm comfort Spanish food. I had been in SF eating cold salads and sourdough for three weeks and I could not take it any more. So I decide do walk in. I had never had a Popusa so I can't compare them to anything but they were so delicious. They were just flavorful and full of cheese and meat I was so happy I walked in. They perfect way to say good bye to SF. Service was amazing also. Cannot wait to go back just so that I can have their steak popusa.
author: Millyed G.

description:
Fresh and happening spot recommended by a fantastic hair colorist down the street!
The food is fabulous and very tastalicious!
author: cathy r.

description: Lousy place, they want  to choose were you can sit, so if you are going there, u know just bring four people with you so u can have a very sit.
author: Yamilette C.

description:
Worst customer service, EVER! I called them a quarter to 10 for a large company order. They confirmed my order and time of pick up. I left my number with the lady who took my order. I arrive to pick up 66 pupusas and a large tray of rice and beans, only to be told that they required a deposit and therefore didn't follow through with my order. When I asked them why they didn't call me, they claimed to have called multiple times. Only after I asked to verify my number, did they look at me like they knew they didn't write it down correctly. Especially, when they said a man answered, and I told them i gave them my personal cell number. I walked away with no food or an apology. Never will I ever support this small business! 

If I could give zero stars, I would!
author: Connie B.

description: They reopened in November 2017. The decor is cleaner and more streamlined but the food is just as good. I'm from El Salvador and it tastes like home. Vegans try the empanada with frijoles. It is made with plantain and beans. Vegetarians order the pupusas with cheese and loroco. Casamiento is also nice for vegans, simple refried red beans and rice. Horchata is different from the Mexican version, it has orgeat which gives it a more complex taste. For meat eaters try the chorizo it is saltier than what you are probably used to...
author: Nils H.

description: This great restaurant has excellent El Salvadoran food that leaves you smiling and wanting to come back soon. The menu has many yummy choices and it has a warm and lively atmosphere. The service is excellent!
author: Marshall M.

description: It was just ok. I had a bean and cheese pupusa and a chicken and cheese and the cheese was just tooooo much on both. It was super salty and lacked the other ingredients. Maybe some people like really cheese filled and saltiness but I'll pass.
author: Yvonne B.

description: Absolutely delicious food but I couldn't believe how terrible and SLOW the service was. Also there were so many mistakes with our orders, I couldn't believe it. Out of the 4 things we ordered, 2 were completely wrong. When we said something to the waiter, he seemed annoyed and from the window, we saw the cook was even more upset. How frustrating! Not worth the hassle or long wait for our food. Never again. Too bad!
author: Stacy Q.

description: Place is small. Pupusas were good. Had platanos fritos with beans,sour cream & cheese it was good. Whenever im in sf again i will swing by and try other things on the menu.
author: Yani H.

description: Best pupusas in the city!!! Feliz que estan abierto de nuevo!! I miss you !!! Been coming to eat here for the past 30 years!!! ARRIBA EL SALVADOR!!!
author: Claudio P.

description: The food here is fucking awesome. The pupusas are amazing, the super veggie pupusas de harina de arroz I love. Also the breakfast special with huevos and casamiento and queso and tortillas hechas a mano are amazing. Please go.
author: Walter P.

description: Yucca !!! This is one of my favorite restaurants in my neighborhood they make my favorite dish Yucca with chicaron like Abuelita use to make it. Food has always been delicious waiter are friendly high reccomend this place !
author: Mario G.

description:
And they've made a fantastic come back! I've been hesitant to come over for a treat after the make over but it's all good. 
My favorite is the queso con loroco pupusa. Might be basic but it's the BOMB! Not greasy yet extra cheesy and addicting. 
Can't wait to go back and have their awesome beans and fried plantains, steak with sautéed onions and speciality tamales. 
Don't hesitate and go on by and enjoy a little piece of Mission history with this long time family owned location. Can't go wrong with the old school.
author: Dee Q.

description: If you love pupusas and you're in the city, you have to come here! They have different ones and they're sooooo good! My husband has also tried a chicken plate and he enjoyed every last bite. The Horchata wasn't bad either. My only complaint is don't come here starving because it takes forever for your food to come out...
author: Mertani G.

description: Your service sucks! Worse experience ever DONT waste ur money here and, as for the owner ur a BITCH ur food was nasty and ur servers need to check their attitude ur not paying my dish I AM Bitch so show some respect.
author: Jessica R.

description:
They are the undisputed heavyweight king of pupusas!

What a little neighborhood gem.  Tasty food, friendly service, a small, busy room for a Sunday brunch.  Families large and small.  About half of the plates coming out were breakfast, the other half were pupusas or other Salvadoran specials.  They love their futbal too...there were soccer banners everywhere, a couple of TVs playing games on satellite.  

The food came out, my son took two bites and said, "how soon can we come back again?"  

Those pupusas were just the right balance of not-too-greasy and just-greasy-enough...but I mean that in a good way.  Crispy, salty, savory, and oozy.  

Not that we had enough room, but the sides were worth making a little room for.  The fried plantains were tasty, the pickled coleslaw added some crunch, and a smooth red salsa just the right amount of heat.

Plenty of vegetarian friendly options too.  My wife and daughter liked the mixed vegetable one and the bean and cheese.  For some reason the lacoro that is mentioned in a lot of reviews wasn't a hit with them.  Oh well, still they agreed, Balompie definitely scored a GOOOAAAL!
author: Joe P.

description: Very good Salvadorian Food, everything was excellent, friendly service also. Great Pupusas, crispy and flavorful Fried Yucca, Pastels and Anchor Steam on draft! San Diego may have the best Mexican Food, but this is the best El Salvador Food I can remember having. Definitely worth the trip.
author: Dave R.

description: I love this place!  The people working there are very friendly and food is great!  Pupusas are not greasy and there are many kinds to chose from.  Carne asada is tasty too.  Nice, easy atmosphere.  We have been three times already after trying it for the first time a couple of weeks ago.
author: suzanne l.

description: Been living on Capp for almost 20 years and I am so happy they opened back up. Food still the same- BOMB! Best pupusas and I love the carne with rice and beans and their style of enchiladas. Everyone I take their always remembers it and loves it! For people that want top notch service- keep in mind this place is busy and food is great! So be patient not privileged.
author: April M.

description:
I loved the pupusas here! I came here specifically with the goal of eating a bunch of pupusas, and I was not disappointed.

They have a pretty solid selection of pupusa options, and in addition to the standard pupusa menu, have another long list of specialty pupusas that are 50 cents more and a little more unique (one of them had prosciutto inside, for example). I opted for the traditional pupusas, and tried the queso y frijoles, laroco con queso, and ayote (zucchini) con queso. I thought they all tasted delicious - very fresh and filled with oozing cheese - what more could you want? At $3 a pop, they're a great deal too! I was pretty stuffed after eating three, even though I wasn't really expecting to be.

If you're in the Mission and looking for some pupusas, I think this is the place to go!
author: Dylan C.

description: Omg Bomb .com ! This little cafe joint was very good . El Salvador food was bomb . There pupusas were very delicious and there chicken soup caldo was very good and authentic. This place very clean and small . I highly recommend this place .
author: Charles G.

description: Balompie is by far the best place for pupusas. This place is a must for anyone who wants pupusas or hasn't had them.
author: Paul O.

description: This little hidden restaurant was a tasty find and appeared to be a very popular family-type gathering place for dinner.  Wasn't sure what to eat, but ordered a few popular popusas and the tongue smothered with a vegetable red sauce.   Very pleased with the food and plan to go back to try some other dishes.
author: Donald C.

description: Great food options, excellent Pupusas! Very good cup of coffee and great service. This is not Mexican food, it truly was their unique take on El Salvadorian cuisine. They had a cheese sauce that was excellent, a must try again!
author: Gabriel L.

description: This was an amazing teasure to stumble upon on our stay in San Francisco. This is the one spot that should have had a long brunch line. I had Huevos Rancheros, the sauce was so perfect. My man had Chorizo and eggs with rice and beans. The tortillas were homemade, fresh and hot. Next time we go back for the Pupusas! They looked off the charts. Wonderful service, sweet and personable owner, we will be back!
author: Angel A.

description: Stopped for a quick bite and had the best veggie omelette! Check out their menu. Great service, fun, and I'll be back.
author: Tom L.

description: DEEEEELICIOUS!!!  Service was a bit slow for lunch time but figured good food is worth the wait.  Not disappointed at all, left satisfied and can't wait to return!!  The pupusa con loroco was the BEST!
author: aynur d.

description:
I fucking love pupusas, and Balompie does this Salvadoran specialty right (not that I've ever been to El Salvador or anything). On my way to dinner, I just had to pop in for the queso and loroco pupusas. The tortilla discs were soft, fresh and swollen with warm runny cheese. They paired perfectly with the red sauce and magical curtido, which I dumped mounds of onto my plate. Our server was awesome - he was friendly, responsive and prompt even though we ordered less than $10 worth of food.

If you've never heard of or tried a pupusa before, then you need to go get some NOW. At only $3 per piece, even homeless people can afford it.
author: Suany W.

description: Ever since the remodel their service really sucks, very dry, bland, and super forgetful to say the least. It baffles me how you can forget to give water after you just asked what we wanted to drink then bring the food and still forget. Your young and unfocused..and get this it was dead so no you weren't busy AT ALL, Im extremely picky when it comes to this detail. As far as the food its just alright, no biggie lacks flavor if you really want to know. I prefer the other location on Mission near 30th.
author: Vee N.

description: This location was recently renovated and it's much more spacious and clean.  The pupusas are not greasy, which is hard to find.  Pupusas are DELICIOUS, by far some of the best we've had!!
author: Rosa G.

description: Delicious food made with fresh ingredients and really friendly, accommodating service. Recently remodeled their interior and with playful soccer ball lights and there's a fun little surprise when your check arrives after the meal.
author: Marc H.

description: Went today with my family unfortunately the 3 stars is for the poor service. Also the surcharge that was added I was not okay with that. First of all why do a surcharge if your service sucks. Now are the price for the pupusas reasonable ummm No 3.50 for one. And you must order two why?! Will I come back umm I doubt it.
author: Veronica L.

description: I got charged $13 dollars for a plate of beans which was nothing special! I got 2 bean pupusas and casamiento. The pupusas were bland, just plain flavorless. The casamiento wasn't made the way it is traditionally made and wasn't good either. The rice in the casamiento also had the consistency of plastic and was a very small portion compared to the fried beans in the casamiento. Casamiento is not a dish made with fried beans, it is made with whole beans and the rice quantity is larger than the beans in the dish. This place is a complete rip off and trash. I also called before hand to ask if they had vegan pupusas and they said yes. The person I spoke to over the phone said they're able to make them with zucchini, basil, spinach and beans. But when I got there they said it's not possible. So I asked for casamiento thinking it would be traditionally made since people in the reviews raved about its authenticity which is not the case. When I was done eating there weren't many people left so I sat for 10 minutes and still no waiter checked in on my table even though they had nothing going on. I got up and paid and left. This place has bad customer service and bland, flavorless food I recommend people go elsewhere. This place is complete trash and ridiculously tiny and overpriced!
author: Eli B.

description: I waited for 25 minutes in a mostly empty restaurant for two perfectly fine pupusas. 25min for two pupusas to-go!!! Just go to La Santeneca instead.
author: Selin K.

description:
I've been having a lot of very specific food cravings recently. Don't worry everyone, I'm not pregnant! Anyway, last week I was craving pupusas and based on 7x7, Balompie Cafe appeared to be a safe bet.

My friend and I walked in and seated ourselves in the corner, away from the folks who had clearly engaged in some serious day drinking. My friend insisted on getting a steak dish but I was focused on pupusas. I ordered two of them with chicharon and queso made with harina de arroz (in my opinion, rice flour pupusas are so much better than the corn masa variety). Like every Salvadoran restaurant I've ever gone to (and trust me, I've been to quite a few), service was extra slow. Don't go there when you're really hungry or you might end up becoming agitated.

When the pupusas arrived, I was happy with the result. The outside stayed soft and the cheese inside was gooey and melted. The only criticism would be that there wasn't enough chicharon; the ratio of cheese and meat was off. If I ever crave pupusas again, I would certainly be willing to return to Balompie .
author: Yi Z.

description:
This place is horrible compared to Balompie #3. Never coming here again. Never got menus after we were seated and it's been over 30 minutes and our papusas are still not here. Everyone around us is also complaining about how long their food is taking.  

This location doesn't have carne asada papusas and their portion of plantains is way smaller than their other location. It's almost 3pm it's not like there is this huge lunch rush so not sure why they are taking forever. Avoid this place at all costs and go to the one in Bernal Heights.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Pupusas galore!

Went here on a Sunday night and it was packed! That's a good sign, right?

Special Pupusa (steak & cheese) - This was heavenly!!! Couldn't have asked for a better pupusa. Can't wait to try the other pupusas out!

Tamale (pork) - I really disliked this dish. I'm used to tamales that are robust and don't fall apart. This tamale seemed overcooked, oily, and mushy......would not recommend.

The prices are reasonable for the quality and taste. Would recommend....only for pupusas!!
author: Vee B.

description:
This was my first pupusa experience! Wasn't too worried about whether or not I'd like 'em since pretty much every carb gets the "thumbs up" on my rating scale. 

Came to Balompie for dinner with a group of 7, which I figured would take forever to be seated. Had our other five diners not arrived super late, we could've been accommodated within 10-15 minutes. Instead two of stood by the bar and waited for the rest of the party to arrive. It ended up being about 30 minutes total, since the servers do an excellent job at getting customers in and out. 

Sangria is a must! Nothing too fancy, just red wine and fruit. Get a carafe to share or simply have a really generous single serving. It's not very strong but since when does sangria need to knock you on your arse?

Since I was a virgin to the pupusa, order a combination plate complete with a shrimp pupusa, chicharones, fried yucca, and a potato thingy that was OK. By far, the highlight was the pupusa. Would eat like 10 more if given the chance. 

Never even thought to come to Balompie for breakfast, but now that the seed has been planted (plaintaned?) in my head, will definitely keep in mind for something casual and affordable. Without a long wait out the door!
author: Abby S.

description:
Pupusas! Cheesy, heart-warming goodness and also one of the more affordable things to eat in the city (2 for $6 I believe). I love their side dish of pickled veggies as well which goes great with the cheesiness of the pupusas.

Takes a little time but the service is friendly and attentive.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Came here on a whim after a run (we parked nearby and were starving!). The BF loves pupusas and I've heard of this place countless times so we stopped in.

To start off, my standard for pupusas is set quite high - I usually go to Estrelita's (over at the Alemany farmer's market on Saturdays). 

Since this was a sit-down place, it didn't seem as 'authentic', but fret not as that is an UNTRUE statement.
The pupusas here were actually marginally better (more cheese, less dough). Perfect pillows of cheesy, yummy goodness. I liked it more than Estrelita's actually. And the price was pretty much the same, AND there's legit seating? Count me in.
One pupusa will sate your appetite, and if you have a voracious diet, two would probably do.. not for the diet-conscious though. DAMN IT, CHEESE. For me, cheese is always worth it. 

The wait was kind of long though. We ordered 3 pupusas in a half-filled restaurant and it probably took 30 minutes? I will note that pupusas are hand-shaped and crafted, and made to order.. it takes a while to heat up both sides on the grill (they're not really a fast food like pancakes) - and I'm sure the grill only can make a certain number at a time, so if it was REALLY busy, I imagine the wait can be reeealllyyy lonnggggg. :/

Overall, the restaurant is clean, the wait staff here is super nice and attentive (smiles all around!) and I'd definitely return and recommend!
author: Emily C.

description:
Swung by with my co-workers around 3PM on a Saturday. Service was a bit slow but the pupusas I ordered were the cucumbers and the pork w/ cheese.

They looked and tasted very fresh and really good. Authentic and just thinking about it right now makes me want one. There were a lot of different options to try and I would like to try them all eventually. 

Many different options for me to try when I'm in SF, so I'm not sure how often I'll be able to come back and visit this place.
author: Kenny N.

description: I was looking forward to this place, heard it was good. Food was alright. Took hella long to get it. Waitress was not attentive and sort of rude. Not a smile, looked irritated to be serving.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Where on earth have pupusas been all my life?! I've been to Balompie #3 in Bernal Heights and this one and they're both awesome! Delicious, affordable, and there are so many papusas to choose from! 

Pupusas are still relatively new to me. I've had a homemade one and have only tried them at a handful of restaurants, but the ones at Balompie are the best ones I've had! I've had the shrimp and cheese, pork, jalepeno, and cheese, and fish and cheese, and they're all flavorful, generous with ingredients, and perfectly cooked. Topped off with the traditional pickled cabbage and salsa, it was a refreshing mix of flavors. Two is the perfect amount for me if you're looking for a light dinner. The standard filling papusas are $2.50, while the specialty ones (which are the ones I got) are $3.50. I like how you can mix and match because I could never choose just one! Shrimp and cheese is my favorite though! 

I've had a plate of two enchiladas here as well and a side of rice and fried plantains to share. The enchilada is like a super-fried papusa instead of a tortilla-type wrap, topped with lettuce, tomato, cheese, sour cream and shredded pork. The crunch adds an unexpected twist, but it's absolutely delicious! Kind of like a mini plate of nachos, consolidated all onto one giant chip. 

Balompie has been featured numerous times in 7x7's Big Eat List, so you don't need me to tell you that they're super yummerz. I had no intention of trying this place until I went here with a group of friends, but now they're on my list of go-to places for El Salvadorean food, and papusas of course!
author: Deanna Y.

description:
Ordered the # 1 platanos and frijoles with queso and crema. So flavorful, would recommend to anyone.
I also ordered a chicharron and queso pupusasl which was pretty good. The queso and frijoles pupusas was delicious.
author: Herbert G.

description:
It's just like home!
Best Pupusas in the Bay Area!! Don't let other lie to you!
A small, comfortable place with real authentic food!!
Great costumer service!
Once you try it... You'll never look for any other Salvadorean place again!!
author: Enrique R.

description:
If you are in San Francisco and craving for some pupusas, this is your place. The pupusas are so delicious. My favorites are La Revueltas, with some sweet plantains and beans. Love the flavor of the pork and cheese, very fresh and tender.  The cheese pupusas are also good.

Great for brunch and have some Salvadorian dishes for a change. If you go on Sunday, please be patient because the place is not to big and it gets really crowded. But it's worth the wait.
author: Patricia R.

description:
I've come here many times throughout many years. The place is mighty filthy and run down. Their dishes do not convince me--the place is just a fonda, average to low quality home made style food. The only good dish is the pupusas. There is a sports channel TV where I've watched footbal soccer world cup games. Typical San Francisco slow service.

I give this restaurant a low rating because it's been overrated by Yelpers, their food is low quality, the place is mighty filthy, and their service is slow.
author: Raymond F.

description:
Wow what can I say but I was in pupusa heaven in this place.  This is one of the best little hole-in-the-wall you will ever go to. The food is excellent! The food is cheap. The restaurant has individual tables and family style sitting. It feels very homey and familiar. If you have never eaten El Salvadorian food this is the best place to try it.  

I ordered the pupusas since that is what all the reviews say to get. Notable ones to get:
ground pork and cheese
ground beef and cheese
chorizo and cheese
shrimp and cheese
spinach and cheese

The wait for the pupusas itself was pretty long, so I suggest you get an appetizer while waiting. As soon as they served the pupusas, even if they were deep fried they were not to oily. The dough was just the right thickness. The cheese was the filling made this a celebration in your mouth, to add to the party put some salsa and cabbage slaw on top of each pupusa so texture is not too dry. Yeah...FIESTA time!  One pupusa is quite filling, good to eat it is hot.

If your not feeling a pupusa, order the Carne Asada, the meat is delicious comes with the Sopa Ros, flavorful and light soup. Love how reasonable eveything is!!!  Four stars because of the slow service.
author: Maria M.

description:
Stick to the pupusas which give you the best value for your money. I love the Shrimp and cheese version.

Since it was early in the morning, my friend and I wanted to try their breakfast. Their brekkie plates were expensive! Starting at $8.95 and going up to $12! Ay dios mio! 

Service was so-so, but won't stop me from getting pupusas since it's close to ODC dance studio.
author: Janice C.

description:
Unfortunately, we had a disappointing meal here tonight.  I have had great experiences at Balompie before, but today's meal was not good.

My husband and I each ordered the grilled red snapper, mine with garlic sauce, his with tomato sauce.  The fish was bland and the sauce really lacked flavor.  I've gotten this dish in the past and really liked it - I don't know what happened today.

Fortunately, the super veggie pupusa I got was very good.

The service was also disappointing, in that when I told the waitress I didn't care for the fish, she said she'd look into it, but then never did.
author: Barnali D.

description:
I grew up in the neighborhood and would walk by every day on my way to school. I walked in once with my family about 10 or so years ago and ended up leaving because we waited over 20 minutes to even have our order taken.

I stopped by today and it looks like nothing has changed. We walked in and none of the workers greeted us so we assumed we had to seat ourselves. After we ordered, we waited about 20-30 minutes for our food. During this time I observed the workers and they were so unorganized. One young lady who I had thought was the hostess was bringing people their checks (something the server is supposed to do) and quickly tossing them on the table and walking away. Fortunately for her, the server brought us our check. The food was great and worth the wait and the server was friendly which is why I'm giving it 4 stars. 

I'm glad I finally stopped by; however, hopefully next time I go there is a designated hostess/busser cleaning tables and seating people. This will speed up service guaranteed.
author: Janette M.

description:
100 Best Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2013

#30 Pupusas at Balompie Cafe

If I had to guess their pupusas are made to order because it tasted fresh and had a great consistency to the masa. Also, they have many filling options which leads me to believe it's easier for them to fill the pupusa as they are ordered then try to figure out which one is which. 

I had the chicharron y queso $2.50 + camarones y queso $3.50. Out of the two, my favorite was definitely the chicharron, no surprise there! The flavors were good and properly seasoned. Keep in mind their pupusas have a thin profile and the filling is just enough. I loved the crisp bits of cheese on the outside and felt that was what brought the dish to the next level.

Overall Thoughts

Definitely a tasty pupusa! Well worth a try!
author: Eddie W.

description:
I'm not sure how quickly we would have discovered this place had it not been for Yamo being too busy and us being pressed for time. I'm so happy that happened because now I know Balompie Cafe exists and it's amazing. 

The restaurant is cozy with dark walls and lots of football paraphernalia. They have a refrigerator with a gigantic bucket of sangria inside which looked delicious, but since we were going in and out for a quick meal we get didn't get to try it this time around. 

I'm so ashamed to admit that I had never had papusas before. I've had arepas, but not true Salvadorian style and flavor papusa! My life is definitely more complete. We ordered the plain cheese one and one with pork and cheese. I should have gotten the pork one with jalapeno because to me there wasn't much distinction between the two, but absolutely delicious nonetheless. Hot melty cheese, slightly crispy, and golden yellow. 

It was also wonderful to start off our meal with a complementary side salad and Curtido (Salvadorian cabbage salad). It can be compared to Kimchee except not nearly as fermented, and really delicious especially for my Nepali palate that appreciates the salty, sour, and hot combination. Papusas were also great with a touch of their salsa. 

For our main meal, we ordered the beef steak with onions. So many countries have their own version of this. The gravy on here was mouthwatering. The steak is drenched in this delicious sauce both rich in color and flavor. There was plenty of it for the side of rice. Hmm. I wish I could bottle it up for some homemade mashed potatoes.

The service was very nice and the prices are reasonable, too. 

I came to Balompie Cafe expecting a decent meal, and left so impatient to wait for the next time. I'll definitely be back!
author: Priti K.

description:
Their pupusas are to die for! They are the right price and not too oily, which I'm particular about. Keep in mind, I'm half salvadorian so I'm well aware of what an authentic pupusa tastes like. Their curtido is delicious! The proportionate amount of vinegar to pickle the cabbage is spot on each time. 

The service is quick and friendly! I recommend this location along with their other spots.
author: Stacy V.

description: The service was great and the pupusas are yummy.  Prices are reasonable and the service is fast if you have 2-3 people.  This place is busy so come early.
author: Chris L.

description:
Tiny El Salvadorian spot in Bernal Heights with unbelievably good Papusas (or I'll call them Papus :) ) 
Best of all for me was that they had quite a few vegetarian ones. I tried the zucchini and cheese and bean + cheese. Yes, very cheesy but just sooo good.
Note you have to order a minimum of two Papus per person if you order them. They're $2.50 each so not a biggie. Just that they're filling so you'll probably take back left overs.
Their guacamole is also fresh and simply yum and the red salsa/sauce served with the Papus is also great.
Yummy yummy would definitely come back :)
author: Kinjal N.

description:
I came to this restaurant with parents on Saturday (9/19) on a recommendation from a family member. We have been trying to go to this restaurant for months now, but it was always crowded. We assumed it must be that good. Alas, our experience there wasn't even Luke warm. 

We ordered pupusas; my parents got the traditional corn masa and I got (I think) the rice masa. My initial reaction was the pupusas were mushy. They had very little depth in flavor and the revueltas had very little pork, but a lot of cheese. I had one that had the zucchini squash, but there was too much ajo (garlic) and again, very little ingredients except the cheese. The pupusas again, mushy and could have used more flavor.

I'm sure the other food might be tasty, like the plátanos fritos (which by the way for the amount they give you is a little overpriced). The thing that makes this a two star review was the service. We didn't get a good amount of service. The waiters did not check up on us, but were at the beck and call of the techies coming in. They received better service than most of the Latinos that were there. I'll probably get chastised for say that, but I'm a very observant person and a pretty big foodie. If the quality of the service is only customer for a certain group of people, then the quality of the food is probably not that great. 

It's a trend I see in the Mission District; restaurants are dumping their traditional forms of cooking to please a group of people now occupying it. It's a little disappointing. 

Let me again highlight why this place wasn't that great:
- Mushy pupusas 
- Ingredients lacked flavor
- The mixed pupusas didn't have enough ingredients other than cheese. 
- The service was lack luster and catered to a specific group of people. 

I'll try the other Balompie location and see what's up. If I come back to this location, maybe the service and food will be better.
author: Arturo R.

description:
Was there this am for breakfast and soccer. I had the vegetarian omelette which was huge and maybe too much food? It came with rice, and beans ( usually not a fan, but I licked them off my plate because they were sooo good) and fresh, hot tortillas. Their latte was really excellent too... Who knew?

Barely ate dinner tonight because I was still stuffed from breakfast.... About $10 and a total steal.

Waitstaff was still excellent, and it's still a run down little hole in the wall with good food.
author: El B.

description: If I could I would give this place -10000 stars. Took over an hour to get pupusas, like really? I've ate at other restaurants and its taken 30 minutes at most! They could have at least told us there was a back up, but we got nothing. They never came to check on us or tell us anything. Then the mediocre waiter with the Argentinian restaurant came to say something to our table after I complained. He said "it wasn't their fault"..... Yes it is, for not telling us (at least!). I thank the manager for saying "sorry" but she was on the floor and didn't even come up to say anything while we waited. Whoever owns the place needs better WAITERS! Both men were rude when I complained.
author: Yedid G.

description: This place is gooooood!!! The pupusas are big, not abnormal big. Good size. They are perfect with just enough cheese and chicharron, not too thick with masa like other places. The yucca con chicharron delicious and to top off dinner.....the platano frito w/ casamiento. Omg! Perfect flavors, great service and reasonably priced. Would I come here next time I'm in San Fran, YES...yes...yes!!!!
author: Jaz G.

description:
Balompie is different from most places in the Mission, in a good way.

It's a local spot without the long lines. Super friendly waitstaff that's proud of the food they serve. Ask your server what to order.

Pupusas!
author: Marcus C.

description:
I've never had El Salvadorian food nor a pupusa. But I've heard great things about them.

Since Paypal had an offer available for Balompie Cafe and they had good reviews, I just had to go!

We ordered two pupusas: the jalapeno, pork, and cheese and the chorizo and cheese to go. They pack you the sauce and cabbage to go too. The pupusas are cheap!  $3.50 each roughly for speciality pupusas and $2.50 for regular pupusas. Our food took a while to make. I was surprised because they weren't busy at all and they didn't have many orders to make. Despite the 15-20 min wait, our food was finally ready. I could smell the delicious pupusas the entire ride home.

They were still hot when we got home. Yay! and not soggy! We placed the sauce and cabbage on top and we dug in. The pupusas were DELICIOUS! It's hard to judge when I've never had it before. They definitely put lots of cheese in them, I wish they put a bit more meat. But I loved the combination of everything.

I'll definitely be back to try more pupusas! Yay!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
On a cold and rainy night, Karen Y and I braved the storm for our 7x7 big eat adventure.

2012 #30: pupusas

There were so many choices on the menu, all sounding every delicious! We ended up sharing Chicharrón (pork and cheese) and Mariscos y Queso (fish, shrimp & cheese) pupusas.

With the fillings finely minced, there was no telling between the two until you take a bite. We easily tasted the fish and shrimp, and pork. The salsa roja for the pupusas was also very good.

Plantains with sour cream

We also ordered the plantains thinking it'll be a small side. It was a generous portion. Having them with sour cream was new to me, but it helped cut through the sweetness and added a light tang to it. Also delicious!

Will be back for more pupusas! =)
author: Marti L.

description:
Love this cozy place, the food is great and the service is friendly!

Seating is self-serve, inside or outside.  The metal chairs outside aren't too comfy though, I suggest sitting inside.  Occasionally singers with guitars wander in, tip if you feel so inclined.

We always order the carne asada, fried fish, fried yucca and of course pupusas.  The food is always seasoned well and delicious.  We had pasteles for the first time last week and how have I lived without ever eating these glorious, tiny empanadas?  Soooo good.  The only dish we would not recommend is the beef stew, while the flavor was good the meat was a bit too tough for our liking.

A minor issue we have had here is that a couple of times we ordered items that were never brought out but were listed on the bill, the waitresses always took off the charges with no problem though.  If you order sides to your entrée just be vigilant about making sure it is coming before the end of the meal arrives.

Definitely one of the top three restaurants for pupusas and great food all around!
author: Mailah G.

description:
Maybe it was their off day because service was terrible. At the end of the day, we ended up with another table's check on top of our own! I'm not paying for that...and our waitress was apparently a manager there?! SMH. Our group of 5 arrived earlier, and later on we added 5 more to the table . Good thing the table right next to the 5 that arrive earlier were about to leave so we swooped their spot right after. 

Realistically I'm giving them a 4 star for their Pupusas because they are worth that much. I've never had Pupusas in my life, and since this was my first time, it definitely blew my mind.

What I've ordered: 
- Mejicana Y Queso ground pork, jalapenos & cheese      
- Gringa Y Queso ground beef & cheese      
- Chorizo Y Queso sausage & cheese
- Chicharron Y Queso mixed ground pork & cheese

What I got was my friend's order:
- Mariscos Y Queso fish, shrimp & cheese      
- Italiana Y Queso prosciutto & cheese      
- Mejicana Y Queso ground pork, jalapenos & cheese
- Chorizo Y Queso sausage & cheese

My friends' order were apparently wrong because they never got the Mariscos one. I don't remember eating that either; however, the waitress said that the shrimp is really small so you can't taste it. Like what? Maybe they should consider making it a little bigger? WHATEVER. We didn't want to dispute and just went with that. 

I'll come back to try the other Pupusas & see how much of a better service they'll give.
author: Anna L.

description:
Balompie in 18th capp, not good, first day are late in their phone orders, bad services, pupusas are not well cooked.
I taught it's was like the one in balompie in Richland they pupusas are the bomb 
If you want good balompie on 18th capp is not the one
author: Margarita L.

description:
I have been coming to Cafe Balompie for over 10 years and it never fails me as far as their pupusas go. They are a pretty small when it comes to space, but the food is very authentic. I feel like I'm back at home. I recommend going early in the morning if you want to catch a seat, because it does get packed at times.

Besides their pupusas, their traditional platano, crema, and frijoles plate is also bomb.
author: Karen H.

description:
It's obviously been a while since I've been here but in the meantime I've tried a few papusas at other places. I'm not sure if the quality of the papusas has gone down in the past 7 years or if I just have more experience to judge them by but they weren't that great this time. Just okay.

The normal papusas are $2.50 each, min 2 per person. I got the chicharrón con queso and loroco con queso. Chicharrón wasn't very distinguishable regarding the actual chicharon. I'd be hard pressed to guess they were in there. Who knows? Maybe they got my order wrong and they weren't chicharrón! The loroco was much better. I'm not sure what Salvadorean vegetable it was but it was tasty - reminded me a little of chinese pickled mustard greens for some reason.

I'm not sure I would return when there are better papusas elsewhere sadly.
author: Jean K.

description:
First off, I like supporting local businesses in my 'hood, but I also love Balompie's pupusas.  It's a mostly Latino crowd but I'm always warmly welcomed by the servers. 

For breakfast they have several egg dishes, which I'm guessing are common Salvadoran combos that come with delicious housemate tortillas and coffee. My favorite is to order a couple of different pupusas with a side of scrambled eggs - tasty and satisfying.  Probably my favorite pupusas in SF.
author: Scott L.

description:
If you're not familiar with this area, as I am not then you will definitely walk past this place. After a little time exploring San Francisco, my brother & I headed here for lunch upon his recommendation. 

I got a chicken sandwich/turkey sandwich? I cant remember. Either way it was good. Tried a pupusa for the 1st time and it was very delicious. 

Also, got the full, authentic, Latin/Salvadorian music experience as there was a man there playing music with a guitar, who must be a regular. I thought this was awesome! There was great service and the prices were decent.
author: Mellissa K.

description:
When mom isn't able to whip up some pupusas of course this is the only other place I will go to. I live in the peninsula and El Zocalo is literally down the street from me, but I wouldn't dare eat there! Balompie is what is real authentic Salvadorian food. The pupusas have just the right amount of filling and they aren't greasy like other places. 
The service is good, the location is small and of course parking sucks but it is so worth it.
author: Irma R.

description: I just walked out of this place after waiting 45 minutes and not even being given water. The waitress gave me a dirty look when I asked for water 30 minutes after ordering and sitting there, hungry and watching people who sat after me finishing their food. First time I've walked out after ordering in my life.
author: sharonv n.

description:
This place is amazing....and I drive all the way across town to go there.
Everything we ordered was delicious and I could foodie-out about ever dish we ordered.
Plantains are outta control and surprisingly, so was the shrimp!!
author: Kai R.

description:
I'm giving it 2 stars for the customer service. 

Poor customer service. From the moment I walked in, we stood there waiting for one of the waiters to seat us. A huge party came in right after us & instead of coming to us first, they went ahead and seated them first. Total disrespect. I finally got one of the waiters attention and ordered my food quickly because I knew what I wanted. I ordered atleast 7 pupusas only. I waited exactly 45 min for my food to come out! The party that came in after us was already finished with their food & everything! 

The outcome of the papusas were good but it wasn't worth the wait.
author: Tiarah P.

description:
1. Summary:
My second time trying El Salvadorian food. I thought the pupusas were ok, but was not impressed with the taste, did not find them flavorful enough. Liked the papusas at Panchitas more.
Seemed like more of a place for watching sports than food.
(Points: 6/10)

2. Food:  
Had the vegetable, and the chorizo pupusa
For my taste, they were too cheesy and bland.
Liked the chorizo pupusa a little more than the veggie one.
Also had the custard empanada.....it was well done, but did not like the overall taste too much.
My friends liked their mimosas, and my juice of the day (tamarind) was not bad.
(Points 5/10)

3. Ambience :
Pretty good.
(Points 7/10)

4. Price: 
Pricy compared to the quality of food
(Points: 7/10)

5. Variety:
They seemed to have good variety, but did not get a chance to try a lot as we did not go in with a full apetite.
(Points: 8/10)

6. Service:
Slow. Seemed more of a sports place, so probably service not a priority.
(Points: 5/10)

7. Value for money: 6/10

8. Wishlist: 
DId not like the minimum 2 pupusas per person restriction

***Note - I personally care about food the most and hence my overall rating is more biased towards food and less towards other factors like ambience, price, service, etc.
My taste buds are more used to Indian flavors, so I'm not able to always appreciate foreign flavors, although I love expanding my horizons and trying out new foods.
I am mostly a vegetarian, and occasionally eat meat, so my orders have a heavy bias towards vegetarian items.
author: Tejas B.

description:
My roommate's friend was visiting and they wanted to go out and get pupusas...not gonna lie, I really wanted some too.

We made our way over to Balompie. Service is generally nice and fairly prompt. It took the longest to get our check.

I ordered two pupusas: the loroco y queso and the chicharrones y queso. I also ordered a glass of orchata.

The orchata was the best that I've had in the city. I've never been so happy with a cup of orchata. I don't know how they made it but it was milkier than usual and it had a slight cocoa taste (to me anyway).

The pupusas were awesome especially considering the price ($2.50). The pork one was hearty and the loroco one was interesting. The loroco y queso was my favorite for sure. I loved the cabbage and red sauce they gave me too. 

Perfection. I want to go back for more orchata and for their empanada de leche.
author: Sofia R.

description:
More people should eat pupusas. Balompie Cafe is legit. They don't mask things with frills or flashy decorations or loud music. It's just you and the food. The best part? So cheap!

Our pupusa order:
Loroco y Queso
Mexicana y Queso
Chorizo y Queso
Camaron y Queso
and Yuca Frita con Pollo

Skip the yucas. They were over fried. All of the pupusas were tasty, and you can't go wrong with any of them. My brother preferred the chorizo. The only problem was that I'm pretty sure they gave us the wrong pupusas... but we were still happy.
author: J J.

description: Well, we had wonderful pupusas tonight. Very cheesy and perfectly grilled. The curtido here is also excellent. But... Service? Not good at all. Oh they were very nice when I felt dizzy and they offered to help. But food service? All I can say is that an hour later, two of us have finished our meal and one is still waiting for her order (which is the same as mine was so didn't need extra time to cook).  The wait staff keeps blaming us and saying we didn't order hers with the rest? Excuse me? We did. And English is spoken well here so that's not the problem. The combination of slow response and blaming the customer means we are not very likely to return. Sad as the food is really delicious, but crappy service is... Crappy
author: Joy S.

description:
Why does the Mission have to have such good stuff?!

Another hidden gem, well to me it's hidden. I was papusa'd at first bite. I've had a few papusas in my life, but my gosh... I am in LOVE. If you haven't tried it, I seriously recommend that you go and order it. 

thinking about the papusas make me pretty darn happy. yeah, thats how good it is. I wish i was hyping it up, you need to have it warm and oooozing of flavors!
author: Mimi T.

description:
This used to be my go to spot for pupusas. I went there this past weekend with my family and boy was it a HORRIBLE experience!  I wanted to take my sister there because she had never been. So we were supposed to be second on the list, but somehow everyone else got seated before us.  So half an hour later, we get seated, fine.  We waited about 10 minutes she took our order. Then we waited, and waited AND WAITED!!! I looked around, everyone else that sat after us were enjoying their beverages, we still hadn't even been served water. A nice anglo family got seated next to us and low and behold...they got water with fresh ice right away...as we were slowly dehydrating in our seats.  So another couple minutes later, I look back at a table that got seated after us and they were eating.  My blood was starting to boil, they still hadn't even given us water. My fiance' had to ask them for water and the waitress said, oh that's not my table. Really?!?!?!?! you can't just give us some water?!?!?!  Mind you we were sitting directly across from the water station....how hard would it have been to just give us some water?  My fiance' had to leave because we was gonna loose his cool. We staid another couple of minutes and I couldn't take it anymore, we got up and walked out. I hope the waitress had to eat the bill we left.

VERY VERY SAD!!!!!

We have been long time customers and to be treated with such horrible customer service is a disgrace!  You should be ashamed of the way you treat people that have been coming there for years, especially quando es su jente!  Because of this I will never go there again.

My daughter who is 4 loves pupusas, that's all she wanted that day. Needless to say she didn't get any.
author: LuLu M.

description: The pupusas are great, best ones I have ever tried but we suspect my card was cloned here and got charges up to $1000. The waitress took the cards (chip cards) for fairly long time and a couple of weeks later I was having this charges. I never recovered my money, watch out for places where the take your cards to pay the bill.
author: Andres M.

description:
I LOVE Balompie. This is a hole in the wall pupuseria with the biggest, most delicious varieties of pupusas. Not just anyone can make a great pupusa, so if you've never eaten a pupusa before, try one at Balompie first! 

My favorite is a traditional pupusa revuelta or mixed pupusa with beans, cheese and pork. My husband, who is from El Salvador, can't get enough of this place. He has traditional cheese pupusas with loroco, but he also loves their special non traditional varieties like shrimp pupusas and the Italian style pupusa. OH, and their horchata is the horchata the Gods drink, yeah, it's that good.
author: Araceli P.

description:
Loved the chorizo and cheese pupusas! Ordered an assortment of other pupusas (pork + cheese, prosciutto + cheese, beef + cheese) for the table to share, but the others all kind of tasted the same (ie meat + cheese). We also ordered fried yuca, which I thought was really tasty! The pupusas are a good deal, but the yuca was more expensive than I expected, considering I didn't care for the toppings and just wanted more fried yuca haha. 

The only downside was that the food took a really long time to arrive. Being a small casual restaurant that wasn't at capacity, I expected a wait time of maybe 10 min max. But we ended up waiting for 20+ min before the food arrived! (and we were only a table of 5...) We were grabbing dinner before a concert, and because the food took so long we ended up missing the opening act :( But otherwise, the service was friendly and easy to get ahold of!
author: Audrey G.

description:
I've been craving pupusas for awhile so I knew I had to drag bf to Mission to get some!  I've heard so much about Balompie because it's been on the 7x7 list so we decided to head over to this location.  Oh Mission how I love how you make parking such a pain in the ass for us!  After about 15 minutes of circling around we finally got lucky with a spot across the street.  

FIrst thing I noticed upon entering is how cramped the seating is.  We ended up sitting at the semi communal table (bunch of tables connected together). This place is on the smaller side and was packed on a Sunday afternoon.  He and I both ordered a shrimp and cheese pupusa ($3.95), he also got a sausage & cheese one ($3.95) & I chose a traditional cheese and pork one ($2.95) for my second.  The wait for the pupusas were a little longer than other places we've been to but they were so yummy!  He liked the shrimp one the best while I liked the pork and cheese one the most!  They were big and had plenty of cheese oozing out.  The curtido and hot sauce added the finishing touches to them.  

Prices here are slightly higher for pupusas and the place is packed, but definitively worth it if you're craving a pupusa while in Mission.
author: Cat C.

description:
This place has really awesome Salvadorean food.  The best option is one of the mixed plates, such as the plato tipico #1, which has one papusa, one pastelle, and one yuca frita.  I don't know where else in the city I can get yucas fritas with pescaditas (fried smelts).  

Pretty affordable, too ... less than $20 a person unless you hit the beer heavily.

Warning: do not go here during the World Cup finals unless you're really into futbol.
author: Josh B.

description: This was my first time trying pupusas, and I think I picked the right place! I loved the pupusas at Balompie Cafe. I had the frijoles y queso, espinaca y queso, and the chicharrón y queso. It's hard to pick a favorite, but I think I liked the frijoles y queso best. The hot sauce was great too. My friend ordered the Ground Pork, Jalapeños & Cheese pupusa and the Ground Beef & Cheese pupusa. We also each had an horchata. The horchata was excellent too. I'm definitely putting Balompie Cafe down as one of my favorite restaurants in the Mission.
author: Andrew L.

description:
The pupusa was ok, there was so little meat or vegetables in the ones I ordered that I wasn't sure if they gave me 2 cheese filled ones accidentally.  I enjoyed the pork/cheese pupusa just wish that there was more meat!  Interesting twist with the lightly fermented cabbage slaw with red chilies and vinegar on top.. added a nice complexity to the cheese and corn tortilla.

Not my cup of tea, but it was fun joking about the word "pupusa" for the rest of the weekend.  Immature? Yes!
author: Melody T.

description:
So, when boyfriend was in town and we found ourselves in the Mission around lunchtime, I decided to take him to Balompie because I had a great experience the one other time I went for lunch and he'd never tasted pupusas before.

Okay, so the food is really tasty, inexpensive, and unique. I love the deep fried yuca and the orchata. However, there are a few things that really, really got to me during my last visit.

1. The floors are always FILTHY. The first time I was here, there was some sort of brownish goop under the table that was right in my line of vision. I mean, I live in the Tenderloin, so I see feces all the time. I knew it wasn't feces. I kept telling myself that it was probably smushed pupusa and not to be so disgusted, but it didn't work. There were bits of food and dirt under every table. I really don't mind hole in the wall spots that have dingy walls and beat up furniture (Did you see the part where I said I live in the Tenderloin?), but to have a dirty floor was a little too much for me. 

2. The tables are way too close together! Normally, I drape my purse on the back of my chair. You can't do that here. I had to eat with my purse in my lap because of course I wouldn't put it on the floor. (See above.)  The lady sitting directly behind me had full, curly hair and whenever she would laugh or adjust herself, I could feel her hair brush up on my neck. It was really annoying.

3. Boyfriend and I were seated immediately, but it took them 20 minutes to give us a menu. That's just unacceptable. After the server took our order, it took another 40-50 minutes just to get our food. People who ordered before us (and were ordering SECONDS) got their food before we got our order. I also find this unacceptable. I was about to walk out. The server did not check in on us once, even though I kept looking at her to try to signal her over. It wasn't until I raised my hand that she came to help us. What made me the most mad is that I saw her give the table next to me such prompt and attentive service.  (I will add that this didn't happen my first trip here, but after this experience I may never again come back.)
author: Jenn C.

description:
I would walk by this place if I didn't know better. 

Got dinner here & really enjoyed it. The prices are totally reasonable & food so good. I wasn't feeling so adventure & got the steak-fries. Man, was that well done & authentic. My friend got the 'pupusa' and really enjoyed it. 

Can't beat Latin American food in the Mission.
author: Juan T. K.

description:
Nice staff, great food, and a really welcoming environment. It's a little off the main strip in Mission, but my partner and I really liked Balompie Cafe. 

Pupusas, as everyone has mentioned here, are LEGIT. Get two. One cheese and another one from the menu. Hot, tasty, and done the right way. (You have to get two anyway, since I think there's a minimum order of 2.)

We also ordered the steak with onions (and gravy), and it was cooked perfectly. Gravy was on point. Really, nothing to complain about!
author: Tik P.

description: Cheapest meal in the city hands down. And the papusas are fresh and delicious as hell to boot! the greatness doesn't even end there because the service is quite friendly and down to earth, always very accommodating. The atmosphere is chill, never crazy packed. I always feel comfortable taking my time. Fresh, hot, never-greasy, melty-cheese papusas on tha low! Takes 15 to 20 minutes so don't go if you're in a wild rush.. but ya can't beat hot and fresh!! A great treat to grab for a picnic in Dolores down the street
author: Hannah C.

description: My co-workers and I ordered pupusas from here the other day. Because it was Friday and still Lent, I ordered the zucchini pupusas. Very yummy and so was there curtido. They're a little pricey, but worth it! I still like Los Panchos, but Balompie's comes in second and La Santaneca third!
author: Neni E.

description:
Still scoring.

Translated: http://www.spanishcentral.com/translate/balompie

Last time: http://www.yelp.com/biz/balompie-cafe-san-francisco-3?hrid=d_acW1UGu_mdZ-3AeyHEgQ

This time: More egg whites only now with spinach, rice, refried beans and a brilliant orange colored sauce. Add one smooth Americano. Together it was excellent.

We also shared a pupusa with Salvadoran specialty loroco (vine with edible flowers) and cheese. Easily could have eaten the entire rich brilliance alone.

About $15/person total.

Returned a few days later to try the grilled chicken sandwich. Appreciated swapping a simple salad for fries and keeping off the mayo and cheese. Delicious as is.

It was expensive at $10 plus tax and tip but worth it as it was large enough to possibly be two meals. But was so hungry we'll never know.

Service on both visits was exceptionally friendly and attentive. Vibe was lively no doubt in part from the space being decorated with plenty of soccer accents.

Hope they keep winning for years to come.
author: Jason B.

description:
I have eaten here for many years.
But no more!!!
Last weekend I went there for dinner by myself and was seated at a table for four because it was the only table available.
When I was ready to order my food I was ask to give up my table for a larger party and wait for another table.
I left and will never come back.
Customers deserve better respect than that.
author: Manuel Y.

description:
Delicious pupusas at a fantastic price.  I had the pupusa set with rice and beans on the side, but I would just get more pupusas next time because the beans were too salty for me.  

The pupusas are very well made and bursting with a generous amount of cheese without being brittle at all.  The cornmeal aroma made me salivate instantly when the very sweet staff served my plate up.  I'll definitely have to go back to try other fillings.
author: Kenji N.

description:
Papusas are great but are a little over hyped, I've had better ones when I went to school in SJ.

Prices are great, just hate the minimum on ordering two papusas. Sometimes I just want one! I'll come back, but I've had better.

They take cash and credit, which is nice. Slow service during the lunch hour.
author: Samantha D.

description:
This. Is. The . Best. Pupusa. Place. Ever! 
I know that many people would like to say it's the one by 16th by CREAM and Skylark, but those people are probably lying to themselves or have never tried this place. Which is understandable because it is pretty hidden from the main street of Mission. However if you have the luxury to go, Go! It's a pretty small space but has very unique combinations of pupusas, that I haven't seen before. One of my favorites is the proscietto and basil and cheese. Absolutely delicious and about $3 or $3.50 as a specialty however the simple one like cheese and spinach is about $2.5 or so. Pretty affordable and good. What more can you ask for!?
author: Desiree C.

description: Great food! Good prices. I would love to come back here again. Service is a little slow though. The food gets 5 stars, but the service gets 4 stars. Want a good papusa? This is the place to go!!
author: Nate S.

description: I would say 4.5 stars! The pupusas were the best that I have had in SF. I had chicharron (pork) y queso and then queso y frijoles (beans) and they were both very very good-not all oily and soggy either. Their agua de horchata was great too. We also tried the fried shrimp and that was soooo good. I would definitely recommend those. The atmosphere was also great. Staff was very nice and fast which is always appreciated :) We'll be back.
author: Marisol S.

description:
Overall disappointing! My favorite food blog TastingTable recommended this but I felt like Ive had way better Latin American food. Probably the best was the fried yuca, but the pupusa especially werent that great at all.

* Fried Yuca, with Chicharrón / Pork, $8.75
- Perfectly crunchy outer layer, soft steaming inside.
- Pork also cooked fairly well on outside but more tender on the inside
- Flavor wise a little plan but the salsa goes perfect with everything

* Pupusa
* Frijoles / Beans $2.50
* Chorizo y Queso / Sausage & Cheese
- both skimpy on fillings, and dough was really thin, don't get a nice soft fluffy bread that blends in with the filling.
- lacking in flavor, had to have it with salsa
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The papusas were great!  I especially liked the Loroco con queso (native Salvadorian and vegetable and cheese).

Friendly staff and the food looks to be good quality.  Nice atmosphere.
author: Roni K.

description:
Dropped by with a medium-size party after a full day of eating our way through SF. We were in the mood for papusas and this place came highly recommended by a local. I've never had El Salvadorean cuisine before, but this stuff was bomb.

Rating Breakdown:

1.5/2 Stars for Taste -- 
 Four of us decided to split a few papusas so we could try some of each. The only really memorable one was the Mexicana Y Queso (ground pork, jalapeno, and cheese). The others were just fried, cheesy goodness that we eagerly smothered in pickled cabbage and smoky salsa. My friend ordered a horchata, but it was more powdery than we are accustomed to. Apparently, that's how El Salvadorean horchata differs from Mexican horchata (This is what I was told...not sure if this is factual) but I was not a fan.  We also ordered the Tamal De Elote Con Crema (sweet corn tamales) and the Pasteles de Pollo which resembled a fried dumpling stuffed with savory chicken. The corn taste of the tamales was very subtle and it may have been my favorite dish of the night. 

0.5/1 Stars for Value --
The papusas were $2.50 while the specialty papusas were $3.50. We were stopping in for more of a snack than actual dinner so having one papusa each was enough to satisfy us. However, if we were actually really hungry, we could have easily eaten 3-4 papusas each. Not bad pricing for SF, but the portions didn't really justify the cost.

1/1 Stars for Customer Service --
The waitresses were really friendly. The food came quickly. No complaints on this front.

Bonus Star because I would definitely come back if I'm in the area and craving a snack. There were a few papusas on the menu that I would still like to try.
author: Abby W.

description: Amazing food! One of my favorite places for Salvadorian food. Super small place I would come earlier on the weekends to get a place to sit.
author: Christian A.

description:
yea the food taste great, but after seeing how they keep the pupusa stuffing out without plastic wrap by the trash and with the door open.. i will never eat here again. 

this neighborhood isn't the greatest nor the cleanest so anyone can just stick their fingers into the bowl of stuffing which was completely unattended.  the garbage being near by means there will be flies right? those little creatures probably landed on the stuffing after they had their fun with the trash yuck!! 

this place is gross because they're dirty.
author: Senia S.

description: Fun San Francisco Central American cuisine neighborhood joint. Easy vibe. Delicious food. Easy on the budget. Fun with a friend or with a group. Saw a baby having the young culinary time of his life. I felt the same food joy. Comfortable. Comfort food. Nice staff.
author: John C.

description: Good place to taste the central and south american food.  It's was a little full,  so I had to wait but this is a good thing,  isn't it.  The meal was very tasty,  well cooked and spicy,  so it was perfect.
author: Koe S.

description:
The short: Great pupusas. Skip the fried yucca. Nice restaurant to sit down and eat without being too crowaded

The food: Pork and cheese pupusa was my favorite. All the pupusas I tried were pretty delicious. The fried yucca was too dry and over-fried/stale. Next time I would stick to mainly pupusas, but I'd be willing to try the breakfast items.

The service: There were very few wait staff, but they managed to push everything through.

The ambiance: Nice area with seating that wasn't too cramped.

Overall: I'd definitely come back and bring a friend or guest. But if it's later in the night that you're looking for, it's gotta be Panchita's
author: Andy C.

description: Best pupusas in the city. Whenever me and friends or family want pupusas, we hit up Cafe Balompie. Best pupusas, tamalesde elotes and just about everything else. Staff is always very friendly. One of my favorite places in the city.
author: Philip M.

description: This place is famous for its pupusas, but their pollo empanizado is the best in the Bay Area.  Highly recommended.
author: AJ M.

description:
Balompie's pupusas are easily one of the cheapest, most satisfying meals in San Francisco. Not just cheap for SF-standards either, but legitimately cheap. At $2.50 per deliciously crisp on the outside, fluffy-cheesy-meaty (if you please) on the inside and paired with a crisp, tangy slaw? Really, the other options are far and few in between if you're searching within the confines of this great 7x7 city to find a more tasty and bang-for-your-buck plate of food.

Two slight caveats -- there is a two-pupusa per person minimum order rule and the service lags a bit at times.

Still worth it, though? You do the math. (Hint: yes)
author: Betty W.

description:
When I went on a funventure in the city a couple of weekends ago, I was in the mood for some good pupusas, and Balompie Cafe came across my radar during my restaurant search on Yelp.  I decided to save this review for my official 100th review here on yelp (Yippee!). 

Balompie boasts some truly authentic, delicious and quality food at a very reasonable price.  We ordered the pork/cheese and shrimp/cheese pupusas, and they were both spectacular.  I really enjoyed the shrimp ones since I had never had seafood in a pupusa before, so it was a really cool and new flavor combination for me.  I also thought that the pork pupusas were particularly savory.  I don't think that you really can go wrong with any of their choices.  I recommend taking a look at their specialty pupusas since they had a pretty interesting selection.  

We also ordered the platanos (fried plantains), which I could have done without, but my fiance loved them.  The only negative thing about our experience is that when they asked us if we wanted sour cream with the platanos, we said yes, unaware that it would come at a fairly hefty extra cost (for sour cream, that is).  I wish it had been more clear in the questioning, but I was still incredibly satisfied with my experience here hence the 5 stars!

Overall, if you are looking for some authentic food in the Mission at a cheap price, come here.  It is delicious and they give you a lot of good, quality food for a price that is pretty atypical in San Francisco.
author: Alyx F.

description:
I've been here twice and both times have been amazing experiences. The pupusas are soft and have a great cakey texture but perfectly grilled on the outside. Mmmmm. 

The second time I came I had the camarones y yuca frita and they were absolutely INCREDIBLE. Maybe the best grilled shrimp I've eaten in my life. 

Don't expect to have tons of elbow room, but expect to have a delicious meal. The sangria's pretty good too!
author: Hannah F.

description:
Went here to try the papusas. We have a place that does them near my house, but these were way better. I tried the loroco con queso and the woman recommended the ground pork. Both were amazing. I poured the pickled cabbage and red sauce on top in heaps and it was wonderful. A simple dish made well is my favorite. The other food looked good, standard el salvadorian and next time I go I will try one of the soups, they looked delicious.

The place was hopping. People almost couldn't find table on a Saturday at 1 in the afternoon. Service was fast. Price was also cheap for all the food.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Best Salvadorean food! We drive 2 hrs just to eat pupusas here. The crema pupusas are the best. If you have a sweet tooth get the empanadas de leche. It's always busy here.
author: Mazziel L.

description:
I've been on a hunt for plantains around the city and balompies has the perfect plantain ($3.75) that isn't too fried or greasy. You can order it with sour cream on the side, but it tastes great without it as well. 

I usually order the specialty plantains with fish or shrimp inside ($3.50 each). This location has soccer playing on the TVs inside, perfect for keeping your sporty friends happy.
author: Lauren C.

description: Loved this yelp assisted find. Cozy and authentic. The food was amazing. We tried four different kinds of pupusas, platanos, fried yuca, chiccarones and carnitas. Everything was delicious. They certainly can own their claim to the best pupusas in SF!
author: Courtney C.

description: I'm an sf native and just when I thought I found the best pupusas by my house on 23rd, I came here on 18th to see what the hype was about, I have a new pupusa spot now. Best I've had in town. I'm not a fan of dry pupusas like other Salvadorian spots make them. These ones taste so much better and nice and greasy but not too greasy. I come to balompie all the time now when I have my pupusa craving. I've also always had great customer service which makes this place a double threat !
author: Angelique G.

description:
I came here a pupusa virgin a few years ago after seeing it on 7x7's Try Before You Die List (which Balompie consistently places on, year after year). The pupusas are so delectable that I don't get them anywhere else but here! I usually throw my calorie caution to the wind and order the chorizo and cheese pupusas (yea, I told you I go all out). The complexity is what I'm a sucker for...you have the tartness from the curtido, and richness from the chorizo and cheese, which is balanced by the salsa and the doughiness of the masa! They have ran out of chorizo and cheese pupusas when I came for dinner once though.  And when you order to go, they give you more than enough curtido in a Ziploc bag!

My boyfriend's had their chicken enchiladas and the sauce they put on them makes you want to lick your plate clean! I'm relieved none of the waitresses bat a single eyelid at the sight of me when I'm at Balompie: an Asian girl who adores their Salvadorean pupusas!
author: Caralisa L.

description: My fiancé is Salvadoran so I consider her an expert of Pupusas & traditional food. If we are not eating homemade Pupusas with her family then the only place we go is here. Hands down the best traditional food I've had next to her & her family's cooking
author: John M.

description:
I love the papusas here. We each got two with rice and beans...and a side of fried eggs..made a heavenly breakfast!

The place is clean and the service friendly. I like La Senateca down the street but really love Balompie!
author: Mimi T.

description: As a native San Franciscan, born and raised in the Mission. Best pupusas in town for sure, your not going to get that left over grease from yesterday burnt onto it like other places. You can taste the difference. Special little place.
author: Robert Q.

description:
Is it just me or does everyone picture a fat woman crashing face-first into a pie when the word 'Balompie' comes to mind? THANKS, LIZ LEMON!

Getting to the point: their pupusas blew my mind; they were the perfect size, crispy on the outside, cheesy chewy on the inside -- it's easy to think of these as the skinny cousins of the gorditas. The accompanying spicy salsa and tangy cabbage slaw were the bomb! My only complaint with the pupusas is that the outer shell is pretty much unsalted, and that kinda takes away from the whole 5-star eating experience.

5 stars for the super-friendly staff, 4 stars for the food!
author: Divya R.

description:
Their pupusas are so bomb! I got them delivered from Postmates and they were still delicious. I got two pupusas, one sausage and cheese and one pork and cheese. I asked for some hot sauce and the tangy cabbage they have. I got them with the rice and beans. Both compliment the pupusas well. 

I also got the platanos with the crema. That was very good as well. 

The only thing I regret is not getting the horchata :(
author: Jasmine W.

description:
Fantastic food for a great price. Ordering pupusas is a no brainer but I also recommend anything with carne. It was so tender and juicy, just what I wanted. Just go with their special #1 to get a little bit of everything.

Staff is very friendly but sometimes lacking speed. I don't blame the guy who is taking orders, bringing food, giving you the check for "every single table" though. They must give a hand to that guy.

I also loved the soccer concept and I am looking forward to joining them during world cup.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
