This Pupuseria is really great. It's only a few more blocks past El Zocalo, which is always extremely full. However, that's not to say that Balompie isn't always full either. The difference is that it's full of locals, who know where the good stuff is!! It's waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay better thatn El Zocalo. It has more of a festive environment. The decor is of all kinds of different soccer clubs from around the world. There's a musician who plays nice background music, but isn't overly obnoxious about you hearing him or about tips. He's great!!! I can't wait to go back!
The pupusas are thick because they're really well stuffed, and not overly greasy. Some other pupusas are thick, but because they have so much masa, the deep fried flour, and not very much in the middle.  These aren't like that, they're perfect!
author: Angel M.

description: Yummy!!! I love their pupusas! Friendly and attentive waiters every time :) great service
author: Alma S V.

description:
Call me crazy, but sometimes I just want to go into the Mission to eat real, down-and-dirty, non-hipster, authentic food (this cafe serves Salvadoran cuisine). Balompie Cafe totally made the cut for all of the above. 

There are no frills to the setting of the restaurant. Our sangria was spooned out of a 5-gallon bucket. The two of us shared a four-top table with two complete strangers. It was perfect.

Our server was great -- he made really strong, spot-on recommendations. We split a half carafe of sangria, guacamole & chips, the garlic chicken with rice & beans, the chorizo and cheese papusa (my favorite), and plantains. Everything was delicious and filling, especially the papusa. I can't wait to go back.
author: Audrey A.

description:
Great neighborhood spot.  Came for lunch with Wife and daughter on weekday. Everyone was really nice in answering our questions since ir was our intro to papusas and salvadorean food. 

Tried 3 papusas. Our favorites in order:
1. Shrimp and fish papusa
2. Native salvadorean papusa
3. Pork jalapeno and cheese

The breaded shrimps were perfectamente!  Our daughter loved it.

Very affordable.
author: Eddo C.

description: Authentic Salvadorean food at it finest. My favorite place to eat pupusas in the city. But the bistec empanizado is a must have.
author: John D.

description:
I was expecting Balompie to grace my taste buds with some of the best pupusas I had ever tasted. Unfortunately, that was not the case. While I did like my pupusas, I could not help but think of other places I would have preferred to go to. I got the shrimp, bean and cheese pupusas and all I tasted was oil and beans...kind of disappointing because the ingredients were so poorly rationed inside. 

Despite the disappointment with the pupusas, I really appreciated the great service. Our waitress was incredibly friendly and very attentive. Maybe I should have opted for another entree...
author: Surge C.

description: Balompie Cafe is the right place to enjoy authentic Pupusas! That sums it up, so you would  have to give the restaurant a try to believe me. I had the queso and loroco pupusas and although they were not the best Pupusas I ever had, I must admit that they were absolutely delicious.The tortilla discs were fresh and soft, and they were filled with warm white cheese. This is a great place for anyone who wants to try some good tasting pupusas.
author: Horace G.

description:
Came here twice for the famous pupusa's and still can't figure out why they're so popular. It's basically really really cheesy pockets. Despite trying 4 different combinations, there really isn't much flavor difference - I opened it up to look inside and saw just a couple spinach leaves, or a little bit of diced vegetables. They all taste pretty much the same, which is, very cheesy pockets. That said, if your favorite part about eating a burrito or pizza is the melted cheese, you'll love these. I was hoping for something a little more interesting, given the hype and reviews.

It seemed like lots of people were eating a soup - perhaps that is the better thing to order here.
author: dana n.

description:
Being half Salvadorean, I'm definitely no stranger to pupusas. I used to go grab some all the time with my dad when I was little. It had literally been years since I've had GOOD pupusas until recently when I went with my cousins.

I ended up ordering the plato tipico, which comes with two pupusas of your choice - I had the queso pupusas - refried beans, and rice. The pupusas were thick and cheesy, not oily at all. The rice and beans were just okay to me, but I enjoyed everything as a whole. The salsa and cabbage are a MUST to put on top! You'll love it ;) After, we all shared two plates of empanadas. YUM! They were warm and sweet and the perfect ending to our dinner.

Balompie is on the smaller side, so there isn't tons of seating. Come early or be prepared to wait and/or sit with other people.

I'll definitely be back!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Service is awful...I believe because they only have two  ladies serving a lot if customers that are slow I'm ordering. Pupusas were OK...nothing out of this world..the red sauce was awesome..and the empanadas were below par..a lot of noise made for this place and I think is due to the comfort food that reminds people of their homeland..
author: Franklin B.

description: I ask for rice pupusa was nasty no filling more masa waiter they need to training really bad experiences the mondongo soup no flavor taste like water horrible I don't recommend this places
author: Miguel L.

description: This place was great. The quality of the food, the price, the atmosphere were great. Definitely recommend it and will be going back. If you want great pupusas this is the best place.
author: Herman R.

description: I've come here more than once before.  Today it was extremely busy but the staff was very polite.  The table's were quickly cleaned & the staff stayed busy the entire time I was there. I walked in around 12:30.  The place was very well kept & clean.  The pupusas here are the best in the SF Mission and second to none.  Please stop by & don't miss out!  I went somewhere else on Monday night and it's only Bc this place was closed but oh boy this is the best.  I'll compare others to this place and when u know better u pick better.
author: Michael G.

description:
Wow, how is it that I haven't written a review for this place yet?! 

I love Balompie!  I heart it for the great food, the great prices, the chill, no-nonsense-ness of it all.  It's great.

I've been coming here for a few years now, thanks to a recommendation several years ago from a fellow SF native (Avenues Represent!).  I came here to try the pupusas that one magical day several years ago, and I've been happy with Balompie's ever since.  

And I think other people are starting to catch on too. I noticed that Balompie is starting to make it onto all those "Best of. . ." lists, which is kinda annoying.  I mean, you can never keep awesome things a secret for very long.

But I suppose it's okay because I think good food really makes people happier, and even better than just good food is paying little money for good food.  People are all over that!  

And this stuff is both cheap + DELICIOUS.  Absolutely delicious!  It's like a flour (or is it corn? I'm not sure. . .) based tortilla-looking thing, stuffed full of meat, cheese, and what have you.  It is a thing of beauty.  Add some salsa and slaw on top, and it's pupusa heaven.  Balompie's does it better than every other place I've tried.  El Zocalo's, another popular pupuseria, is okay.  Balompie's really is best.  Their pupusas are hearty, the bread-ish part is soft and cute, the inside is hearty, flavorful, packed with good stuff.  It's a nice portion too; two of these will make you nicely full.  

And the best part?  Incredibly affordable.  If you do take-out, it's like $1.95 each.  If you get two, with tax, it'll come out to $4.27.  Isn't that INSANE?  Under 5 bucks for a very delicious meal.  Worth it.  Talk about bang for your buck.

You know, everyone loves the burritos in the Mission, and I certainly do too.  But there are also many days where I'll take a pupusa over a burrito.  But not just any pupusa.  A Balomie pupusa.  

Put that on your list of San Francisco must-eats.
author: Vivian C.

description:
We ordered the chile relleno, a spinach and cheese, and bean papusa.  The juice of the day was cantaloupe and it was delicious.

I've had better papusas, but the spinach cheese one was pretty good.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Was introduced to this place by my very own Salvadorian friend who swore up and down they had theeeeeee best Salvadorian food.  He definitely did not lie and he came through on what he swore on.

What?  Papusas?  Who said that? LOL!  I don't think I've ever had a bad papusa.  But seriously though.....I have not had a great tasting papusa like Balompie Cafe serves it.  I usually can only eat 1 and I'm sick to my stomach but here I swear to you I will probably eat a couple.  Balompie's papusas are not greasy and maybe that's what it is that makes me want to stomach more.  In addition to my 1 papusa, I also had the platains, beans and sour cream to go along with my pork and cheese papusa. Ohhhh man, I cleaned both those plates up like you would not believe.  

I noticed a quite extensive papusa menu where they serve specialty papusas.  I'm definitely coming back to try a few of those.  They all looked so delicious!!!  This place definitely delivers on all levels, food, price and service.  I'm definitely coming back for more!!!  Enjoy!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
I had chicharon and queso pupusa . It was pretty good not too greasy. Also had the plantains with sour cream which was good as well. 

They so charge for chips and salsa. Salsa was good, chips are too hard (I do have braces, maybe a factor)  

I do have a local pupusa area I go to back in San Pablo, I probably wouldn't come back tho.
author: Feuy P.

description: Have been dinning here for years. Food is great but make sure you watch for fruadulant activity on your credit card. I used my credit card and left a cash tip for my bill. The next day, I noticed that the charges in my account were more then my receipt. When checking into it further, they added a tip which was not authorized. I at this point feel uncomfortable to give them my business due to this type of activity. Please watch your bill statments!
author: April Z.

description: One of the best! I blame this fat ass on your pupusa's! Thanks bitch.
author: Jourdain D.

description:
Pupusas! They make delicious pupusas, the usual types with loroco or bean, but I love their spinach pupusas. Last night we decided to eat family style and one of the dishes we were sharing was the sopa de res. It smelled so good, but as I was dividing the soup, I found a bug!!!!!!!! Gross. They were aplogetic and they took both the soup and one of the sides off the tab. I feel that that was generous.
My friend wanted the fried yucca with chicharon and while the yucca was good, the pork didn't taste really fresh to me. The platanos with crema were great. Overall, we were happy with our meal and service.
author: Susan B.

description: Best pupusas you will find in SF! This is coming from a local too! ;) enjoy the service is pretty good too. Best part is they have fútbol
author: Jose C.

description:
I get that you walk in and you are scared by the decor, the locals sitting around staring at you, and the girl at the counter giving you the "what the hell do you want" look. Brave on fellow eating champions.

One word. pupusas. PUPUSASSSSSSSSS.  Yes, this is why you are here.  Delicious  round, corn rounds filled with cheese.  Yum.  When I first had one, I was wondering why I didn't eat them on a weekly basis.  Later my digestive system let me know why.  The grease, diary, and animal protein is really hard on my body, but those 15 minutes of heaven are worth it!
author: Jessica H.

description: I love a good yet presentable hole in the wall.  This Salvadoran cafe Balompie on 18th Street is so tasty and affordable. That is always great to find in SF. Highly recommend their horchata and combination plate: Chorizo and queso pupusas, yuca frita con chicharron (mines were a bit over fried and therfore dry), and pasteles de pollo. I also ordered a side of platanos. I love me some platanos!! Staff was really nice too.
author: Hoosie U.

description:
AMAZING tacos, I mean that they are amazing, some of the best ever, if you could call them tacos.  I think this place might be the best taco place in the world.  

5 stars. amazing.
author: Connor B.

description:
Would give 0 stars if I could...

Here's how my ordering experience went: I placed my order at 7:17pm through Eat24. I received an order confirmation stating that my order was confirmed, and it will be ready between 10 and 35 mins. I live about 20 or so mins away from the restaurant. I arrived at the restaurant around 7:40. I asked the person at the register about my order, and he said he never received it. He tried checking on his iPad, but it wouldn't even turn on. WHY DID I RECEIVE AN ORDER CONFIRMATION IF MY ORDER WAS NEVER ACTUALLY CONFIRMED? Instead of helping me find a solution, or even looking at the order confirmation I was trying to show him on my phone, he proceeded to help all of the other customers and ignore me. 

While I was checking my online account to see if I was charged (which I was), I received a call from Eat24 around 7:45. The person told me they couldn't get a hold of the restaurant after repeated attempts. I was already at the restaurant at this point... This was over 30 minutes after my order was placed. Why was I just then receiving a call about this, when I already drove all the way there? And why did I receive a confirmation of my order? 

I kept trying to get the guy at the restaurant to assist, but finally, I had Eat24 cancel my order with a refund, and re-placed the order with the person at the register, paying on site, because I was hungry and didn't want to look for another place to eat. That was around 7:50. You'd think that after the guy saw me trying to figure out what was going on with my order for the last 10-15 mins, he would've had the kitchen rush the order. My order didn't come out until 8:25. I think he actually forgot to give the cooks my order. I could see the kitchen from where I was sitting. The staff was not cooking anything until about 8:15. The stove was empty. FINALLY MY ORDER WAS READY. At this point, it was about an hour and 10 minutes after my initial order was placed through Eat24. Thanks for the $15 coupon that I have to use within 30 days, Eat24. The restaurant offered no discount, and their service was some of the worst I've ever come across. I honestly feel like if I spoke Spanish, I would've received better service, and their sense of urgency would've been better. I've ordered from the Balompie #3 location many, many times without issue. That location is closed on Tuesdays, and this was my first time ordering from the 18th Street location. Never again.
author: David B.

description:
This is my favorite pupusa place.  But, it only gets 4 stars because arepas are better and because as good as they are pupusas are not 5 star worthy food.  Kind of like when you watch gymnastics and the gymnast has a lower score because of lower degree of difficulty.

Actually, the chicharron and fried yucca is my favorite dish here.  I would skip the sweet corn tamal.  It is a bit flavorless.

This place feels like a sports bar in latin america.  small wood tables.  small flat screen tvs playing soccer.  banners for soccer teams.  but, the place is filed with white hipsters as are most places in the mission.  so much bad facial hair and plastic-framed glasses.  you know it is no longer ironic if everyone is doing it!

This place is not crowded and the service is friendly.  but, not terribly attentive.  We waited quite a while for the check to arrive.  I noticed because we were trying to get somewhere.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I recently realized I had been mispronouncing Balompie for over a year (baa- lom-pee-yay) but a yummy meal by any name is still finger licking good. 

My staple order here is some pupusas with Negra modelos. Chorizo and cheese and spinach and cheese are my favorites. Ham and cheese is great too (see a pattern?). To be honest, I haven't liked anything else here all that much. Go here for the pupusas - the best I have had.

The service is warm and attentive. The soccer is a bonus. Not much of a follower myself but the soccer matches on TV keep the boyfriend distracted enough that I can get more than my half of the pupusas!
author: Amrita M.

description:
My "Rating" is actually based on the breakfastary meal that I had on Sunday, not on Balompié Cafe's most excellent pupusas, which are exemplary and some of the best I have ever had (plus, they offer seven different vegetarian versions); their pupusas rate at least 4-5 stars.

Having eaten at Balompié Cafe recently for lunch (for their excellent pupusas), I noticed that they are also open for breakfast daily. I made a "mental" note (with me, there are no other kinds) to go back and check out their breakfasts. I finally got around to doing so this past weekend.

I simply had "Huevos con loroco"/scrambled eggs with loroco (this is a Salvadoran green vegetable, hard to explain but good to eat). This comes with rice and refried beans, and home-made, fresh-off-the-grill corn tortillas. Everything was very good. If I go back again for "desayuno", I will probably get their simple breakfast of plantains, refried beans, and queso, so that I can get two of their pupusas to complement (or compliment, even) the meal.

If you would like to read a more detailed take on this meal, please feel free to check out my stupid li'l breakfast 'blog. You can see the link if you click on my profile here. (For some reason, yelp* does not allow the use of hyperlinks in their reviews.)
author: Brian M.

description:
If you want "quality" and authentic food from EL SALVADOR, I must recommend!

There are various other establishments in SF which claim to be better, but they epic fail! The portion sizes are great, the vibe from the waiters is fun, sometimes, they'll have this older gentleman sing and perform Spanish Flamenco Guitar which is amazing.. coupled with the international soccer games on multiple screens, it makes for a very fun atmosphere. 

Last Saturday, I ordered the "chorizo con huevos" (sausage and eggs) for breakfast. The plate was enormous!  They served with a healthy portion of Spanish rice and beans and chose the French bread (since we Salvadoran's have French descent). Additionally, I love their natural drinks and imported sodas, ordered the "COLA-CHAMPAGNE"; deeeelish... my family was happy, the food was absolutely delicious and appreciate the great service - TWO THUMBS UP!

If you want a QUALITY breakfast, with reasonable prices and good portion sizes, this is your place!

Thank you, Balompie!!!!!
author: Michael M.

description:
You know, I've been around the block and have had a couple of "pupusas" in my day. 

Balompie serves up a mean pupusa. I went in the middle of the day and happened upon a bunch of Spaniards watching the Barcelona / Sevilla match. I was in heaven. It's been years since I've seen someone without a plasma TV, but the enthusiasm made up for the lack of technology. 

I had the pupusa revuelta and it was damn tasty. Along with Panchita's  #3 this is one of my favorite pupuserias. The tamarindo drink I ordered was also very good. It's hard to get tamarindo just right, and Balompie did it. It wasn't too sweet and not too bitter, 

The space is tiny and nothing impressive. They do have tons of soccer paraphernalia which gets it an extra star. It's like this place was built for me: pupusas + soccer. 

I love you, Balompie.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I LOVE Salvadorean food. 

The Mission is where it's at. Great authentic pupusas and orchatas for authentic prices. I don't want any of that overpriced fake crap that they serve in fancy schmancy Latin-food restaurants. I want the real stuff. Homemade tortillas. Homemade pupusas. Everyone speaks Spanish, and the place is packed with locals. I enjoyed the vegetarian one (zucchini, mushrooms, carrots, etc), but my faves were the shrimp and cheese one and the ground beef and cheese ones.

Balompie is small. You may have to wait a while before being seated, but for $2.50/$3.50 per pupusa, you can't beat the price. I opted for the 2 pupusas + rice/beans combination for $8.50 with a $2.75 orchata. Salvadorean orchatas are a little different from the Mexican ones. They taste like a lighter version of chocolate milk, and they're made from morro seeds (instead of rice), cocoa, cinnamon, sesame seeds, etc. (Thanks, wikipedia!). Delish.

My friend enjoyed her chicken enchilada with rice/beans plate, which came with a salad and two homemade tortillas, accompanying cabbage and a spicy red sauce. 

Good luck finding parking. But such is life in SF. 

Great service. Great prices. Great, authentic food. 

If you're looking for a pretentious place, this is not for you.

EDIT: Originally a four star review turned two stars. My friend found a bug in her food. That generally makes for a 1-star review, but given the quality of the food and the fact that I haven't had any problems, I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.
author: Stef S.

description:
We've been coming here for years after a Salvadorian friend said it was very good, but finally writing a review. Other than our friend's mom's food, we think it's the best Salvadorian food in The City. We have tried about 4-5 other places but we come back here because we love their papusas and casamiento. I don't agree with the previous reviewer who claimed they were too oily. When you pan fry cheese you're going to have an oily quality to it. We think papusas are terrible when they are too dry....
The restaurant is very modest in decor and the neighborhood is typical non-gentrified Mission, but that is part of the allure. It's definitely a favorite of locals. It's usually very busy but the servers are friendly and efficient. Best of all, it's inexpensive!
author: Scott G.

description: Handsdown the Best Salvadorean spot in the city. I've been coming here for the past 15 years, a tradition handed down by my father who saw this place open up in the late 80s. The pupusas is all I go for. The closest flavor to El Salvador favorite dish. U gotta try their rice flour pupusas, with chicharrón (grounded pork), cheese and beans. Or just say revueltas. The staff are friendly and attentive.
author: Papi R.

description: Fak this place. I had the worst experience today. I've been coming here for 20 years and never have I been treated with such crap awful service like today. I waited patiently with my family for 30 min to get seated and when we did they never brought us water or menus. I got up and asked the dumb ugly waitress for water and the dumbass replies oh yeah it's coming 10 min pass and nothing. My 4 yr old was really thirsty and they did nothing. Finally a short fat jaba the hut looking lady takes our order and apologizes with a smile. I asked her how come everybody got water and we didnt? She ignored me and walked away. We ordered food and after 20 min of waiting while everyone else got their food who arrived after us I said...Fak it got up and walked out. Never going back to this crap hole.  The cooks make great food but the waitresses are horrible. Mal paridas pero ni a sus propios paisanos tratan bien.
author: Flechazo I.

description:
My girlfriend volunteered in the Peace Corps in Honduras, and she got all excited to check this place out when we passed by on a Sunday bike ride.

Despite being crowded, the atmosphere here is really laid back and relaxed.  It seems like a gathering place for Central American immigrant types.  There are soccer banners adorning every wall, and my girlfriend recognized the banner of CD Motagua from Tegucigalpa.

I ordered the combination plate lunch with fried yucca, chicharrones, and a fish pupusa.  It was really good, and very filling as well.  I didn't need to eat anything for the next seven hours after we left.

The style of preparation here is different from other pupuserias, even the ones nearby.

The fried yucca in particular was outstanding.  The chicharrones are not the kind you find in the plastic bags next to the potato chips.  They're an entirely different style than that, with chunks of pork fried to a crisp. 

I imagine that this must have been what the Mission District was like decades ago, before the waves of punker dive bars, techie lofts, and gourmet bistros began to crowd their way in.

I want to come back and grab a few beers while I sample the menu again.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Really surprised by the positive reviews. Obscenely terrible service. To call out the worst: I was served raw eggs, and had to point that out to get a new order. We never got our drinks, were charged for them and was also charged or water. 
There are plenty of other places to get papusas and tasty breakfast in the mission. This one is not worth it.
author: Mei C.

description:
The owner & staff here are extremely friendly.  The place can get really busy but they try super hard to accommodate everyone and make you happy -- it took a few minutes to get our order in and the manager/owner gave us chips & salsa on the house! Totally unexpected and not necessary but it was a nice surprise.  Not to mention the chips were right out of the frier and the salsa was spicy - just the way I like it!

There are so many options when it comes to the papusas so come with some friends and try a few!  The Salvadorian Vegetable IS DELISH!  

The beans are TO DIE FOR. seriously, don't miss out on the beans.

The horchata tasted fresh.  The beers are cheap!!  No complaints about this place -- just left and I am dying to come back, drooling over pictures and I'm stuffed :)
author: Tiffany W.

description: The decoration is why I gave it 1star. The popusas are made with some cheap ass cheese dough and oil. They're not crispy as should be. Their loroco and chicharron also sucks ass,they skimp out on whatever you order with cheese popusas...I just went yesterday,Sunday afternoon and we got horrible service by this rude ass waiter, who was half assed paying attention to our order,wrote it down wrong,  brought the wrong order and then had the AUDACITY,el pinche descaro, de echarnos la culpa:to blame us,saying we ordered it....and then he didnt r en take it off the menu, so had to wait to fix the receipt. This is one of the worst serviced places I've ever been to. THIS PLACE IS NOT EXCEPTIONAL...ITS HALF ASSED. FOR STANDARD,bomb ass popusas and understandable service when its Hella busy go to EL ZOCALO!!!!
author: Mar L.

description:
EVERYONE LISTEN UP... WHAT YOU READ ON HERE IS ABSOLUTELY CORRECT!!! 
I have never had pupusas before and I didn't even know what they were. I came here the other week and tried some for the first time because my best friend swore on it. It is like heaven in my mouth. I got the ground pork with cheese and it was just absolutely amazing. I don't even know what it was but it was just about the best thing I've ever had. I wish it wasn't so far from where I live so I could get it all the time but maybe it is a good thing after all.. for my wallet at least.
The service was really good and attentive and the establishment is really clean. They don't speak too much english but it is understandable. I am definitely coming back here again.
author: T L.

description:
I'm Salvadorian so I know what I'm talking about! This place is legit

Been coming here for years with my family and the food is always fresh and made to order. The pupusas are on point but let's not begin the battle of Santaneca or Balompie. I have a preference but I won't say it on Yelp. The atmosphere is great but it can get crowded at times so prepare to wait for a table every now and then. I don't watch soccer but it appears to be a great place to watch a soccer match. The fact that my mom makes the best pupusas but still wants to come here says a lot. The Salvadorian steak and the platano's are great too. The service is good and it definitely helps if you speak Spanish. 

Balompie has really changed over the years. It has become more touristy and hipster but that's just because of the gentrification that the Mission has gone through over the years. The only reason I didn't give Balompie five stars is because they don't have Pan con Pavo which *ahem* other places do... But overall, I definitely recommend this place if you are looking for some authentic Salvadorian Food.
author: Javier G.

description:
Pupusas are AMAZING here!!

Lets start out with some honesty: I had no idea what pupusas were. When my friend asked if I wanted to get some, I figured what the heck?! I want to try new things!

Turns out this El Salvadorian dish is fantastic! ...at least the ones at Balompie are! OK, so I've never tried pupusas at other places, but my friend said she liked the ones at Balompie best and I trust her judgement (she is an ELITE Yelper after all ;D).

I got a ground pork pupusa and a spinach/cheese one. hMmmmm! SO. GOOD. They may look small, but these babies are filling! I learned how to eat pupusas with the pickled veggies + sauce too! YES! :) 

It's a really chill environment here. If I was big into football aka soccer I would totally come here everyday to eat pupusas and watch games on TV! 

I'll come back and see if I still give Balompie 4 stars (maybe 5!!). For my first time though, I'm very pleased!
author: Kei H.

description:
Pupusas, arroz con frijoles, sangria...overload! Delicious.

Family style restaurant, futbol playing on all screens if avail (low volume though). If busy be prepared for a long wait (at least 30 min for food to be plated)

Pupusas thick stuffed full of: I had shrimp and fish, zuchinni, loroco all (with cheese) with a plate of seasoned rice and beans, It came with salsa and pickled cabbage salad.

Sangria: Ahhmazing! Spiced fruits (papaya, orange, apple, guayaba, and many more), strong, and sweet!

Came for a business lunch, client loved the food!
author: Haben E.

description: I've been on a pupusa mission since I finally tried them. (I try not to think about my wasted years in LA as I drove past one pupuseria after another - although I was probably on my way to a Zankou Chicken...). Balompie Cafe has a wonderful selection of delicious pupusas, including chorizo pupusas. Mmmmm.
author: Vena V.

description:
The pupusas are quite filling and authentic here. As I bit into my loroco pupusa (a good measure for how good a pupuseria is), I felt the cheese and loroco flowers oozing into my mouth. I like how crisp the pupusa was, but don't really match my standard of crispy outside goodness and inside doughy, cheesy love. There was just something that seemed alright with it. And my goodness, maybe it's my small Asian frame, but I was barely able to finish my combo plate of $9 with 2 pupusas, rice and beans. Good thing I went for a 5 mile run the next day.

One last thing, service is attentive for the most part, we did have to call the waiter a few times to refill our water. And the horchata is authentically Salvadorean. YOU MUST GET IT.
author: Tony H.

description:
I have a Salvadorian friend who has been coming here with his family for years. He was nice enough to take six of his asian friends to this wonderful place to experience Salvadorian food at it's best.

Of course, most of us ordered pupusas while a few of us got plates to try. The plates were good, but the pupusas... oh man, let's just say we had to put in a second order they were that good. Next time i go back I want to try their soups which also looked amazing. The people that worked there were also really friendly and super happy that we were so excited to try their cuisine-- I love that. Them loving us loving their food. Love it. 

Definitely super authentic so if you're craving a pupusa make sure you come here.
author: Kimberly F.

description: This was the second time trying El Salvador Ian food, this place was insanely great. I'll be coming here all the time, getting the most delicious Pupusas! We had a great waiter named Ben, helped out with deciding and menu options. 5/5 recommend.
author: Drake G.

description: There was no line to get seated, but service was slow. We waited about 10mins to order and about 30mins for the food to arrive. We had nowhere else to be, so we didn't mind too terribly. The pupusas were delicious and tasted fresh, the fresco de tamarindo was the right amount of agrio and the tamal frito was the bomb.
author: Mariam T.

description:
Tried pupusas for the first time and I'm so glad I chose this place to pop my pupusa cherry (lol). It was freakin' delicious. I got the pork and cheese pupusa and it was yummmmy!!!! They definitely came out super hot and they were so good I burned the top of my mouth. I only bought 2 but I felt like I could eat so much more because it was so good. I also tried the horchata, it was pretty good compared to the other places I've tried it at. It's a small restaurant but feels very home-y. The service we had was decent, not good or bad but decent. We had to ask the servers to order our meal. 

I'm definitely coming back when I'm craving pupusas!
author: Ashley D.

description:
Mmm I'm craving Blimpies. Can we have Blimpies today? Oh what? Ba..lom..pee...ay? Yeah ok, so what time does Blimpies open?

Mmmm I die for their rice and beans. I even jock their coffee. I've only ordered their breakfasts and pupusas, and have yet to try any lunch/dinner entrees. But their breakfasts alone are bombastic. Yeah I said bombastic.

This is my preferred Salvadorean joint. Nice staff, good food. Parking is moded, but its part of the experience if you choose to eat in the Mission.

Try the Scrimp n Cheese Pupusa. Fontastic. Mista Laba Laba. Mmmm.
author: Rho T.

description:
I recommend Salvadorian horchata and salvadorian tamales. I like cheese pupusas with loroco, and zucchini and cheese.
Really good food, nice service. One of my favorite Salvadorian restaurants in the city of San Francisco.
author: Carlos L.

description:
Since becoming vegetarian, the only meat item that I miss are my favorite pupusas de chicharron. However, if you're missing out on some extra flavor after ditching the meat or just bored of just queso con loroco, you must try Balompié's Super Vegetarian Pupusas! 

Usually I was anti any non-traditional Salvadorean pupusas like tofu and such but I must highly recommend the super veggie pupusa because it's the only one that has come close to replacing my pupusa de queso con chicharron. 

Again, I've grown up loving this place and no other pupuseria in California compares and I've also grown to love their adaptability to San Francisco's dining audience and expanding their vegetarian pupusa menu.
author: Mariajose A.

description:
(See pic)

Rating for the pupusa: 5 stars.

I craved some filling brunch in one late afternoon.

This place appeared to be dark as I walked in from really bright sun outside. Come very sweet sunshine smiles from the folks while most patrons wondered why an Asian would walk into a Salvadorian place.

The menu overall has more "higher priced" items but if you come and order pupusas you would be in shock as it's only $2.5 each. 

It takes time for them to make each one so be patient and you will be pleasantly surprised. It was so so SO delicious. The outside was a bit crisp with small pockets of grill marks while inside was all the phenomenally good gooey cheese with pork and another one with native Salvadorian veggies. 

The sauce was very solid.

The spicy and sour side of coleslaw was fantastic, a very acidic that goes really well with the rich taste of pupusas.

I was very hungry and did ask if 2 would be enough, at which point the super friendly server said it would definitely be enough. I was so used to paying much more when eating out so I got skeptical. With tax all that food was less than 7 dollars! And with all that work  one wonders how they could be profitable at all. 

Onto the ambiance, It's a family style setting where most tables against the walls or windows are 4 seaters with a couple 2-seaters. In the middle is multiple tables all string together, catering a big group, which this day had a family with a future group of Soccer players, a group of 5-year adorable boys!
author: T L.

description:
I love this place!!  I usually stop in for dinner on my way home from work every ten days, or so.  The staff is great and the food is excellent.  Some of my favorites are: carne asada, beef soup, mariscada in the tomato sauce, fried yucca with chicharron and I love their side of veggies.  But really, you can't go wrong with anything you might order here.

The place is kind of cramped and the TV is definitely on, showing some soccer match or another.  Since it's usually full, you're very likely to be seated at the family style table in the middle of the small room, so be ready to rub elbows with someone you never met before.  Not exactly all candles and romance, just some of the best El Salvadorian food you've ever had!
author: Patrick F.

description:
Homey sports ambiance with warm and hearty food. 

Balompie cafe is a welcome change of pace and atmosphere against all the hipster places around in the mission. 

I never had the opportunity to have Salvadorian food before and I am happy Balompie was the first place I got to try it because this authentic, lovin' joint does not disappoint~

PUPUSAS ARE YUM! Also-SEA BACON- that is right, sea bacon. That is the only way to describe the fried fishes that toped the combo plate. Everything I tried here was yummy and the service was kind and caring. 

+++Extra points for this place because I left my phone on the table and the waitress chased me down to bring it back to me!
author: Stephie M.

description: The food is really good I would give 5 stars just for the food but the service is really bad .They have so many employees on the floor that they don't bother with the customers at all.. It just get worse every time I have gone... I need to find better place that has good food and great service ....
author: M G.

description:
Hands down the best papusas I have ever eaten period.  I may not have ever gone to El Salvadoe but I have eaten at well over a dozen different Salvadorian restaurants on several different states.  Balompie's papisas are great.!!  The refired beans which seems to often be a throw away were outstanding as well. The service was great, very friendly and attentive.  

Beyond the food quality I really loved the atmoshphere.  You can see and hear your papusa being made from scratch by hand.
author: Brad P.

description: PUPUSAS! my sister found this place on the top 100 eateries in SF list. i had the sampler with fish & chese pupusa, fried yuca with fish, & chicken empanada (http://bunnylovebaker.blogspot.com/2012/02/salvadoran-in-sf.html). my sister got the cheese & mixed veggies pupusa and we both got an horchata. we didn't order much, but it was more than we could handl. i brought home half of the order! everything was awesomely delicious even the leftovers two days later!
author: Leslie P.

description: This place has changed a lot. The server seemed on edge, so I decided to cancel my order, but my friend wanted pupusas so she ordered some. The server said "sorry if you felt insulted". He gave my friend's order to another server, and was done with us.
author: B A.

description: Baloompie baloompie! I've been saying the name wrong this whole time. But balom means soccer ball and pié means foot, so soccerballfoot (i asked our waitress). The pupusas here are yummy! I tried chicharron y queso and loroco con queso and they were both good, especially with the curtido. They've got a bunch more different kinds on the menu. The special veggie one sounds good for next time.
author: Sylvia K.

description: This place doesn't have a lot of vegetarian options, but those that they do are fantastic! I ordered the stuffed pepper with beans and rice... it was great! My friend and I got the tamarind drinks--they were more interesting than amazing-tasting; I'd recommend those if you're a bit adventurous. The staff were friendly, and the price was great. I'll definitely be back if I need a lateish post-climbing snack!
author: Gatoatigrado A.

description: This place is fantastic. Really good food. Great authentic breakfast. Mostly local Latino clientele.
author: jeremy H.

description:
7x7 List: Pupusas

YES!!!!!!!!!!! yes!!!! SI SI SI SI!!! MAS PUPUSAS!!

Dragged the coworkers out here for a weekday lunch around 1, following the advice to avoid the 12-1pm rush.

Waited for about 5 minutes for a table of 5, got the

-spinach & cheese pupusas: THE BEST.
-seafood pupusas (shrimp, fish, cheese): meh
-pork, jalapeno & cheese: pretty tasty (nodding while typing)
-plantains (not as good as others made it up to be, order if you got a sweet tooth and will be craving something sweet after pupusas)

Def will come back when craving the cheesy doughpeness.
author: Ami Y.

description: Like a little ethnic restaurant would be in Lansing, Michigan, but in the Mission. Nice people, laid back atmosphere, honest-to-goodness food, awesome prices, great jukebox. Just a good spot.
author: Andrew K.

description:
You can't go wrong with a pupusa revuelta (meat and cheese). At $2 a pop (minimum order of 2), you don't need rice and beans to make this a full meal. They're not too oily either - in fact, they're one of the best I've had. 

Try it with an horchata (my favorite!) or an agua fresca. There are no frills about this place - just GOOD pupusas and cheap prices. Their service is not the greatest, but I'd recommend ordering "to go" anyhow.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Another 4 star dinner ! Had the usual suspects papusa ( not a big fan of the fish one, the chicirone' sp? one was good). The fried yuca is always a must, had it w/ beef, always perfectly done. Fried plantain  (bananas) on a plate w/ cheese and beans .... better than last time, loved it. Pastales, never can go wrong ! (ahhhh, I didn't eat all this stuff myself !)

This joint can get loud, with amigos at the bar downing cervesas like it is 1999, it is just the Balompie vibe. Its fun. Family's (some look to be Salvadorean, most don't seem to be on a low-cal diet), hipsters from the mission ( a looking hip ) , fastidious looking career couples ( a looking successful) on an adventure.... all is good. 

They do a good job at taking care of the customers, no flares required. 
Missed the Mariachi band this time....
author: Matsuo U.

description: Excellent restaurant!! Every single thing that I tried was delicious. Very sad it was closed on monday since I didnt get to order to go before heading home. Completely recommend this restaurant. Next time you're in SF and are looking for some great Salvadorian food this is the place to go.
author: Karla M.

description: A friend recommended this place because she knows my love for Salvadorian good. First time made a good impression! Tasty pupusas, not too greasy with enough filling. However, the chicharron was mediocre. Almost tasted like ground chicken.
author: Johana M.

description: These are the best pupusas in San Francisco in my opinion. But they also they mix wheat flour into the corn tortilla mixture, I called today to confirm this. Since I cannot eat gluten/wheat anymore I will be skipping this place for now.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I wanted to have breakfast tacos so I decided to head over to the Mission area to a local Mexican restaurant.  To my surprise, the restaurant I had in mind was close for renovations.  
Walking back to the BART I stumbled upon Balompie Cafe.  Since I had a few hours to kill and alone I decided to give Balompie a try. 
   Balompie is a local restaurant with simple decor and menu. The majority of the patrons are speaking spanish as well as the staff.  Most of the patrons seem to be regulars.  
The menu has all the typical latin breakfast items - huevos rancheros, casamiento, platanos, papas con huevo, etc.. I just wanted to have something simple and easy, so I sat at the bar and ordered.  I ordered chrizo con huevo, arroz, and frijoles.  
Reason: 
I love huevos rancheros but I wanted to try something different.  Since I wanted eggs and some protein i ordered the chorizo con huevos. 

   i received my dish within 10 minutes.  The female working the bar was very nice, friendly, and attentive.  The portions are healthily but not Texas size. The chrizo con huevo was nice and not oily.  Sometimes the chrizo gets too oily and ruin the flavor of the egg. Overall, nothing special but just a good simple meal.

I would come back if in the area.
author: Pierre C.

description:
There's something endearing about hole in the walls that thrive way off the "Mission" strip. You really can't go wrong with any of their pupusas. 

I mean, seriously. You should just come here for the pupusas. Don't waste your money or my time by telling you otherwise.
author: Abel L.

description:
Just like all of the other reviews already mentioned, the pupusas were delicious. I tried a cheese and bean and a spinach and cheese. Both were great.  
I also had a side of fried plantains, which were so good.
The only thing they could work on here is the service.  I asked my waitress for recommendations and she looked rather annoyed and just shortly suggested the spinach and cheese.
author: Gloria N.

description: So authentic. Bistec empanizado is just like how I am used to in Miami.
author: Petie P.

description:
TIP #1: Not saying I'm THE authority on pupusas in San Francisco, but--these really, really hit the spot! If you're feeling adventurous, try one of the special pupusas. 

TIP #2: Come with an appetite!

Straightforward, yummy food. I ordered the pupusa plate--besides choosing from the regular group pork and cheese varieties, you can choose from their special $3.50 pupusas too, which have unusual fillings like fish, shrimp, and prosciutto--and it comes with rice and creamy, velvety beans. My sister ordered the El Salvadorean sampler, which came with a pupusa, yucca (we chose steamed, it's like potato), and pasteles de pollo (which is a fried corn pie filled with your choice of meat). We shared everything and it was very filling and tasty. Nothing super stellar, but nothing below average either. Just simple, good food.
author: A.L. H.

description: Balompie was recommended to me by a friend during a recent visit and it absolutely did not disappoint. I went there for dinner and had the sangria (strong and delicious) chips and salsa (just the right amount of kick in the salsa), and three pupusas (beans & cheese, pork & cheese, and beef and cheese). The pork and cheese pupusa was a little bland, but the other two were delicious and super flavorful. Be aware, though, that the pupusas are not large, but they are very filling. I highly recommend taking time to eat here if you are in San Francisco. It's a can't miss!
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
If you have $20 to blow and you want a super cozy joint with sinful Salvadorian fare and beer, Balompie awaits you.

Lovely service, no frills dining and a menu about the size of El Salvador. We had the spinach/queso and pork papusas to start, and they were heavenly pillows of warm deliciousness. I had the lemon chicken and licked the plate clean - including the rice and beans on the side.

So many things to explore on this menu; I just went for what my eyes gravitated to first. And they did not deceive me.
author: Meredith R.

description:
If I lived in SF I would probably eat here at least once a week....truthfully, I'd probably eat here more often. The pupusas here are just like the ones in El Salvador....and I always get homesick for m homeland after a meal here.
We came for lunch on a trip into the city and it was packed (as usual), but worth the wait. Everything was delicious, me and my dad had the pupusas and my mom had the carne asada. The horchata (a native rice milk drink) was delicious, and not watered down or too sweet like the Mexican version.
Only down side was that the service was a bit lacking this time around.... the waitress seemed a little put out to have to wait on us (uh, hello, that's what you do!) and it took forever for the food to show up. Again, I know they were busy, but c'mon, I know how long it takes to make pupusas and it doesn't take as long as it did this time around.
author: Cecy V.

description:
pupusas + beer = i'm good

My favorite pupusa joints in the city. Inexpensive and very good. Typically fairly crowded here and sometimes a small wait.
author: Thuan N.

description:
If you love Papusas, this is the place to be!  They have a wide variety to choose from.   All are great and what I love best is, they are not greasy at all.  I have not tried any other dishes, however, I have heard from quite a few people that order other dishes and all the feedback was good...

A MUST VISIT if you have a craving for Papusas!!!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I have been there two times this week. Special circumstances..
I would eat there every week if I didn't live in San Jose. I always celebrate my birthday, mothers day, with a meal from this place. 
I love it that much!
author: Tara D.

description:
It never ceases to amaze me how many different permutations of corn, cheese, beans and meat you can find in Latin American cuisine!  The size of Massachusetts, El Salvador bequeaths upon us the pupusa.  A  small disk of corn flour encasing cheese and some filling.  They are griddled fresh to order and a little cheese always seems to seep out creating a small taste of crispy goodness.  You won't find this cheese at any high end fromagerie since it is far from sophisticated, but still satisfies from the basic fatty dairy point of view.

Queso con Frijoles: The only pupusa where the filling co-star actually managed to overpower the cheese.  Good in a diversified pupusa portfolio, but a bland choice if your only one.

Loroco y Cheese: From the description of a native Salvadoran vegetable, the loroco seemed a lot more exciting than it really was.  The bits were so small I really only tasted cheese, especially when dipped into the salsa.

Camaron y Queso: I wouldn't normally think shrimp and cheese go together and I'd be mostly right.  The shrimp seemed overcooked and the pairing just okay.  Would have been better with some garlic, butter an parsley in this pupusa.

Mejicana y Queso: The ground pork is really bits of pulled pork, but kind of small so the flavor gets lost amongst the cheese. There are some jalapeño bits, but doesn't really spice things up.

Chorizo y Queso:  Little bits of ground chorizo add a very noticeable zing to the cheese.  A tad on the greasy side, but forgivable for chorizo.

Curtido: What better to join the beans in your digestive tract party than raw cabbage?  Way tastier than typical sauerkraut, this is more similar to kimchee.  I really liked the texture of delicately shredded carrots, cabbage and red onions that were still crunchy, indicating a very light pickling.  Some nice hot pepper tones without being as saucy as kimchee.  Loads of spices and herbs too!

Salsa: Bring a straw.  Perhaps this is traditional, but it's still too runny and bland for my tastes.
author: Adam B.

description:
BEST PAPUSAS IN SF!!!

i love this place and its been here for years and hopefully it will be here forever. in a mission that is rapidly turning yuppie places like balompie must be supported.

i'm not salvadoran but balompie has the best papusas of anywhere i've been to in sf, or california for that matter. big, tasty, free, with tasty salsa and cabbage on the side. their plantanos and beans are delicious as well and so is the casamiento. 

the atmopsphere is great, there is always a soccer match on the tv, usually a la liga match, but the sound isnt too loud. there is a great collection of soccer scarves hanging up all over the walls which i think is really cool and the service is very warm and friendly.

i love this place and its been here for years and hopefully it will be here forever!!! in a mission that is rapidly turning yuppie places like balompie must be supported.

EAT THERE TODAY!!!
author: ben s.

description: Excellent pupusas, but rice and beans were not very good. The pupusas were generously stuffed and made exceptionally well, with the cornmeal not too dry. Definitely a great spot for a casual lunch/dinner and drinks!
author: Jessica L.

description: I recommend the pupusas and the platano frito! Soo good. The only thing I didn't like was the horchata drink but that's because I'm so used to a different kind of horchata.
author: Marlo M.

description: Great food really good price, very hispanic which is very home feeling,pupusas were great and the empanadas were excellent only thing that i didnt like was the long wait. 4.5 out of five for me
author: Franklin B.

description:
Pupusas are comfort food to the max. Balompie makes a decent one, but I feel they somewhat lack on some of the fillings in them. Yes, they are good and properly grilled to a nice browning crust. Topped them with the mild vinegary cabbage and some salsa and they make a filling lunch with 2 pupusas.

 My fish, shrimp pupusas was OK, like I said, not to much filling as was the sausage and cheese. At $3.50 each, they were OK, expected more, as I had some from a excellent pupusas from the North Bay.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
PAPUSA!!!!!!!!!!!! This was a spot recommended by a few buddies when I wanted papusas and it did not disappoint! I was very glad to be able to eat very good papusas for a pretty cheap price. The restaurant is a sports bar geared towards soccer especially the european leagues and latin leagues.

Food-
Shrimp and cheese papusa- Very good
Chirzo and cheese papusa- tasty!

This place has a huge selection of different types of papusas!
author: Elliot T.

description: Yesterday, came for lunch/dinner, food was great, the horchata very tasty!! I ordered the 2 pupusas with rice & beans. The pupusas where delicious!! The rice not enough taste, beans where good! My hubby has the bistec Salvadoreño, Salvadorian Steak he loved it, very nice theme they had, various flags up. The waitres could have done alittle  better  explaining what was an item we wanted to know more of. Overall would come again but order only the pupusas and horchata to go!
author: Yessenia C.

description:
Mmmmm...pupusas...big fat pupusas!

This is becoming a serious addiction. The experience of tearing into thick masa bread that came piping hot with gooey stringy cheeses oozing outward along with your choice of meat or seafood is one powerful "wow" factor that can't be underestimated. These pupusas do not simply stop here to make an impression after triggering a temporary paralysis of non-stop drooling. As soon as I broke off a piece of one of their specialties--mariscos y queso pupusa--my growling stomach started to seize control of my body as I quickly dipped the bread into a red salsa on the side and made sure it was accompanied by plenty of cole slaw before shoving it into my wide open mouth. The entire process cannot be repeated until I stuffed a few more spoons of refried beans and Spanish rice to make sure that my mouth was jammed packed to capacity like what you would see on the MUNI lines during those crazy commuter hours. 

Nom nom nom...to me this was the sound of divine intervention with every component of the pupusa meshing together in my mouth. Thanks to Mika I, who declared this place as having the best pupusas in town, I had to drag my bestie David N to the Mish for a visit. When we walked in, the place was packed with people of all backgrounds with the ambiance alive and vibrantly decked out with soccer memorabilia everywhere. We sat under the flat screen TV that was showing women's soccer at the time, and we ordered the pupusas arroz y frijoles ($8.50) and crossed our fingers to hope that Mika was right. It took some time for our order to come, but along with a side dish of chunky cole slaw, my rice and beans gave a nice combination of textures to perfectly complement my choice of loroco con queso and mariscos y queso pupusa. I love the sweet scent of loroco while the other pupusa had a wonderful shrimp and fish filling that was excitable and delicious. They were both highly addictive and it made me wanna bring a big party here so everyone can sample all 17 choices of pupusas. I would love to check out their prosciutto, super veggie, and chorizo y queso in the near future.

Service was warm, friendly and helpful. The only complaint I have is their 55 cents surcharge on some of their pupusas for those who dine in, and for having a minimum of 2 pupusas per order. Other than that, my experience was worth 4.5 stars. This is one exciting place that I would love to come back.
author: Daniel L.

description:
AM HOOKED ! Can you believe I lived half a block away and never went here. I would go to another El Salvadorean restaurant :( ! 

The staff is amazingly helpful, as after 27 years here I still do not speak Spanish. As a general rule, I used to only get papusas but have expanded onto other dishes and have been delighted every time ! 

You cannot beat the prices - you'd pay way more at some "hip" joint - although most of us know what's truly hip are the paces like this that don't make the paper !
author: Karen H.

description: A busy local eateries. Dropped in for the Pupusa. Was good but the El Salvador was better. Like that they serve it with unlimited home made hot sauce. Sometimes, one of the locals entertains with his guitar too.
author: May C.

description:
Great papusas and good versions of other El Salvadoran food like tamals.  Very nice service and a cozy environment.  Good place to watch a soccer game on the Spanish station.  There are frequently large (20+ person) family groups eating here and it feels like a great neighborhood sort of place.
Good breakfast selection and friendly refills on the coffee.
author: Ric S.

description:
The pupusas are delicious. The pork and cheese one is really good. We also got the ground beef and cheese but it is pretty close to the pork and cheese. I would stick with the pork one because it's a bit cheaper. All of the pupusas are cheap. 

 I am kinda of shock to say this but I want to go back and try the veggie and cheese one. I think it just might be better than the meat and cheese one, considering I am in a constant fight with veggies. Eat the slaw and the pupusa together, the tanginess from the slaw combined with the rich melty goodness of the cheese is literally a party in your mouth. The girl that works the counter is super sweet.
author: Eve C.

description: After 8 years, this is still mine and my (now) wife's favorite mission breakfast. Best coffee too! Keep up the great work!
author: Michael C.

description:
I've never had El Salvadorean food before so this was a nice treat! We were seated immediately and our waitress was quick to serve us.

We ordered the horchata, which is different from Mexican horchata.  El Salvadorean horchata tastes more like milky cocoa.  In honesty, I think I like the Mexican horchata better.

But the pupusas here are outstanding!!!! They are sooooo good. They are like round flat thick tortillas filled with different types of ingredients.  It comes with a pickled mild spicy cabbage and a salsa sauce. If you combine them together, it tastes sooo good. 

We also tried the empanada with custard and the sweet tamale.

Service was excellent and prices were affordable. Parking can be a little difficult. I'm so happy we came here!
author: Janet E.

description: My coworkers and I stumbled across this place during one of our lunch breaks. They have a great selection of pupusas for a good price. I loved the spinach + cheese and ground pork + cheese + japapenos (I did wish the jalapenos had more of a kick though). My coworker loved the prosciutto + cheese one she ordered. The plantains with refried beans and sour cream we got as a starter was also really good. They take a while, though, so if you are ordering takeout, call in your order beforehand.
author: Jiselle L.

description:
Decor: 0.5
Quaint little corner restaurant with a view of the streets. It's not in a busy area, but if you like access to other options, then I didn't really see other places to check out nearby. I didn't get to see the seating area very well because we got our pupusas to go, but there seemed to be a good amount of space. We even sat on some stools while waiting for the food. The bathroom I hear is pretty clean, too.

Food: 0.5
I got pupusas which are kind of like soft tacos but contained in the fluffy wrapping, kind of like Hot Pockets in the shape of a pizza. Among the many  fillings offered, I got "chicken and cheese" and "ground pork." They taste similar to what you'd get at any Mexican taco. The red sauce we got was very mild and I could taste the spices (cilantro?) more. It left me wanting more because it was just enough to rescue my stomach from hunger, but it definitely didn't fill me up in any way. Overall, very easy to eat and quite non-offensive to the palate.

Price: 0.5
Decent price for the amount. $1.95 per pupusa to go (a bit more eating in). Decent price/portion ratio.

Service: 0.75
The delivery is not the fastest, but it seems like they take care of the food! The cashier was nice as well.

Overall: 2.25/5
I recommend anyone to try it out first and see how you like it from there :)
author: Brian H.

description:
First day in SF and I find myself hungry in the Mission - the same mission widely considered the most exciting food district in the city - so needless to say I'm excited. 

I'm new to Salvadoran cuisine, so I figure why not try a little bit of everything? A chicarron papusa, steamed yuca, and pastel de polla later, and I was definitely full and happy. 

I loved the no-frills atmosphere and the super interesting slice of humanity this restaurant (and really Mission in general) draws in. Food wise, I've probably had better, but Balompie is still a solid place to try something a little different.
author: Alex H.

description:
On the advice of 7x7 100 Things To Try Before You Die (2010), I rounded up an eating crew to try out Balompie's pupusas (Salvadoran hot pockets essentially).  We brought along a Salvadoran to be the expert.

The cafe is relaxed with a neighborhood hang out vibe, and the food is legit.  The "specialty" pupusas aren't traditional but who cares - order what you want.  I really liked the chorizo y queso and the traditional pupusas got high points too.

Grab your friends, order some beers, and have an awesome(ly) cheap dinner!
author: Priscilla T.

description: I'm a little spoiled I live so close to this place- take out or eat in, it's always hopping, & this place has the best papusas.  I get bean, but I hear they're all fabulous, what are you waiting for?
author: Coco J.

description:
As the name suggests, they are really into football (soccer) at this restaurant.  I opted for the whole fried tilapia instead of the famous pupusas.  The fish came with mixed vegetables and seasoned rice.  I think I liked the sides even more than the fish, and the fish was just that good! I had an orchata -- which was delicious, the fish was to die for, and the service was great.  

My only complaint has nothing to do with the restaurant really.  Dude, what's up with that parking situation? :-)
author: Courtney S.

description: I tried pupusas for the first time in my life here. Definitely a fan now. My favorite one was the cheese and bean pupusa. I also tried the ground pork, chicken, and beef ones as well.
author: Michelle H.

description:
I'd just learned about pupusas and I was so excited to try them. This was the first place I got to try them and definitely a great intro to 'em.

When you get them on a plate, it doesn't look like a lot of food, but it is incredibly filling. I got a pupusa, yuca, and pastel (corn pie) in the Salvadorean sampler plate, which I thought would be a nice try-a-little-of-everything meal. Everything was tasty and flavorful.

I've gotten to try their different pupusa offerings on multiple occasions: chicharrones y queso, Mejicana, chorizo y queso, espinaca y queso, and camaron y queso. I think I liked the spinach one the best.

I have grown to love Salvadorian orchata. It is delicious, and almost has a chocolate taste to it. It has a richer flavor that Mexican horchata. Yum!

Great food at great prices with friendly service.
author: Zi C.

description:
I LOVE PAPUSAS! They look so innocent...but oh no. They are actually full of evil/delicious cheesy goodness as soon as you slice them open. My favorite had the cheese and chorizo mixture wrapped inside the warm corn tortilla. I also recommend getting the papusas with the beans and rice. They all mix together very well and make the meal extra filling. The salsa and preserved veggies that accompany the papusas are also quite delicious. I had to ask for an extra BOWL of the salsa just to be satisfied. 

Other things I enjoyed were the fresh cantaloupe juice (tastes just like a cantaloupe) and the look of the meals from the customers sitting next to me. Those came with what looked like fresh tortillas and bread. Anything with extra carbs is good in my book so its safe to say that I will be back to try those dishes. 

Minus one star since the price for a papusa is a litte steep. Perhaps I will try to learn to make them on my own and come here for other goodies. 3.50 for one papusa (which is basically corn flour/cheese/abitofmeat) is quite a price tag.
author: Minerva l.

description:
I've been in and out of this neighborhood for some time and finally went ahead and tried it for myself after hearing about the reviews. I got three pupusas to go and they were all delicious! I got the ayote (zucchini), mariscos (fish and shrimp), and mexicana ones. Even by the time I got home, my order of this deliciously popular dish was still hot and made to perfection! Still slightly crispy on the outside, each pupusa had a reasonable portion of meats and cheese stuffed within. Adding in the complementary flavors of the pickled veggies and cool salsa, each pupusa was definitely a worth-while treat right before dinner time. Sharing the three pupusas with my brother has made me full already!

This place definitely has a homey and casual atmosphere to it. It seems like people living in the neighborhood swing by here all the time, which must definitely say something about the authenticity of these dishes. While I only got a chance to try their pupusas, I can say that I'll most likely swing by here again to try out some of their dishes including the brunch items!
author: Cheston W.

description: I have never written a bad review bc I'm not the pessimistic type but we will never come here again. We brought my sister here for her 30th bday tonight and had a very bad experience. We all feel so bad. First off, we waited an hour and 15 minutes for our food. That's ridiculous! 3 other families who came after us got served before us. They messed up on 2 orders so my sister had to wait 10 more minutes for her food and not to mention the platanos were VERY hard and dry. The pupusas de queso were good and the manager gave us a 15% discount for their bad service which is why I'm giving them 1 star.
author: Cecilia C.

description: The fried fish with shrimp is what keeps me coming back here! Served with rice and beans, the fish is always cooked to perfcetion with just enough salt and condiments on it. They serve you salad before too which is a plus. The shrimp is absolutely delicious as well. You guys have to try the horchata! The other plates are good too and the prices are good.
author: Anonymous ?.

description: A small little corner cafe that entices you in with the incredible smell of Latin American food. We are slowly making our way through the menu. Their Pupusa's are amazing as are the plantains. They have a very delicious salsa that my kids want to drink with a straw it is so good. Tortilla's are fresh and are the better choice if offered bread or tortilla's. The staff are always friendly and have a way of making you want to come back (as if the food wasn't enough). Definitely a must go to place when craving some Latin faire!!
author: Sandra B.

description: I had papusas with beans and rice. They were ok. El zocalo is South San Francisco is so much better though. The papusas were burnt and had black spots on them. The beans weren't good though
author: Cass D.

description: Let down, so many good reviews but their food other than their pupusas is salty. I dint recommend this place, unless you don't mind salty food.
author: Miguel G.

description:
There's a reason why their pupusas are on the 7x7 list.

I was on one of my little food tours again taking my friends to try various SF eats, and I decided to finally check this place out.  Keep in mind that my friends and I were already full from everything we had eaten, but we really wanted to try this.  So we just wanted to literally order 2 pupusas at $2.50 each and split among ourselves.  To be honest I was a bit embarrassed because the three of us sat down and our order total was $5...but the woman that served us was still very gracious and didn't give us a crappy attitude for taking a table and only spending $5 bucks.  Any who, service was great, food came out fast, and they were so good! 

We tried the ground pork and the zucchini pupusas.  The pork was great!  And while I am normally a meat person, I surprisingly loved the zucchini one and actually preferred it!  Great meal, light on the wallet...I'm coming back!
author: Tanya P.

description: GREAT pupusas! Sometimes I go to other places and excitedly order pupusas, hoping they are as good as Balompie's but I am almost always disappointed. Prices are reasonable but seating is cramped. My faves are the spinach & cheese and fish & cheese ones. Mmm someone please bring me one! Or 2, or 3...
author: Lily C.

description:
Balompie Cafe has made my life miserable... miserable because I live so damn far away and I can't eat their pupusas whenever I want!

For years my husband had raved to me about this little El Salvadorean restaurant in San Francisco that he said made _the_ best home-made pupusas. He claimed it was so authentic that the menu was entirely in Spanish. Now, I always take what he says with a grain of salt, but the last time we were in San Francisco he took me and a few friends to Balompie Cafe, and I've got to say it was worth the hype.

For only a few bucks a pop, the pupusas were outstanding. I tried two: the fish and the prosciutto. While both were great, the fish pupusa was my personal fave. I wish I were eating one right now. (It's totally reasonable to buy a $400 round-trip flight to get one, right? Riiight?) 

Not only was the food great, but the staff were all lovely as well. They were very patient with us while my entire table desperately tried to narrow down our options, which took a little work. And who could blame us? I'm sure everything is excellent.

One final note, their menu is NOT all in Spanish. That grain of salt was warrented after all.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Friends of ours recommended this place months ago. I'm not sure why it took so long to visit. Oh, yeah -- because a dinner of carbs stuffed with cheese is something I reserve for rare occasions. :)

Pupusas are so good, but when prepared fresh and to your specifications, they're out of this world. The pupusas at Balompie came to our table fresh, hot, firm on the outside, soft on the inside and filled with melted cheese. One was spinach and cheese and the other was ground pork and cheese. I would have loved a little more spinach in mine, but I'm OK with the idea that pupusas aren't going to be health food, no matter how much curtido you put on top. 

Since we didn't want to turn our evening into a total pupusa-fest, we also ordered entrees. My man had camarones in garlic sauce, and I had them in tomato sauce. The dish came with plenty of prawns. The tomato sauce was flavorful without being overpowering. The plates were heaped with rice and we also got little side salads -- with lettuce that was actually green and tomatoes that were actually red, which is kind of rare for a Latin American restaurant. 

The service was friendly and prompt, and the place has a very authentic feel -- there were older Latino guys watching futbal on the television while younger diners scarfed their pupusas. And the prices are totally reasonable. This isn't a super romantic date spot (the place is pretty loud), but the food and service make up for it.
author: Beth W.

description: The food was excellent!  Pupusas  were just the way they should be. Tasty and NOT greasy. I just had a problem with the noise level.  Tables are set pretty close, so  you can hear everyone's conversation at once.  Service was timely.  Our waiter kept us updated about the wait time.  The place was very busy.  For sure I'm going back.
author: Mercy V.

description:
Love this place. What it lacks in appearance it makes up for in the food. So many options. Love my Salvadorean food but it is so heavy!!!

Obviously it is not meant to be refined food. But it is damn good.
author: Penelope S.

description: I had the ground pork pupusas and they were great! Tender and flavorful meat mixed in with some nice spices - win!
author: C K.

description: My favorite pupuseria in the city. As a salvadorean I vouch for their pupusas. Delicious! Customer service is slow everytime....so have patience.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
PUPUSAS:
1.) Spinach = Yum, I liked this. Simple, but I like my cheese. 
2.) Pork = This was good. Dun remember what I'd compare to, but it reminds me of something else familiar. Will verify next time.
3.) Seafood = Meh. Good but not as good as the other two above!


SERVICE:
Not bad... 


ATMOSPHERE:
Casual....
author: Angela L.

description:
Not sure why this is on the 7x7 list.  That list is seriously letting me down all the time.  But when I can't think of what kind of food to try, my friends and I default to the list to try something new.  ugh.

I really like papusas, but this place was just okay.  And you have to get two papusas per flavor, so it's really difficult to find room in your stomach to try more than one flavor by yourself.  But thankfully, you don't really need to try more than one flavor because the excessive cheese overpowers most of the flavor anyway.  

The variety is nice.  I enjoyed the zucchini and fish papusas, but the cheese in both was excessive.  I appreciate that this place has nice service, but then again most of the places in that general area have to be attentive otherwise they wouldn't survive.  Probably won't go back here unless I have a ridiculous papusa craving.  But even then, I think Planto in Berkeley is better.
author: Anna T.

description: THE GO TO spot when you're craving some bomb papusas. Great service, and good vibes made the experience even more with while.
author: Jasmine J.

description:
This was my first experience eating a Papusa and I have to say... I am in love.  I tried their super vegetarian and the bean/cheese Papusa and they were both amazing.  We shared a side of fried plaintains and empanada's and we were stuffed to the gills. The price it totally right and the servers are quick and happy to be there. 

If you're looking for a long lingering meal with lots of ambiance, this is not the place for you. Come when you're ready to throw down and move on with your day.
author: Lauren K.

description: I've been turned on to pupusas by a friend's family of mine and have loved them ever since my first bite so I was curious how they would be in a restaurant.  Obviously they weren't as good as homemade but they were pretty close and very good.  We ordered three different kinds and all were delicious although I think I ate my weight in cheese there.  The staff was very friendly and it was pretty inexpensive as well.
author: Blake B.

description: Wow, what a great find!  I had never had a pupusa, but I had heard of them and I had to try them.  These corn tortilla filled pillows of love were heavenly.  I ordered them to-go my first time and they were decent.  The second time I decided to go in and see if they would be as great as thought they would be.  Yup, I was right they are great.  I ordered 2 pupusas, the Salvadoran veggies and cheese and the sausage and cheese and both were tasty!  Check out the pics of these pillows of love on my blog @ www.gonegluten-free.com.
author: Heather S.

description: Yes, Yes and Yes! This is a small establishment with authentic, delicious food at reasonable prices. I had some pupusas and my partner had a turkey sandwich, all were divine. We live in Seattle, where there are VERY few choices for any good Central or South American cuisine. I have been dreaming of these pupusas since!
author: A. C.

description:
My favorite pupuseria!

This place serves up tasty and satisfying pupusas and delicious fried plantains for very reasonable prices.

Definitely worth checking out.
author: Murphy O.

description:
I've been coming here for a while. The food is made to order, which means you'll be waiting a long time for your food. The quality is authentic Salvadorean Cuisine. Its not for those on a strict diet. You leave this place feeling stuffed. The food is excellent, affordable and comforting.
The Service how ever is questionable. Very casual, not refined or very attentive for that matter. But its a neighborhood, family owned restaurant and there's really no need for such pretentiousness!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
These pupusas are wonderful! 2 order min for both regular & specialty. Reg are $2.50 each & special are $3.50 each so not the cheapest pupusas in town. 

Pupusa w/ loroco - A+. Not sure what type of veggie loroco is, but it's yummy. A bit tart/bitter, it pairs so well w/ the melted, gooey cheese & grilled corn shell. 

Pupusa w/ zucchini - A+. Not a lot of zucchini in it, but enough to offer a flavoring to the cheese & corn shell. 

The cabbage slaw was delicious - shredded cabbage w/ a lite spiciness...I'm a spice-wuss & this was perfect. I topped both pupusas with all of the slaw & wanted more at the end (no, I didn't ask for more!). The red sauce (hot sauce?) is more on the jalapeno/spicy side so I only drizzled it on top of pupusa/cabbage mixture but the sauce added a different zip/hotness to the dish not gotten when eaten w/o it.

I stayed away from the cut veggies brought as my waitress warned me they were "very spicy"...I saw the jalapeno seeds layered on top of the carrots/cauliflower/jalapeno pepper mix & said, no thank you!

Horchata is made fresh there daily & it's for real. Soooo good, & I'm not usually a fan b/c it's too watery. But this was just right...a bit sweet, not overly watery or gritty. I think I had the best lunch of pupusas & horchata I've ever had! And all for under $10!

$10 min for credit card charges, otherwise cash. 

The restaurant obviously knows what they're doing. I used to live in the area & the place was always packed. It was like that today as well w/ Latinos, Americans & everyone in between having a sit-down meal or takeout. In the words of Arnold... "I'll be back".
author: Marissa H.
