description: Great Place! The Pupusas are delicious! the curtido, salsa and escabeche are fresh! you can taste the Crunchiness' on it. Their customer service is Great . they are fast. If you are craving some platanos fritos , that the spot!
author: Gigi H.

description: I was in the area running errands and started getting hungry.  I already had a parking spot so I decided to stay put and checked Google for the nearest food joint.  Balompie showed up and was only a block away, so I walked in and ordered. I had no idea of the stellar reviews on Yelp.  Fantastic food and great service!  I ordered the #2 breakfast and it was delicious.  The beans were very unique - mixed with rice and had a crust from being on the flat top grill.  Amazing flavor.  There was a cheese cube which had the perfect salty flavor and tasted incredibly fresh.  The eggs were scrambled with veggies and the homemade tortillas were thick, hot and fresh.  I've never had tortillas quite like these...EVER.  I then checked Yelp - as I was eating - and saw all the great reviews, particularly on the pupusas.  I was stuffed, but HAD to try them, as I was not sure when I would be back in the area.  I ordered 2 pupusas and they were  FANTASTIC!  So fresh and tasty.  The red sauce and slaw were great with it.  I will most definitely make a point to return.
author: D R.

description:
We went here for the first time today.  We all had pupusas.  The Ayote & cheese were good. Las revueltas were good, the chicharron and cheese were good, the fish and cheese pupusa needed to go back.  The fish was smelling like a fish market, the fish was old and the fish pupusas had to go in the trash.  The orchata was too milky and not enough moro.  We are salvadoreans and we went because of the reviews.  Over all a lot of their plates look delicious but we only had pupusas and I would say the pupusas were the best choice in there of what we had with the exception of the fish pupusas.  The prices were a bit high for the quality of food.  If you like salvadorean orchata, this is not the place to have it.  Theirs tasted more like chocolate milk.  It was very dissapointing. The place is very small, some of the tables are touching.  Most likely you will be sitting next to other parties and don't plan on having an intimate conversation.  This is not a place for it.  Attire is very casual, they do serve liquor.  The people are friendly and do speak English in case you don't speak Spanish. We had kids in our party and they love pupusas. This wat they had to say about the pupusas: very good, good flavor, not enough salt, the chicharron was all in one spot. Would they go back they said no. They said they rather go to _________, a place where we had been in our previous visit to California.
FYI, there is no parking.
author: Blanca R.

description: BEST papusas in life! Even better than the ones I had in El Salvador. I'm smitten with Balompie's delicious and reasonable food, friendly and personable service and my great seat at the end of the bar. Balompie's is to me what Cheers was to Norm.
author: Sadie D.

description:
small, hot restaurant with good food and nice staff. 

had pupas which were very good and filling (shrimp w/ cheese-nicely cooked and not over done, bean and cheese- tasty, vegetarian one seemed more cheesy than the bean and cheese one somehow. perhaps it was the butter they used to saute the vegetables). 

Had the chorizo egg breakfast which was really good. 

the pickled cabbage made everything  that much better. would come back to try the fish pupas (they were out when we got there :(
author: Elaine Y.

description: Food was great, delicious pupusas and authentic Salvadorian food. The atmosphere wasn't super fancy, but the service was fast and friendly and the portions were very fair. I had the chili releno with pork, and cheese pupusas, my boyfriend tried a few pupusas with rice and beans. Everything was really delicious. I will definitely be going back soon!
author: Samantha G.

description:
GIving Balompie 5 stars for their pork, jalepenos, and cheese pupusas! They were the best pupusas I've ever had. The crispy toasted flour with the gooey cheese made it all so delish. 

My friend who went ordered the Modongo (Tripe Soup). He LOVED it. They were generous with the meat and included a few tendons as a bonus.
author: Joanne C.

description:
On a Saturday morning, I decided to go have a central american breakfast which would consist of casimento, plaintains con creama.  I thought what better place than Balompie.  I arrived at 8am as the first customer, I was greeted by Laura who had a warm friendly invite and made my experience memorable.  She made recommendations and I opt for the number #2.  The food arrived and boy was I in heaven.  Everything was fresh and she kept checking on my mug being filled with coffee and asked how the experience was.  
I plan on trying the other items listed and hope next time she will be working.  Other thing I like is they serve beer
author: Isis L.

description:
Ive never tried El Salvadorian food before. My bro in law was going to get married in May. So they decided to get cuisines from both cultures to be catered.  

As we entered ,the atmosphere was very lively. Music blasting from a jukebox, two TVs displaying the Superbowl, and many people enjoying their meal. 

The bride of the wedding ordered papusas and paharittos. (Sorry for the spelling) All in different flavors.

Bean & cheese
Cheese
Chicken
beef
Pork
Zucchini and cheese

All of these were papusas and all of them were oh so yummy! The meat was very plentiful and the cheese was gooey :)

Although i did not try anything else, i bet the rest of their food would be delicious!

So in conclusion the groom and the bride are definitely impressed and ordering from here!
author: Eleanor D.

description:
O ...M...G. Pupusas, pollo guisado, platanos fritos con crema, and agua de horchata?! Can I ask for a better lunch? NO! Perhaps a healthier lunch that wont cause a food coma? Of course, but who cares?! Balompie's Salvadorean food is to die for, full of flavor and at a great price. They have all kinds of pupusas and plenty of other dishes. Get there early during lunch hour, it gets packed!

This place will NOT disappoint!
author: Susana M.

description:
I have to disagree- Cafe Balompie (Spanish slang for soccer) is meh. Came here recently with 2 relatives for pupusas. We all started with hot chocolate (yum!!) which is tall and super yummy. 

For some reason we all departed from pupusas- my mom and aunt got chile rellenos  with casamiento (rice and beans mixed togther), and I got salpicon (chopped beef with mint and onions). All 3 came with a salad beforehand, so overall it was a big portion. But unfortunately, all 3 were blaaaah. 

I'll look elsewhere for good Salvadoran food! Also, the bathroom was disgusting.
author: Amaranta C.

description: My favorite restaurant in the Mission. Have tried other Salvadorian places always come back here. The pupusas are the best I've had. All the ingredients are freshly prepared and delicious. The staff are always nice and the atmosphere pre-gentry simple and warm. My foodie cousin from Paris ate here every day after I introduced him to Balompie!
author: stephan k.

description:
I placed an order over the phone and sent the bf to go pick it up. Ordered Bistec con camarones which was very flavorful and came with 3 large shrimp still in the shell, a heaping side of very tasty refried beans (which is something I usually don't like) and a side of rice. We also ordered a pupusas platter with one loroco and one zucchini and another order of pupusas, one with shrimp and cheese and one with pork and cheese. My favorite was definitely the loroco and zucchini. The slaw that they give to go on top of the pupusas along with the red sauce is so damn good. I was weary at first so I only poured a little red sauce on, but after trying it, I ended up drowning everything in red sauce! 

This place is awesome and the prices are super reasonable!
author: Jen D.

description:
Pupusas are the new taco.  Pupusa trucks will be the next big thing, trust.  
Balompie Cafe has basic Salvadorean food done nicely.  I enjoyed the pupusas with the Salvadorean veges and carnitas.  

The plantains were good but I prefer the New Spot for tasty fried deliciousness.  

I like that they have futbol from around the world on huge flat screens.  You know it is authentic when they've got that on.
author: Monica L.

description: I discovered pupasas thanks to my boyfriend and his family.  I've checked out other places around the city and really didn't care for any of them. So only had the good stuff when his family cooked. Until this place! Love their pupasas! I always order the cheese and loroco and cheese and spinach. This is the first place I've seen that do the spinach and it's delicious. After trying a few things I prefer the tortillas made with rice flour. And I just can't have it without a little cortido and salsa. What would I have done without my boyfriend for introducing me to a new favorite and yelp for showing me this place? Everything else here looks good but I can only vouch for the Pupasas. If you're in the area try it. This place is small and it almost always busy so I usually get food to go. Service has always been pleasant and quick.
author: Kelli V.

description: OH ME OH MY! Some of the most delicious food I've had in San Francisco!  The papusas are top notch with plenty of variety. They offer traditional Salvadorian fare as well as non traditional options. The staff is friendly and if your willing to wait you're in for a treat.
author: Nina W.

description:
Despite the warm and friendly service, the food was a bit disappointing.

The plantains were served with sour cream only- no beans!
The fried yuca was a bit tough. Tasty, but tough.
Skip the steamed sweet corn tamal and ask for it fried instead.

Papusas are a stand-out here and I enjoyed both the zucchini and cheese and bean and cheese. If you come here, order those along with a melon to drink. You can assure yourself a tasty meal that way.
author: Miriam W.

description: This was my first time trying pupusas in general and can't say that I'm a huge fan of them, too much cheese and not enough meat for me but that's just more personal taste. I would come back again to try their other food. They do offer a vast variety of pupusas with different fillings; I would recommend trying one if you haven't before. The restaurant is small and offers individual tables as well as communal tables. We did have quite a bit of a mix up with our orders and with the bill. When they brought us our pupusas, they had our orders all switched around with different people's pupusas on different plates. In the end we were able to figure it out amongst the six of us but one person in our group did end up with something she didn't order. They also managed to screw up our bill as it somehow added on the previous party's bill who sat at our table on top of ours. We were able to work it out with the manager, but we did have to spend a considerable amount of time to figure out what went wrong.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Why did I come back to this spot again? 

Our orders:
I orded the carne asada with casamiento. The steak was flavorless but the casamiento was tasty. 
My coworkers ordered yuca with chicharron and 2 pupusas. I tried their dishes and neither was anything special. I am not a fan of pupusas so I cannot judge them but the chicharron was dry.

The  prices are high for what you get. Also, it takes forever to get your food. Definitely not coming back.
author: Andreia G.

description:
Very very very tasty. 

Definitely get a few pupusas. (If you haven't ever had pupusas, be sure to put some of each of the bowls of condiments that come on the side on top of your pupusa.) I wasn't impressed with the fried yucca or the horchata, but the Salvadorian style steak we ordered was delicious. 

So yeah, there are a couple things on the menu that I didn't love, but I still loved Balompie.
author: Emily C.

description: Favorite Salvadorean restaurant in SF. Amazing pupusas, I prefer the bean and cheese kind all the time. Great service, feel-like-home environment. A lot of natives come here. This place has been around for years. And it's not expensive at all.
author: Rico H.

description:
Thank goodness for people who know how to order.
We had one guy do all the ordering, and dude knocked it out the park.  My lunch party had plates filled with grilled chicken, carne asada, shrimp, this deep fried empanada thing, chorizo, chips, and garnished with red onions, beans, tomatoes, fried yucca, and lettuce.  
Other tables would stare and point at our when it came time for them order.  And when I thought they couldn't bring out anymore food, here come the papussas.
The food was great.  I especially like the freshness of the grilled shrimp and the fried yucca.  I hope I've learned enough to figure out what to order when I go on my own.

My only gripe was how much we ended up spending on brew.  It was almost as much as the food itself.  Damn drunkards.  Now, I'd be the first to admit brew goes well with the food but still.
author: Dan B.

description: Had dinner here for the first time last night. Had beef tongue, seafood soup and papusas. Almost too much food for the two of us and soo good. Really enjoyed the family style casual atmosphere and service.
author: John G.

description:
Good to come grab a bite with a large-ish group. I stopped by here for a pre bday bar hop 'lets fill up so we can drink more' stop. 

Its a pretty chill place, not somewhere you want to bring out of towners to, but somewhere you can come hang with your buddies. Not a good first date spot. You get the idea.
author: Anish B.

description: Simply delicious!  This is the closest taste I have had to the pupusas back home!
author: Laura M.

description: Ordered take-out for a small gathering at the house and it was fantastic!  I am still thinking about how incredibly tasty the casamiento was - perfectly flavored beans and rice all mushed up together.  The Salvadorian platanos really brought me back home and I cannot wait to go back and get more without traveling to El Salvador.  We also had pupusas, which are always fantastic.  I highly recommend Balompie Cafe for authentic El Salvadorian food, just like my grandma and great grandma made!!  Delicioso!
author: Cristina M.

description:
So I FINALLY came to Balompie after riding my bike past it for years.  I loved the soccer theme and since a few friends had beat me to checking out Balompie, and I have been living in the Mission for a year, I just had to make a trip.  

Of course you have to get the pupusas  so that's what I tried: I got the Mejicana y Queso (ground pork, jalapenos and cheese), Loroco con Queso (Salvadoran veggies and cheese) and Ayote con Queso (zuchinni and cheese).  Well I thought I'd like the one with meat the best but the two veggie ones were delish!  

Definitely a nice, low key vibe here and it's pretty homey feeling here.

All I know is I wanna go back and try more of their dishes to do a more complete review!
author: Gene X.

description:
I've been eating pupusas since my mom first took me to a Salvadoran place back when I was just a young, impressionable child. Since those early experiences, I love walking into a pupusa joint and hearing the sound of the patting of masa against the hands coming from the kitchen. 

A few weeks ago I experienced the best pupusas I've had since accompanying my mom to pupusa places that no longer exist. 

Balompie Café turns out quality pupusas chock full of ingredients. I was shocked to see the number of varieties offered. I had to go with a few including shrimp, beans and my go-to, loroco variety. They came to our table piping hot and plumb with goodies inside. The curtido (slaw) served with the pupusas was just the right balance of vinegar, oregano and cabbage. 

If you're in search of the perfect pupusa, look no further. Balmopie is your place.
author: Lee H.

description: I just stopped into this restaurant for a quick breakfast. I had no preconceived notions about this place; in fact I had never even heard of it. I ordered scrambled eggs and they came with unbelievable rice and beans. To top it off  I was also given two freshly made pupusas. This was a very simple meal but it was to die for. The place was almost full but very calm and quiet. It became obvious that they have quite a following. Well, you can add one more to your list!
author: Jenol M.

description:
As far as pupusas go, one of the best I"ve tried. They are of good size, and have the right portion of fillings inside. The outside is crisp and dry, not moist with grease.. a definite plus. Other things worth mentioning:
- Great , friendly service and an overall chummy atmosphere with families, couples, singles alike. 
- They have a small bar with basic beers on tap for those that want to eat quick and head out. 
- Tv's showing soccer and baseball.. whoohoo
author: Jim Y.

description: I've driven past this restaurant may times and have always seen at least a small crowd inside.  Today I decided to give it a try for a late lunch.  I ordered pupusas with casamiento.  This is certainly the best Salvadorian food and horchata I've had in a long time.  It was definitely a casual environment but the food was great as was the service.  My only regret was that I hadn't tried this place sooner.
author: Kent W.

description:
I'm not Salvadorean, so I'm no pupusa expert, but in comparison to other places where I've eaten pupusas, this is my favorite. There is something ridiculously good about the cheese they put in the pupusas. They also have what are called empanadas de leche, which are essentially plantains stuffed with some milk-like filling, that are hella good.

Loved this place. Loved the food, loved the service. Awesome.
author: victoria s.

description: The food is good. The service is okay, depending on whether they're busy or not. The portions are sometimes smaller than expected though. But overall, not a bad little place to have breakfast or lunch.
author: Yocelyn C.

description:
I'm so glad that this is a strictly Salvadorean place and not one of those Mexican/Salvadorean places. Perhaps those are good, but I can just imagine some clueless person ordering a burrito and not being impressed when maybe what they SHOULD have gotten were pupusas revueltas. Can people back off of burritos in general please? There's so much more to Mexican than that! I digress...

You can't have a discussion about Salvadorean places without talking about pupusas. It would be like a discussion about a Southern restaurant without talking about their fried chicken. In addition to the more traditional pupusas of cheese, pork, and/or beans, they've got specialty ones that would raise some eyebrows in the old country. Spinach, mushroom, carrot and cheese? Whatever. I stay traditional. Never disappointed. I recommend pairing them with the salsa and curtido (quick pickled cabbage and carrot) to cut the richness.

I've also had the yucca with chicharron, chicken pasteles, and empanadas. These empanadas are made with a fried plantain exterior and filled with either refried beans or a milk custard. I prefer the custard.

The horchata here has a texture that can read as gritty I guess if you didn't grow up with it. To me horchata SHOULD have texture. Try it! You might like it! They always have it on hand in addition to another beverage. In the past it's been tamarindo--a sweet-sour cloudy tamarind drink, or chan--a citrusy bright red drink with flax seeds.

Take a break from all those burritos you've been eating in the Mission and come here sometime.
author: Diana O.

description: Um, I'm not sure why I hadn't been here before. The pupusas and beans are soooooooooooo gooooooood!
author: Farah S.

description:
I came here to fuel up before my dance class at ODC. The minute I walked in, I wanted to skip the class, order some beers and food, and watch soccer with the locals. Had a veggie and also a pork papusa, which were made fresh. They smelled great, but unfortunately, it took so long that I only managed to gobble down half of one before my class. The rest, I ate afterwards, and they are not very good cold. 

Not the fairest review, so I will have to check it out again and sit down to enjoy over beers and good company.
author: Ai S.

description:
I'm upgrading my review from the last time I came here.  This place is open late, I came here around 9 pm with friends on a Friday night b/c every other restaurant was booked up.  This place always has seats open, and it's fast n' hearty.

I got the beef stew, and it was great!!  It's a little expensive for a little cafe - $9 for the beef stew, which comes with a side of rice & pinto beans - but it's a delicious, hearty meal that really hits the spot after a night out.
author: Bee M.

description:
Contaminated food!

My wife and I ate here about 2 weeks ago. It was the ONLY meal we ate together that day, so there is no question how it happened... That night my stomach was rumbling and I woke up sweating with diarrhea. We were both on death's door with diarrhea, fever, dizziness for about 2-3 days afterward. I have not felt that sick In years - since I was in Brazil and got the gringo initiation to 3rd world water treatment. 

Also, my wife is pregnant, which is concerning being that she was so sick. 

Will NEVER go here again...should call the health department actually...

Actually, on the good side I lost about 5lbs!  It's the new fad diet - food poisening!
author: Brian N.

description: Too much cheese in the papusas.  The pasteles were surprisingly nice, but that's about the only thing that was alright.
author: Di Yin L.

description:
Dear Balompie,

I hold you responsible for any weight gain over the next few weeks since  I am undoubtedly addicted to your papusas and keep wanting more.  First it started off with just a fantasy then, I finally went in to get my fix and now I've already eaten there twice this week!

Sincerely yours 

On a serious note, the food here is amazing and not just the papusas, the platanos & yuca are out of this world.  Everything about this place is authentic from the food, to the atmosphere, live music and the affordable prices.  If you like Salvadoran food you MUST go here!
author: Molly M.

description: My friend and I came here when we were both craving a small meal.  I was quite pleased with the selection of food, cost, and the ambience of the place (quite family-friendly and casual).  Our waitress was nice and friendly, and we ordered some pupusas (one shrimp and one vegetable) with sweet plantains.  Everything was delicious, and the whole meal cost around $10.  Good, cheap food in a friendly place makes me very happy!
author: Judy C.

description:
After a hard morning's work of purging closets and dropping of our donations at the Community Thrift Store, my best friend and I felt we needed to reward ourselves.  Since we are obsessed with pupusas and empanadas I looked up where to find them on yelp.  Balompie was one of the front runners.  Walking into Balompie yesterday was like being transported to another country with Spanish flowing from all around and soccer on tv.  

We shared multiple pupusas, rice and beans, empanadas filled with custard and plantains, and a side order of chicharrones.   The most savory pupusa, filled with ground pork, jalapenos and cheese, was hands down our favorite.  We, of course, had to try the more exotic loroco (El Salvadoran vegetable that looks a little like okra) and cheese pupusa which tasted of malt or Ovaltine.  The empanada was unlike any I had before, shaped like a large egg, with dark brown coloring and exterior looked like a burned corn dog.  I enjoyed the sweet custard filling which made me wonder if this was perhaps more often eaten as a dessert.  The preparation of the chicharrones somehow resulted in a loss of the crispy skin which happens to be my favorite part.  I was disappointed because it wasn't what I expected but it was still good.  Make sure you add the hot sauce they put on the table to spice your pupusa up.  I look forward to going back to Balompie again and trying other things on their very large menu.
author: Jeannette W.

description: Delicious Salvadoran food in a lively, casual atmosphere.  Helpful/friendly service, really great prices, generous portions.  Good variety of menu items, including pupusas.  A fun, friendly place with soccer games playing on televisions.  If you're looking for some great latin food in a lively/relaxed atmosphere, you will be wonderfully satisfied.
author: Katherine C.

description:
This is in my top 5 favorite places to eat in San Francisco! It's super cheap (I can fill up AND have a drink for under $10 for dinner). 

I always get two pupusas, usually one with cheese and one without (because the cheese ones are so rich) -- my faves are Queso con Loroco and plain Frijoles, and they come with super yummy salsa and cabbage salad. If I'm extra hungry I add the plantains breakfast (#1) with refried beans and crema. Everything I have tried is good, and all the platters etc. that other customers order look delicious.

The staff take great care of the place and the service is relaxed and friendly.

LOVE!
author: Jenny H.

description: Love the name. This restaurant reminds me of Pupuserias in El Salvador and the food tastes authentic.
author: Wendell A.

description: The pupusas were good.  I had the loroco con queso(Salvadoran vegetables with cheese) and the zucchini pupusas.  The curtido(Latin American cole slaw) and salsa were also good. The horchata was OK.  It's not fancy, but the service was great and it was very reasonably priced.  It's a short walk from the 16th and Mission Bart station.  Ok, I saw the review about the cockroaches.  Hey, did you know that some female cockroaches get pregnant and stay pregnant for life?  And you think you have problems??  Well, the place looked clean and I didn't see any cucarachas.  If I could have seen a nice big fat pregnant one, I would have given them 5 stars!
author: Blondie R.

description:
parking is a little difficult.

so their prices went up a little.  2.50 a papusa and you must get a minimum of 2...so 5 dollars for 2 papusas.

they taste good.  they seem fresh made.  they are just as good as any other papausa out there.  

they even have ground beef and spinach papusas which other places don't have,  so i guess that could warrant 2.50 a papusa.

okay, i've just been so spoiled with the 2.00 papusas and some at 1.40 that i just can't seem to justify a 2.50 cent papusa.

Sure they taste just as good.  But that means the other has a BETTER value.

Don't go with my stars on this place.  Go if you like papusas, and you want to try one with ground beef or with spinach.

okay, i'll just bump up the 3 stars to 4.
author: Bing D.

description:
If you are craving pupusas, and don't you want to wait 2 hours like when you go to El Zocalo, and you are too far away from Santaneca, then Bolompie is your next bet. Located on 18th St., between South Van Ness and Capp St., I discovered this place when I was just in the mood for something that was simple, straight to the point , and  would hit the spot. Service was friendly, fast, and welcoming. The ambiance was homey, and food was just was I wanted. 

     The thing that I read about Balompie is that they offer an extensive option of fillings other than the regular queso such as chicken, fish, shrimp, and ground beef as well as a few other combinations. 

     I had the cheese with ground beef and that was tasty and very good. I also had the seafood combo with fish and shrimp and that was good as well. Personally, I prefer a simple queso pupusa con loroco to satisfy my appetite.  Sooooooooooooooooooooooo simple and good. They also offer a good selection of other plates asides from pupusas, which I will definitely be back for, however, I just need two delicious pupusas and an horchata for satisfaction. 
     
    So, if you like pupusas, and are fed up with waiting for these delicious treats elsewhere, then go to Balompie. They are here to welcome, serve, and feed you with open arms !!!!!!
author: Granolia G.

description: My parents were Salvadoreans and I have been eating pupusas here in San Francisco since I was 4 years old. I've eaten in just about every Salvadorean restaurant in the city. Pupusas I am sure look like they are easy to make  but I assure you that nothing could be further from the truth! I was once taken to a place that claims to be Mexican/ Salvadorean and it was the most grotesque version of a pupusa I have ever been unfortunate to taste. Balompies hands down makes the very best pupusas in the city and county of San Francisco. Not to mention the staff works hard to please even when they are at capacity. If you need to call in with a large order they can do that and with few exceptions do it in the timeframe they say they will do it in. Also they have a shrimp pupusa which has no match anywhere. I could care less what the prices are given the amazing food they make. I would pay anything thats how good they are but relax their prices are very reasonable. If you want to taste authentic pupusas or any other type of Salvadorean food you have to make it to BALOMPIE!
author: Jim S.

description:
AMAZINGNESS!!!! We got there right before 11am on a Sunday, right before church got out. Praise Jesus we made it there and got seats in time. 
The papusas were awesome cheesy goodness. I tried three different kinds, all were good, though I was partial to the plain ol cheese.
author: Sarah M.

description: Holy wow, this place makes some amazing papusas. Just order a meal (two of them with beans and rice) and you'll be more than satisfied.
author: Pierre B.

description:
The ambiance lends itself to sports cafe minus the sticky, stank, stale beer on the floor. ie. it's classier. and you're going to catch futbol - not football. 

As for dinner, the pupusas were delish - chorizo & cheese and spinach & cheese - more like, cheese specked with a little green but both lots of flavor and gooey, melty, a little greasy. The grilled chicken w/grilled onions was so entirely bland - both in color and flavor - you might consider pouring over the whole bowl of red sauce. The accompanying rice and refried beans didn't add much in terms of color, flavor or texture. I found myself eyes other patrons' meals more than my own, the grass was much greener on the other side of the table.

I might come back and try breakfast but other than that, there's nothing pulling me back.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Had the pupusa, yuca and pastel combo with a glass of horchata. Loved the toasty-tasting horchata, the crisp, freshly fried yuca and the wonderful cabbage slaw that came with my entree. The pupusas, however -- supposedly the stars of the show -- were good but really not memorable. 

I'd eat here again if I was in the area, but I wouldn't travel across town again just for this place.
author: Todd H.

description:
I'm torn. Pupusas taste awesome, but at $2.50 per pupusa and about 3 to get me full.... I could have gotten a burrito. Argh, but they taste so good!

I tried pork, chicken, and shrimp. It came with a side slaw and some tomatoey-vinegary sauce that was a perfect pair to cut through the richness of the pupusa.

This place is regularly packed, but you can order to-go as well. I don't mind spending a few more bucks just to get some tasty pupusas, and on the plus side, they're cheap and filling to get you through the day as a snack. I'll come back to experiment more since I live on the block.
author: Charles L.

description:
As a big fan of pupusas I thought this would be paradise. It turns out that these pupusas are just okay. The best pupusas I've had were off the street at a festival. I had one shrimp and one vegetable pupusa. What's strange is that I couldn't taste the difference between the two after awhile. I think it's because they put so much cheese in it overwhelms any other flavor. I also had the pupusas with beans and rice. The beans and rice are plain and surprisingly uninteresting. I left content but not wowed.

They give you individual bowls of sauce and cabbage to top your pupusas. I think they don't give you enough sauce but I guess you could always ask for more.

Service was great. Very very friendly. I couldn't ask for anything more. As a restaurant this place seems very popular. Having two flatscreen is good for games but there isn't a ton of seating so get here early if you want to catch a soccer match.
author: Michael H.

description:
Ugh, I really really liked this place but after a sort of not so great experience, I can't give it the stars the food itself deserves.

We went for pupusas on a crowded Friday evening but were seated right away and ordered fairly quickly.  4 pupusas and plantains with sour cream.  Waited quite a bit to be served, but the pupusas are made to order and when they did arrive they were hot and melty.  They tasted so good we almost forgot that were weren't served ANY of the accompanying sides (sauce, slaw etc).  By the time we thought to flag down a waitress, we were basically done so we never asked for them.  I spent most of the meal trying to calm down my boyfriend who felt like we got the "white person" treatment.  Literally everyone sitting around us got served the sides, even if they weren't having pupusas.  

Typically, I hate Yelp reviews that just comment on the service, but when its bad enough, it certainly can change your mind about a place.

But the pupusas were delicious; I'd recommend you go and make sure you get your sides!
author: Kristin P.

description:
On this day I went to Bisou, BiRite, Blondies and then Balompie and I was a little borracho (borracha??).

I'll have to go back soon so I can write a proper review. Unfortunately I can't comment too much on my visit since I had quite a few drinks at Bisou and Blondie's beforehand BUT I vaguely remember eating several pupusas and enjoying a seafood one. I had a Salvadoran beer that was good, I think. Husband says that the beer was good and economical and that his meat platter was really good. 

Not too many details but husband says that it was really good and that we are going back...so, 4 stars! :)
author: Kiristen R.

description:
Dirty little secret of many Salvadoran restaurants: the service you receive will vary according to your perceived socio-economic status, i.e. your gender and even [gasp!] your color and race.  Yeah, I know, it's a phenomenon not unique to these restaurants, but the boldness of it is.  

Case in point: I visited Balompie over half a dozen times with my (whitish) boyfriend and liked the food and service each time.  The pupusas are great, the guacamole was surprisingly fresh and tasty, and the salpicon plate was awesome.  I liked it so much that I decided to take my Salvadoran mom and sister to lunch there (sans bf) and WOW, what a huge difference in the quality of the service.   Our food took forever to come (over half an hour) and came in a crazy order: each person's food came separately and the tortillas came at the end of the meal (wtf?!).  The waitress seemed to disappear for long periods of time and never came to check in on us; we had to spend 15 minutes trying to flag her down just to get the check - the place was not even half full!  The next time I went with the bf, I paid closer attention and saw that  same waitress being oh-so-attentive and constantly checking in...with him.  Hmm...yeah.

I'm trying not to blame this particular restaurant for something I've observed at several Salvadoran restaurants (yes, in SF); having lived in ES for several years, I can't say I'm too surprised to see the strong stratification and prejudices of the home culture reflected in the restaurants here.  It's still disappointing, though - I mean, come on, this is San Francisco.

In conclusion: the food is good (esp. the pupusas, guacamole, horchata, and salpicon), the futbol-themed decor is interesting, and it's a good place to try Salvadoran brews.  But if you're brown and female like me, watch out for the spotty service.  Or you could just take your lighter-toned SO.  [shakes head]
author: Stacey S.

description:
I thought i was going to find an alternate to El Zocalo... me thinks o0o Heccky naww!!
one: this place smelled like mold.  (it was bad)
two: the waitresses were rude and didnt want to be there (they wouldn't explain the menu)
three: its crowded (practically sitting on top of each other)
four : overpriced with no flavor  (im not happy)
i went once and i'm not making that mistake again real talk.
4 *'s for what?
author: Sherrell D.

description: Delicious pupusas! Best Ive had so far & the service is really good, everyone is so nice.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I've loved pupusas ever since my manager, who'd lived in El Salvador for a while, introduced them to me in SD. Things haven't changed much, except that I still love them. 
I came here on a random weekday for lunch with two other friends. We pretty much each ordered two pupusas, and one friend ordered the combo/sampling platter.
The pupusas were by no means bad... they were good. The reason I knocked a star is just because service was meh on a not-that-busy day. We probably waited at least 25 minutes after ordering for our food to show up. I know Latin American culture tends to go along a slower pace, but not when it comes to food, man! We had to refill our parking meter just because it took a lott longer than expected.
Food was good, prices were cheap, service was meh.
author: Jen T.

description: Ohhhh my god! SO GOOD! Everything was fresh and very well prepared. The atmosphere is a little silly, but it added to the sense of adventure! The wait staff is very sweet and laughs at your bad Spanish jokes, all important factors! Will definitely be going back and taking all my friends there when they visit the bay area!
author: Catherine J.

description:
Pupusas & Empanadas (filled with beans) = HELLA GOOD (though practically any food is hella good after dancing hula). Came here with some of my hula sisters in need of filling our stomachs. Balompie did NOT disappoint. In fact, it made us all shut up because we were too busy stuffing our faces. I had 1 pupusa and 1 empanada and was completely satisfied. A note about the empanada that I fell in love with, it's similar to eating the platanos and black beans from Cha Cha Cha's (which is just around the corner). And if you know what I'm talking about, then you know it's good. 

Staff was awesome too. We had 7 in our party and told them we didn't mind eating separately so we didn't have to wait for a big table to open, but they managed to seat all of us together fairly quickly. Plus, they took our order while we were waiting to be seated so our wait time didn't have to be as long. 

Most definitely want to go back because it'd be a sin if I didn't.
author: Valerie E.

description: Baby's first pupusa. Oh why did I wait so long? Pork...and cheese...and gooey...oh god. Smooshed together with curtido and sauce and...wow, those fried plantains on the side sure are nice, but I need about ten more orders of pupusas. I don't know if good pupusas are a dime a dozen in SF, but I do know that they are fantastic here. Add a laid back, cozy environment and friendly service with real smiling included, and this would be my go-to neighborhood spot. If this were my neighborhood. And, uh, city. And state. *thinking of moving*
author: Keegan L.

description: When perusing the depths of my mind for the best Spanish cuisine to have on a Saturday night, the word "pupusa" escaped my partner's lips and and  immediately after we were dead set to attain said delicious discs of savory, cheesy goodness. Luckily, our chauffeur is of Salvadoran descent and quickly agreed to indulge in our desires, so we were quickly transported to Balompie and our expectations were definitely surpassed. We were served two surprisingly large, crisp pupusas stuffed to the edges with gooey cheese that beckoned us like a siren calling out to her unsuspecting victims. We dug in and an explosion of flavor and ooze took me to a magical place where giddy Salvadoran children roam with golden pupusas in hand. It truly was a transcendent experience that was magnified when topped with "curtido" (lemony cabbage mixture) and their signature salsa. The acidity of the lemon complimented the fish within my pupusa like peanut butter does jelly, completing the simple masterpiece that this dish was. If you are curious about pupusas, this is the place to go. I've bookmarked it and intend on returning :)
author: Isaiah G.

description:
To me the key to a good pupusa is the curtido y this place has AMAZING curtido!!!

I always just stick with the classic cheese pupusa but they have all different types here which are great.

Tip -- this place is small and gets packed at night, yes even on a Monday or Tuesday. I always call in ahead of time and just pick them up to go :)
author: Maya-Luisa G.

description: Loved the pupusas here.  The place has an added charm because it's a small whole in the wall and everyone eating there is Hispanic.  I'm dying to go back one of these days and get some more pupusas with delicious salsa and cabbage topping;
author: Michelle F.

description: The location is in the heart of the mission, the vegetarian selection is decent. The food, in my opinion was so-so and definitely not too healthy :). I wouldn't have minded the place if the service wasn't so slow and terrible. For an extremely easy order, it took them ~45 minutes to get the food.
author: Ankit J.

description:
Balompie's a good place to go for Salvadorean food - it's also the only place I know of.  You can find the sister restaurants (Balompie Cafes #2 and #3) in SOMA and Bernal Heights, respectively.  Oh, and Balompie is the Spanish word for soccer, so expect a soccer themed decor and televised soccer games.

Food:  2 stars.  As it was my first time here, I had to try the Salvadorean Sampler (1 pupusa, 1 fried or steamed yuca, and 1 pastel).  I opted for the chicharron y queso pupusa (ground pork with cheese), steamed yuca with beef, and pastel with chicken.  The yuca (aka cassava) is a starchy root similar to potato.  While there was nothing wrong with the yuca, I found that it didn't carry that much taste, along with the grilled beef on top.  The pupusa was mealy, but the flavor of the meat was akin to what I could get from frozen microwave-able burritos.  The best of the bunch was the pastel, which is similar to an empanada.  I liked it for its crunchiness and the fact that it wasn't too flaky.  

Service:  3 stars.  When I first walked in, I wasn't sure what to do because there was no greeter or signs in clear view to tell me what to do (adding to the confusion was the line at the cash register, but no menus in sight).  I finally decided to ask a server if I could take a seat and she said to go ahead and grab a table.  Aside from the confusion at the beginning, the service met my expectations.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  Word of advice:  don't take the tables directly next to the restrooms (phew!!!).  This place feels like any other cheap restaurant in Latin America where the locals congregate to watch soccer.  Expect a loud and sometimes raucous atmosphere (on my night, a Mexican band sauntered in and performed a song for the crowd at jarring levels).

Hits:   Pollo pastel.

Misses:  Tables by the restrooms.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Balompie Cafe #2, Balompie Cafe #3.
author: Keith C.

description: This place is pupusa heaven! They had so many creative options I would have seriously tried them all if I wasn't stuffed after two! I guess that's means ill be back very soon. Also their beans are too died for as well!
author: Mitch H.

description: Not an expert on papusas, but it's a decent place. My favorite is actually the chicken stew. Really tasty!
author: Bernard F.

description: this is definitely a hidden gem in disguise! if you want a great papusa come here they have so many different choice to order! service is good too! have been coming here for over 20 years1
author: Susie C.

description:
The food was amazing.

Fun crowd, down to earth, inexpensive, and a fun place. I will definitely com back here again to fill my tummy!
author: dj z.

description:
I was browsing the reviews and have to agree on 1 thing the pupusas at this place are amazing, really delicious! as well as a few other dishes my family and I have tried.
However I do have to say even if you love the food be honest about the service. . . its a 50/50 your going to get good service.  So heads up! 

ps.  Don't get screwed into sitting at the deuce in the back under the tv their floor is sliding really bad & you will feel like your dining on a hill.
author: Erika S.

description: Delicious! I used to live SF while I was in college, and while visiting for work I met up with an old friend. She is Salvadorian, and she recommended this place! AMAZING! Those were some good pupusas! I ordered the revelta with rice and beans. My friends and I also split the fried plantains with cream. All of the food was great! I'll be back!
author: Courtney h.

description:
So much good to say.  This is how good it is, I hate stacked seating it sucks but I didn't just get past that at Balompie.  The food in Balompie is so utterly engrossing that you don't really care if a walrus is smoking a cigar and exhaling into your face while sitting beside you, or on your lap for that matter.

Really, it is one of those cup of tea things.  And, this is my taza.  

The pureed beans, the casamiento, the platanos, everything is amazing.  For me, the more I explored the more the pupusas became more of an afterthought.  It is worth exploring the entire menu for new and exciting meals.
author: e m.

description:
BEST PUPUSAS IN TOWN, HANDS DOWN! 

Their minced pork and cheese pupusas are so tasty. After one bite, I knew it was love. I loved it so much...ended up scarfing it down. You have to order a minimum order of 2 pupusas. Shoot, no problem!

Their pickled cabbage and hot sauce really went well together and the whole love affair only cost me $6.00 including a small bottle of Perrier.

I'd come back here again, service was fast, friendly and helpful. They have other specials on the menu I'd like to come back and try. 
Street parking is available!
author: Mika D.

description: Futbol! Delicious Papusas! Draft Beers!  In the Mission!  This SF native loves this place.  I will always recommend when out of town folks ask me. Great selection of Papusas.  Service folks are polite and conscientious.
author: Leilani I.

description:
W00t! so. . . I live in LA I'm surrounded by pupuseria's. Call me immature but I could never walk into a place that sold something called pupusas. This has now changed thanks to Balompie's!

For those of you who don't know what a pupusa is, imagine a corn tortilla, topped with cheese and your choice of stuffing (beef, spinach, etc.) topped with another corn tortilla, and sealed together with more corn tortilla. I guess the uncrustables pb&j is the closest gingro version of these pockets. 

Top these off with the slaw they give you in a ziploc bag, and drench the whole thing with the hot sauce they give you and you are in for a delicious, hot, and savory treat!

Great food! Hole in the wall pub atmosphere with a big screen with soccer showing. If you have never tried pupusas before, head over to Balompies! Their fresh cooked ones are well worth the wait!
author: Sparky P.

description:
Service was a bit slow but I was loving the atmosphere.

The waitresses and the patrons were really friendly (since my friend and I looked so out of place) haha asians in a salvadorean restaurant.

I totally digged the sauce, but not so much the pickled cabbage, it was a bit too salty for me, but it wasn't bad, the sauce was just exceptional, had to ask for seconds.

We ordered the Salvadorean sample platter #1 pupusa, yuca and pastel, a Loroco con Queso papusa and a cheese and pork papusa.

I have to rave about the loroco con queso papusa, which is cheese and salvadorean vegetables inside. AMAZING, it's a MUST order item.

And on the sampler the pastel was super delicious, whatever the deep fried thing was...that's a must order as well.

Loved it.
author: Zu W.

description:
Came here after a music concert at night. Night before halloween, it was cold and chilly foggy as usual. Everyone in here was watching soccer. 

I sat down with my girlfriend and friends, I had no idea what to order cause i've never eaten food like this. So I ordered the same thing my girlfriend ordered. I forgot the name, but there was a big piece of steak on it with rice on the side. The beef was unbelievable, it was so gooooood. The portions are perfect, not too much not too little.

Looking at other comments, i guess the beef is a highlight for them also. I recommend the beef plates, they are just delicious. 

The setting was very nice, service was awesome, food came at a reasonable time. Inspired me to try more food that I normally wouldn't. Now I try to tell myself, try something before disliking it... but its still hard for me but this place definitely proved my wrong. I enjoyed it here !
author: Andrew H.

description:
Great place to sit outside and grab a snack. The coffee was hot and the food was good. Service was a little slow, maybe because we were outside, maybe because we were gringos. Whuteva. I like this spot, i'll go back.

I had the skirt steak with onions. It hit the spot. I sampled the papusas, tasted savory and rich like it should. The plaintains may have been the best part of the meal though. Soft sweet and hot without being drowned in syrup. The dishes come with cabbage and a little sie of pickled veggies so take care not to over-order.
author: Zac H.

description:
Finally had a chance to come to Balompie yesterday, and I was not disappointed.

I love pupusas and could eat them all day every day.  I ordered their combo plate #1 which comes with a pupusa, yuca, and a pastel.

I chose a pork/cheese pupusas, fried yuca w/ chicarron, and the chicken pastel.  I love how they season their food just right so that the natural flavors of the main ingredients (cheese,  pork, chicken, yuca) shine through but not in a bland way.  I actually tasted pork in my pupusa, where so often at other places there is hardly any pork in it at all.

Some of the chicarron chunks were a bit overcooked/dry (-1 star) but overall the  meal was delicious, cheap, and very satisfying.  

My friend got the combo #2 which is 2 pupusas, rice and beans.  She got the spinach/cheese and I think the pork/cheese.  She loved her entire plate too.  we will be back!
author: Naoko M.

description: Delicious food and good service. We had the pork pupusa, chile relleno. The fried fish is simply superb. And the final bill will be a surprise...
author: Philip T.

description: We didn't feel like cooking tonight so we decided to tryout this place since its literally 5 mins away from the apt. Good choice and great price too! We had the espinica y queso, super vegetariana and Mexicana y queso pupusas. Very good! I didn't think that was enough so also ordered the Bistec Salvadoreño, however I think if we had ordered another pupusas we would have been fine with that. The bistec was eh but it did come with rice and beans and a salad. The dipping sauce plus the pickely lettuce/cabbage thing was delicious and that came with the pupusas. Will def want to come here again and try some more :)
author: Tina D.

description:
Balompié, you make my knees buckle. While my Salvadorean mother demands pupusas to be a bit oily, I prefer Balompié's style of pupusa which aren't as greasy as other places. The bean and cheese is my favorite, as are their other traditional dishes - platanos con crema, empanadas con frijol o con leche, tamal de elote. yum yum YUM!  And Blue Moon on tap!! 
Docking them a star because of the super slow service. They are very very friendly, but aren't aware when you're trying to catch their attention. It can take a while to get your check in this place so either plan ahead, have cash and ask for your bill right when you get your food, or just relax and have another beer.
author: Lisa Marie G.

description: This is the go to place for PUPUSA! And if you don't know what that is yet, you simply gotta go! They are well done, and seems like they prepare after you put the orders in as it seems like you can modify what to be put in there. I love it. Definitely get the combination with cheese in there no matter what you choose to go for. And the place is like a hole in a wall kinda place, but it is right for the kind of food it serve, it reminded me of my travels in latin america. Definteily visit it.
author: Fung S. O.

description:
So recently I have been on this pupusa kick and I'm on a mission to find the best in town.  Word on the street is Balompie, El Zocalo, and La Santaneca are where it's at.

Wut wut you say...prosciutto pupusa?!?!  Hell to the yeah I was all over that.   I also ordered the loroco con queso and a horchata to wash it down with.     

Personally, I prefer my pupusas to have a slightly more firm and crisp texture.  These were slightly doughy for my liking.  I thought the prosciutto was really good but could have used more prosciutto.   Loroco was good too but nothing really just knocked my socks off.  

I wasn't crazy about the pricing as well.  As someone else noted, these run a dollar more than most places.

Final verdict: decent pupusas but it just did not live up to the hype.  Off to El Zocalo and La Santaneca I go!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Inexpensive, tasty Salvadoran cuisine

FOOD:
Pupusas - 2 for $5
   1 Loroco y Queso
   1 Espinaca y Queso
The pupusas were flat and filled with delicious melted cheese and our chosen toppings of the Salvadoran vegetable loroco and spinach, respectively. It was mostly cheese, but very tasty...and greasy. Don't come here if you're on a diet. The chopped pieces of loroco were chewy and had a tea-like taste reminiscent of artichoke. The outside of the pupusas were lightly golden to perfection. 

Plantains
~$5
Big plate - half filled with chucks of sliced plantains, other half with sour cream. We didn't use much sour cream. The plantains by themselves were delicious. Nice and crispy on the outside, warm and soft on the inside. Fairly greasy for those health-conscious folks.

AMBIANCE: Causal-divey, nothing fancy place. Jukebox by the door. Always showing soccer on the TV, which fits its name well. I learned that balompie means football aka soccer in Spanish. The area around the bathroom is smelly.

SERVICE: Fine

VISIT DETAILS: Quick dinner
author: C L.

description:
My abuellita (that's grandma in Spanish) was born in Mexico.  Her pop was half Italian.  Her maiden name was Filipini.  My dad's sister married a straight up Italian dude.   So at our family gatherings - the tables groaned with mounds of delicious food. . .tamales, fragrant in their corn husks; cauldrons of pozole rojo or menudo blanco, refried beans, rice; hot, steamy corn tortillas and a big giant dish of baked rigatoni or a nice braciole.  Wait.  What?   Yup - it was like that old Sesame Street segment of "one of these does not belong with the others" but we were all happy and ate everything with equal gusto - baked rig in a corn tortilla is a taste sensation you might not experience everyday, you know.

Now, I am not sure what went down at Balompie - perhaps one of the ladies who makes the pupusas hooked up with a Guido but man oh man .. SOMEONE invented one of the most delicious taste sensations of all time.  A pupusa filled with prosciutto, cheese and a few leaves of basil.  It is called the Italiana and it is absolutely delicious.  I do not sully the flavor with the curtido. . I eat it straight.  I like to order some to go and have them for breakfast the next day - an Italiana with a couple of over-easy eggs is just about the best thing EVER!

Go here.  get this.  I'd never steer you wrong.
author: Lainie L.

description:
1st pupusa evar. man - so goood. 

had the mushroom spinach and cheese. jesus christ was it good. a bit greasy and heavy, but really hit the spot. and super cheap, like 2-3$ each depending on ifyou get the specialty ones or not. 

The ambiance inside is classic, true whole in the wall, family owned place. Beer on tap and in a bottle also.
author: David N.

description:
Wow, the pupusas are amazing! I had the chicarron y queso (pork and cheese) pupusas when I was there TWICE this past weekend. It's soooo delicious.  Put the cabbage salad on it and the salsa on it and voila!

Sadly, the salsa wasn't spicy at all so I had to ask for some Tapatio.  I also had the enchiladas but they weren't anything special.  Seems like they use the same tomato-based salsa on everything. I will only come back for the pupusas. :)
author: Hwan L.

description: Phenomenal. Every person I bring here agrees it is simply delicious.
author: Sara D.

description:
There's a place in Oakland, Lupita's, that have great pupusas.  But my BF and I stumbled across this place one afternoon and I remembered a friend of mine telling me how great this place was.  

We went in and ordered pupusas, fried yuca and chicharron, and some fried plantains.  Everything was sooooooo delicious.  Fried yuca was amazing and I usually don't like yuca in general, but it was amazing.  The horchata is to die for, just try it, you'll understand if you've had horchata elsewhere, and then try it here.... you'll never want to drink horchata from anywhere else.  

This place is busy, and that's expected because the food is great and a lot of people know that it's great. And specifically referring to another yelper's comment about mistreatment due to race or whatever,  YOU ARE WRONG!  Just because you don't get sides AND not ask for them because you forgot, that's your fault and they were probably just busy, so you should have asked for them.  I'm far from being Latina and I've always had great service every time I've gone there.  It's a small establishment with great food and service is good for how packed it gets, so deal with it. 

Again, this place is highly recommended. :)
author: May L.

description:
Only stayed in the Bay Area for a week - and not even in San Francisco - but this place was so good that we had to go twice.

Everything was tasty and fresh, the service was prompt and friendly, and the soccer memorabilia gave it a distinctive character. I recommend the papusas, of course. There are some great vegetarian options here. Oh, and it's a great value: a filling dinner + tip for just under 10 dollars.
author: Ben S.

description: I use www.trycaviar.com, and decided 2 get some pupusas from Balompie Cafe a week ago.  This was the best choice I've ever made when it came to pupusas!...They delivered them hot, cheesy, and the most delicious pupusas I've ever had!...They hooked me and my diet!!..I've since ordered 3 times in one week, it's going to be the 4th time today!!!..lol...I would HIGHLY recommend Balompie cafe if you're ever in SF, and want to try the BEST pupusas n the City!!!!!...#OneSatisfiedCustomer...keep it up Balompie!
author: maxine m.

description:
I can't believe that I passed by this place almost every day for a couple of months and only went there for the first time last week.  I have been missing out hard core. 

The pupusas here are SO GOOD.  And they are super cheap (cheaper if you get them to go). The chorizo was so good and I loved the spicy cole slaw that came with them.  It made me think of kimchi and anything that does that generally makes me happy.  It was delicious. 

We got our pupusas to go, but I would love to come back to sit in and eat.  I liked all the soccer gear (even if they did have a Juve scarf up).  

My one complaint about Balompie was that the people there were unnecessarily grouchy with me. I'm not sure what we did to warrant that.
author: Alea G.

description: Really good salvadorian food.  I had chicken enchiladas which were excellent and the popusas looked awesome.  Added benefit is that it is good for your spanish as nearly everyone esta hablando español.
author: rahul c.

description: This place is absolutely AMAZING. I love latin american food and this is at the top of my list of all places I have eaten at anywhere in the U.S. The fish filet in the tomato sauce is a perfect blend of flavor with fresh cooked fish. Delicious. Also recommend the Pupusas! The salsa that they give is also fresh and really tasty. I am saving this place as a top favorite for San Francisco.
author: Elizabeth V.

description:
I came here seeking pupusas. Actually I came here to get my first pupusas ever! Did I like it? I'll say for my first pupusas, it's pretty good. I've no other benchmarks so I can't quite comment on it.

However I would DEFINITELY return for some horchatas. Handsdown the best horchatas I ever had (which doesn't say much) but it's really addicting. Got one more horchata to go after my meal! It's not as watered down as some of the ones I've had. It's honestly tasty and REFRESHING.

I also had my first yuca and it's really good. The waitress described it as tasting like deep fried potatoes but I've to say it's better than that. It's not as starchy as potatoes. If I had it my way, I would replace potatoes with yuca's. Yes, that means I would have a side of Yucas with my burger. 

The deep fried plantains were pretty good too. I like that it's semi caramelized from all the natural sugars that oozes out, but it's not overwhelming sweet. Which makes it an acceptable maincourse meal for the sweet-tooths out there. 

The bottom line is that I'll definitely return here for my horchata and yuca fix.
author: Jun Kang C.

description: SO WORTH HITTING 5 LAPS AROUND THE RESTAURANT LOOKING FOR PARKING! Yes, it was THAT GOOD. We stood out like sore thumbs, but thats how you know the food is LEGIT. Pupusas came out piping hot! Cheesy goodness. Pickled cabbage, carrots and jalapeños were the perfect accompaniment. I also had grilled shrimp that were perfectly cooked. Even the beans had that special something something that had me savoring every last bit. I'm being stingy with the last star because the salsa was just OK. Actually, the food is so good that the salsa wasn't even necessary.
author: Isabel N.

description: Bombest pupusa joint in SF. There are a lot of pupuserias in the city but this by far is the best. They don't use hella dough like other spots do, and they aren't greasy neither.
author: Bryan C.

description: This place Sucks! It took forever to get a papusa which in this case was a glorified quesodilla. The service was horrendous, and took forever to receive the food.
author: Jared D.

description:
I've walked by this place so many times but never thought to drop in..I love pupusas, and whenever I crave pupusas I go to Panchitas on 16th and Valencia...but now I will go here. 

This place is clean, the service is fast (or faster than panchitas), cheap and the food is yum!
author: nancy b.

description:
I'm starting to do the 7x7 100 best eats in SF and was craving for pupusas. Lucky me I found this place on the list! I've been eating pupusas since I was little and honestly these didn't hit home for me. I ordered the pork pupusa and wasn't satisfied with the meat. 

ehh..

I didn't feel happy or disappointed, but rather content when I left.
author: Tina T.

description:
Actually, my rating is more like 4.5 stars, due to the fact that these pupusas were crazy delicious.  They're accompanied by this coleslaw-like lettuce mixture (vinegary, spicy, sweet, moist and generally super tasty).  We basically poured the entire mix on top of the pupusas, and my friends and I downed them like madmen.

I often disagree with 7x7's List of things to eat in SF, but discovering Balompie redeemed the List in my eyes.  There's a fifteen minute wait for the pupusas if you get them to go (you have to buy two at a time, but they're so good and cheap that you'd probably want to buy at least two.  Or four.  Or maybe twelve.  Who knows.  I know I keep wanting to come back!).  We got the chorizo and pork pupusas, if I remember correctly.  But I have a sneaking suspicion that they're ALL going to taste awesome.

(See some pictures: http://pineapplebread.wordpress.com/2010/05/25/the-list-an-8-restaurant-marathon-through-the-mission/)
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
We came here after a super long wait at Hog and Rocks, and it may have been the best meal ever.  They were fast, nice, and served us copious amounts of great food and beer.  It literally saved the day.

I recommend the combo plate of shredded beef and chile relleno--it's ridiculous.
author: david m.

description: Incredible meal. Platos tipicos 1. The bean pupusas was mind blowing. $15 with a blue moon. Crazy good, will definitely come back.
author: Johann R.

description: Food is great but need to improve the customer service and wait time if you're hungry you better order over the phone otherwise get ready for wait at Least 30mins. Or 40mins.....
author: Hermes L.

description:
The pupusas are the best I've had in in SF.  I really dig everything about this place, but the pupusas are fantastic.  My one knock on this place is the service.  The staff is friendly, but not terribly speedy/aware.  My table has been completely forgotten twice.  Still, this place is a total winner, and I'll definitely be back.

Price: 5 stars (the prices are very reasonable, especially for the pupusas)
Food: 5 stars (I haven't been super impressed by the non-pupusa items.  Nothing has been bad, but the pupusas are the pick of the litter by far)
Ambiance: 5 stars (it's usually a little crowded and loud, but it's clean and has a great family feel.  Typically the place is almost full [if not overflowing] with families out for a meal and a little futbol on the tv)
Service: 3 stars (as I said above.  The staff is friendly and respectful, but...could use some work)

We'll be going back here again and again.
author: Thomas K.

description:
I probably never would have come across this place were it not for a friend who led me here.

Why did he choose this place? The papusas.

This place can be summarized with: good and cheap.  3 guys each had two filling papusas for about $17.  

I had the spinach & cheese and bean papusas.   I liked them both, but will have to give the first one my preference.  

The service was nice enough and the place is small, but well-kept.
author: Charles R.

description: Food was good. Service was good. Get the pupusas - but ask them to go easy on the cheese. We ordered one chorizo and one ground beef pupusa - and it was hard to taste the meat over the overpowering cheese. The bean pupusa was great though. Place isn't very spicy.
author: Saquib P.

description:
maybe i don't have the affinity to Salvadoran food or my taste buds were whack the day we had lunch here, but i was not impressed by the food and feel crestfallen that i chose this place amongst all the other places we could have gone in the Mission District.

i had the orchata drink, the yuca frita (fried yuca) con pescaditos (anchovies fried) with the side of empanadas con frijol (fried plantains filled with beans).  the yuca entree was okay, the drink was gritty, and the plantains filled with the refried beans made me almost heave.  i was disappointed, since i've had Salvadoran food before and it was tasty.  my only reprieve from the nausea was the futból game they were showing on the tv.
author: Liz Z.

description:
This place is fantastic and I really enjoyed myself. It's really small but very cozy and you can tell that it is a local favorite. They have a full bar and pretty large wine selection and play old futbol games on all the tvs. I went with a few friends and we shared a very long table with other guests who suggested the pupusas to us. Let me tell you about these pupusas..they are so delicious. I had two pupusas, one with a cheese and spinach and another with cheese and meat. It's really inexpensive, the pupusas are about $3.00 each and you must order a minimum of two. Their beans and rice were also really really good. 

This place was great but the only problem was the parking. It's right off of Mission and it's in a very busy area so we ended up having to park a few blocks up the street but it was worth it. It was clean, our waitress was friendly and the food was fantastic. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Denise S.

description:
I should probably stop reading reviews before eating somewhere. After reading the raves, I was very excited for this place. End result: hm. $2.50 for usual pupusas, $3.50 for special ones.  They were tasty and a decent size. Yet I wish I knew before sitting down that the pupusas are $1.99 if you order them to-go. I taste with my wallet, okay? Also, make sure they charge you correctly.  If you feel like arguing over a buck (I'm too wimpy to), you're welcome to. 

Very popular place, so you may need to wait for a table and/or share a table with strangers. They got points with A by seating us across from rather than next to each other. A normal tv by the front door and a huge flat screen inside that plays football/soccer games. So, very noisy as people will cheer and jeer for teams. At breaks in the game, expect a guitar player to come in and play very loudly. Definitely lively.
author: Yan E.

description: Best pupusas I've tasted in a long while!  Thanks to my friend's birthday, they decided to have pupusas that evening.  I'm in love!  They ordered tons of pupusas in variety of flavors.  I loved them all!  Their cabbage slaw is very delicious (I'm usually not a fan of slaw).  Their yucca fries was good but I've tasted better (hence the 4 stars).  Chicharrón too was great!  It's not the normal crunchy chicharrón you see in the stores cause it's very meaty but it was still great!  It actually reminded me of Lechon Kawali.  Oh sooo bad but soooo yummy good!  =)
author: Fran F.

description:
This place is fantastic!  As it stands, Balompie is my favorite Salvadoran restaurant in the bay area.  Their pupusas are perfect, the yuca delicious, the platanos (plantains) are flawless, and the casamiento (mixed beans & rice side dish) launched me back to my childhood summers in El Salvador!  Literally... I needed a moment.

The prices are very reasonable... I remember when pupusas were like a buck a piece and now they are more than double.  But I can't really complain about spending $2-something on such a filling meal.  

The only thing that could use improvement is the service.  I have never had stellar service and the wait time for my order has always been rather long.  The quality of the food more than makes up for it.  I just know to go prepared for a wait!
author: Debbie S.

description:
OH MMMMM. MMMM.  I'm still buzzing from the high I got off eating such tasty, quality food.  I'm basing this off the point that I've NEVER had Salvadorian food before and so opted to try something new with a friend of mine.  We took about 20 minutes to decide what we wanted because before this day, "PAPUSAS" was just a funny looking word.  

Granted it was a little intimidating to be the only two Asian girls walking into a restaurant that felt like a portal to another country, but hey--our minds were set on good food.  

After the waitress explained (tried to) what a papusa was, we ordered a couple of the pork+cheese ones.  We also got fried plaintains, a combo plate with mint and beef, pork stuffed bell pepper, as well as one of the morning scramble plates.  nomNOM!!!!!!  I guess would describe the papusa as...a stuffed..pancake?  Whatever it was, it was good, super filling and I'd definitely return again.

Oh yah, the waitress was super nice!  We didn't know how the horchata would taste there so she gave us a sampling for free!  

Good service, good food, good prices.  (total was 34, including tax and tip)  5 stars no doubt.
author: Tokki M.

description:
And then there were pupusas!

How had I not discovered this place after a year of working on 18th street?  I bought two delicious cheese papusas, one with black beans and the other with zucchini for 5 bucks and it's only 4 if you get them to go.  They're like little pancakes/crepes filled with happy goodness.  The servers are really nice and the dining experience is pretty decent.  One of my favorite cheap eats!
author: Elena S.

description:
This is a great little place with a cozy neighborhood cafe feel.   The service is great, the people are genuinely nice and friendly.  

It's become our go-to place for take-out now - the pupusas are great - filling and flavorful!  Two pupusas for $5 and you're set for the night.  We also ordered a whole bunch once and brought them home for a group of hungry friends that dropped by after a long hike - they were such a hit!  

If you're vegetarian like me I highly recommend the  Queso y Frijoles and the Super Vegetariana.  Yum!
author: Divya S.

description: I love refried beans and Balompie's refried beans are the best!!!! Lardy and creamy. I love the huevos rancheros breakfast....fried eggs with red sauce with refried beans.
author: Wakako U.

description: This place is authentic. I'm Salvadorean, born and raised, and I can tell you that their pupusas taste as good as the ones in El Salvador. I've lived here for 14 years and searched high and low for the perfect pupusas, and I have yet to find a place that can match Balompié. I recommend trying beans-and-cheese pupusas and revueltas (or mixed) which come with beans, cheese, and pork. And you must accompany them with enough curtido (pickled cabbage) and salsa. For a true experience, try eating them with your hands. Make sure to finish your meal with some empanadas de leche (mashed plantains filled with custard, rolled into a ball and fried). They have great Salvadorean horchata (made with pumpkin seeds instead of rice) as well as great hot chocolate. You really can't go wrong with this place. If you're still not sure what to order, ask your server to recommend items, their staff is very friendly and helpful.
author: Dina S.

description:
Hah, I'm such a Gringo.... I wrote this review for the wrong restaurant!

On the invite of a recommendation of a friend, a bunch of us took the BART out from Mission and 2nd to have some papusas. The bunch of us who took BART were a little late and we had to wait outside for tables. An apparent usual who was standing outside waiting for a to-go order, had told us that the only real papusas on their menu were the first part, not the specialty ones.

Following that advice, we ordered all our food. It took a little while, but when it finally came out we were chowing down. For a big guy like me, two of them filled me up just right... and while I could have gone for bite #3, I'm actually TRYING to watch my diet.

5 stars. I love the spot. They were showing Live Bundesliga playing, plus the service is excellent. Come here for the Papusas. Order 2 first, and work from there.
author: Michael C.

description: The pupusas here are the bomb!! As are the planatos fritos y crema! Come here for some authentic salvadorean food!!!
author: Joaquin G.

description: I had the Pork jalapeno and cheese pupusa and it was amazing! The service wasnt amazing, but if you want really good pupusas come here!
author: Tyler L.

description:
Super-crisp fried yucca!

almost caramelized ripe platanos

Yumm. 

My friend had the steak encembellado and was so happy ...
author: gar l.

description:
These are the best Papusas I've had in San Francisco.  I like the friendly neighborhood feel of this restaurant.  We sat at a long communal table next to a family from El Salvador that had driven all the way from San Jose for this food.

The corn pies were good and these were the best beans I think I've ever eaten.  The Yuca was a little bland for my taste.

Worthy of the 7x7 list:  Yes
author: foodiewithadrawl S.

description:
This is probably one of the most highly touted places around town for pupusas, and I've only had pupusas once before at Panchitas. 

We tried 3 pupusas - lorroco; cheese, pork, jalapeno; cheese & shrimp. They were fine, but slightly doughy, and not crispy like I remember at Panchitas, and I also liked their pickled red cabbage slaw better. 

We also shared two other dishes that raise the rating to 4 stars:
Lengua with onions - Awesome, very beefy, tender, with nicely cooked onions, and a delicious sauce.

Fried yucca with chicharon - Very tasty, the yucca had a texture similar to tater tots. Chicharon was nice and porky, with plenty of good pork fat throughout.

Service was really good, very friendly with good recommendations.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Came into town from Santa Barbara to visit friends and was amazed to find this place!  We had 5 people so decided to share 8 pupusas, 2 soups, an order of plantains and horchata.  

If your friend socal like us, you might be surprised by the flavor of the horchata which is not as sweet and has a hint of cacao.  Still it was delicious and hit the spot after walking around town all day.  The plantains where well caramelized making them crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside.

The main complaint we had ( along with other reviewers) is that the wait was so long.  The pupusas (bean and cheese, chorizo, vegetarian, italiana, shrimp)  was really good with the cabbage on top, even the bean and cheese which some of us thought would be bland but nooOOOO so good *chomp chomp* .

If you are with others you should definitely share a soup which is great for a cold night.  Our crew got a shrimp soup and a chicken soup to share. The Shrimp soup was as good as it looked! The egg inside was to die for, you could taste all the flavors in the soup soak into the yoke! At first chicken soup didn't look special. But a single sip was enough to be blown away!!  It tasted like chicken noodle soup, but with a boost of flavor!
author: RockLily S.

description:
I was disappointed. The pupusas were fine but not nearly the best I've had. Lots of cheese, not much of the veggie goodies ...the three I ordered all kinda tasted the same. Beers were cheap and waitresses were very nice though.

We didn't get any meat pupusas though, so maybe those are better.
author: Josh B.

description:
First time to Balompie for breakfast. I had the platanos dish with casamiento and a pupusa (the veggie one)
The coffee was really good for just regular drio cafe. The platanos were fried perfectly and with the crema they were delish. The casamiento (rice and refried beans together) is different from what I call casamiento, but it was still very good. 
I will forgive them that they forgot to take our order for about 15 mins and then they forgot our water, but that's OK.
I had enough food to take home and finish it later.
Overall, very friendly place and really delish food. Go there, go often...
author: Cristina R.

description:
Other than parking and the crowds this place is pretty cool!
Came in and got some pupusas (queso con frijoles, espinaca y queso and crema) they were all good, the toppings were great. Also got cantaloupe juice and horchata. Friendly servers, good prices, live music (though they pester you for tips) not too much of a wait either.
SUPER TASTY!
author: J A M.

description: Loroco con queso pupusa is so good. I love how they give you such a generous amount of the pickled cabbage condiment to eat with it.
author: Claire b.
