description: Had brunch here yesterday.  Good, solid, fresh food.  Their horchata I think is the best in the city, not too sweet and very fresh and tasty.  Try their breakfast specials.  Lots of people were eating the Menudo but I'm not that adventurous..  The cheese pupusas were great as well.
author: Mitch A.

description:
i finally busted my papusa cherry. eating your first papusas at balompie is loosely akin to losing your virginity to irinia shayk. here's what i LOVED about balompie, in order of deleciousness:

1- best fried yucca i've ever had.
2- best cole slaw i've ever had.
3- rice and beans
4- best (if only) papusas i've ever had. we ordered shrimp and cheese and veggie.
5- papusa sauce

can't wait to go back to this packed papusa paradise!
author: Brett W.

description:
balompie continues to be my go-to pupusa joint. the pupusas are cheap & some of the best i've ever had. i usually get the loroco con queso & a chiccharon y queso, which fills me up for like 5 bones, uh hell yeah. they're crispy on the outside, juicy & cheesy on the inside. the big bonus is their cabbage slaw, which i mound in exorbitant quantities on top of my pupusas, along with their sauce. it's addictive. we usually ask for extra upfront, which they're cool about.

i brought my family here for lunch when they came up to visit last year for their first salvadorean food experience & they loved it! for one, the kids could just share a couple of pupusas instead of wasting a ton of food. plus, they've got a big table across the center of the restaurant communal-style, so if it's not too crowded, you could accommodate a fairly large group. drama-free & didn't feel bad to have the 'rents pay since it's so reasonably priced.

i haven't explored much else besides the pupusas there. there are more traditional entrees on their menu, but i'm usually there for lunch & on a budg. i did make the mistake once of ordering a rice flour pupusa, which was sort of chewy & dry. they don't normally come in those, but you can request it. i'd recommend not doing that.
author: jacqi k.

description:
Solid food, awesome friendly and efficient staff, and a very nice, cozy authentic atmosphere. And if you're a soccer fan, then it's a plus because balompie means soccer and there's always a game playing on their tv here! 

That's Balompie for you. My inner fatty in the past few days is going overboard wanting to try as many different places as I can. So I've been channeling that by picking places that are a bargain. And wow, is this place a bargain! 

My roommate and I decided to basically try all that they're known for. So we two combination plates that combined 3 types of pupusas, plaintains, yuca, pastel, arroz, and frijoles with orders of an orchata and cantaloupe juice. What is a pupusa you ask? Good question. Wikipedia says, "A pupusa is a traditional Salvadoran dish made of thick, hand-made corn tortilla that is usually filled with a blend of cheese, cooked pork meat ground to a paste consistency, refried beans , or queso con loroco (loroco is a vine flower bud from Central America). I left the last parenthetical because we had no idea what loroco was. Now we do. Yay wikipedia!

Pupusas are kind of like arepas. Except they do taste slightly different. Balompie makes them fresh and you can really taste the cheese. The toppings were the vegetables we ordered in the pupusa (our order for pupusas were the loroco y queso, pescado y queso, and the super vegetariana). My favorite was the super vegetariana - simply because of the fillings. But really all are incredibly tasty and at about $3 bucks a pop for a pupusa, you're in for a treat! On to the yuca - ah fried goodness. I could eat these all day long. So crunch, tasty, and perfectly seasoned. Loved it. The plaintains were soft, chewy, and not overly sweet. Absolutely perfect. The orchata required a little getting used to as I am not an immediate fan of really sweet drinks. But it grew on me. And for those who don't know what an orchata is - made from morro seeds, not rice. Other common ingredients include ground cocoa, cinnamon, sesame seeds, nutmeg, tigernuts and vanilla. Finally the cantaloupe juice was good, slightly watered down, but still good.

Finally, the service is great. You can hear mostly spanish at this place but they can tell who's new and who can't speak spanish pretty accurately. And the service accommodates that very well. 

And the final bill for all that food?! $28 with tip. Boom. I'm a happy happy girl. Thank you Balompie. You've got a repeat customer!
author: Aditi R.

description: this was the first time trying salvadorian food. and it was for a class project. omg i love it! Britany C. recommend this place to me. and i love it.  my friends and i ordered the pupusas it was so good. i had the salvadorian veggie pupusa it was so good!i have no idea what type of veggy was in it but it was good! i also had this melon drink which was also good. but parking around this area is hard! if you have a mini cooper it's easy if you don't be prepared to circle around and around and around for parking. the waitress was nice, she knew it was our first time there and she taught us how to eat a pupusa. you have to put the chopped up veggie on top of the pupsua and put the red sauce over it.  or you can stuff it in the pupusa. overall i love this place. just parking is a pain.  well  it's sf after all right?
author: Belinda C.

description:
Do you LOVE pupusas? Then maybe we can get married, because pupusas are a permanent part of my life.

Even though I had a *meh* experience at #3 on Mission, I decided to give 18th street a try based on all these great reviews. 

Well, the place was bumping on a Thursday evening. Packed. I felt like I was in a very authentic restaurant based on the clientele.

The menu...lots of options...the prices about $2.50 a pupusa, which is a $1 more than those deliciously perfect meat-bean-cheese pupusas at La Santeca in Bernal...

My order: melon juice (refreshing and delicious), a shrimp and cheese pupusa, and the super vegetariano. Everything was fine...but not WOW. 

We were STARVING, but the food came out s.l.o.w.l.y.

My bill was about $12, which just seems too high for 2 pupusas.
author: Misha F.

description:
This was my first time eating Salvadorian food and what an introduction!  
I am in love with the fried plantains. Absolutely head over heels. 
The pupusas were not only affordable and filling, but they were very good!  I had to be tutored on the preparation, but after everything was said and done, I believe I put down my fair share.
I was told this is the best place to go and I can see why.  If it's your first time to this type of cuisine, then go here.  The ladies are very understanding and will explain everything to you, if you don't have the tutors that I had.  Good times and affordable food :)
author: Hannah B.

description:
I had a big breakfast of papusas and beans and rice yesterday on the recommendation of a good friend. 

Are papusas about to blow up and become the next taco or crepe? I think papusas could surpass all other snacky foods in the next couple of years, and Balompie may very well be leading the charge.

The service was fast, friendly (and hot.)
author: Jason R.

description:
The pupusa's are delicious! Not as good as my mother-in-laws but definitely a contendor.  Perfectly porportioned and very flavorful.  I ordered the "lorroco y queso" and "espinaca y queso."  Both, I would reccomend.  My bf ordered chicarron y queso which were good too.

My husband ordered the steak and chorizo plate.  He said it was good too but I wouldn't recommend if its your first time or if your not salvadorean.  He is, so he enjoyed the salvadorean chorizo.  I'm not a fan.  I like my soyrizo, and I'm Mexican!

We also ordered the platano fritos (fried bannana) with beans and sour creme. I DO NOT RECOMMEND this dish.  The bannana's were very dry and not flavorful at all.  The beans were very bland too.  If you love you some platano frito, I WOULD RECOMMEND cha cha cha's.  The have a very good dish.

Overall, our experience was good and we will be coming back once I crave pupusa's again.
author: Mandy R.

description: I felt as though was in El Salvador. Lots of Latinos enjoying breakfast. Good music. Weak coffee. I preferred the corn flour pupusa. The rice flour pupusa was bland and chewy. Bean and loroca, a native plant of El Salvador pupusa was yum. I would have liked more loroca,...served with a watery salsa...did not care for the side of cabbage that comes with it. I would go back to Balompie for breakfast and maybe skip the pupusa. Great service, considering how crowded it was.
author: Bleep S.

description: I never write a review unless it's really good or really bad. And this one is bad! We like the pupusas at Balonpie. This review is for the Balonpie on Mission St cross street Richland. This weekend we called in our order to pick up the food. We got the food and once we were home we noticed we were missing food. We called and  Lissette said that they had forgotten an order,it was there. So we had to drive back and when we were there she was very rude,upset,and arrogant. This was Lissette. She should be grateful she has a job and we weren't rude. I don't think I'll go there again. La Santaneca is a couple of feet away I'll go there from now on :(
author: Laura Z.

description:
Ehh, it was okay.  The Yelp reviews definitely over-hyped it, but Yelpers are damn good at that.

The pupusas, though very cheesy and fresh, were undercooked for what they are. Mine were white and golden brown, but the griddle marks on pupusas should be a lot darker ... I wanted my burnt leaked cheese-bit!

I was also disappointed that they didn't have pupusas revueltas, which contain a mixture of beans, cheese, and chicharron.

On the bright side, they have Salvadorian beer (Regia), which is always tasty and can creep up on you if you're not careful. But maybe if you drink enough, you can drown out all the clamor -- I couldn't even hear my boyfriend from across our two-person table without shouting.

The pupusas here are good, but you can easily find more authentic pupusas around 24th & Mission. Even if you don't know Spanish, the universal "point and pronounce poorly" trick should do.
author: Maria M.

description:
My Salvadorean friend swears that Balompie is hands-down the best place in SF to get papusas, and while I am no papusa expert, I must say that Balompie's papusas are prepared to cheesy perfection! Wash them down with a refreshing pineapple drink, and you'll be dreaming of this meal for weeks to come...

On a side note, I had been warned that the service at Balompie leaves much to be desired, but upon arriving at 11 a.m. on a Sunday, I had no difficulty being seated and my food came out right away. I left with a (very) full tummy, and absolutely no complaints!
author: Leslie F.

description: You can't beat the value for money, the food is well presented and fresh and definitely moreish! And at that price you can have as many as you want and still not break the bank.
author: Bryn I.

description:
Balompie is first on my list of pupuserias -- they're filled with lots of cheese but are surprisingly non-greasy (although I would never consider them to be "light").

I ordered a combo plate that also included steamed yucca (you can get fried, too) with steak and a pastele (l'il fried chicken pie).  The pastele was a little dry (next time I'll get the pork one), but the yucca w/ steak was just excellent -- perfect texture and a great complement to the pupusa.   

With an extra pupusa, the damage for this gut-busting meal was $13, including tax and 20% tip.  Read: major deal.  

The only downside was that there was a party of 12-15 people that seemed to slow down the kitchen's coping skills, so it took a while to get our food.  But hey, it was a Saturday night, I was off the clock, and I'll definitely return (saving room for plantains this time).
author: Steve K.

description:
I'm all about finding my new Happy Places (tm) these days.  Balompie is my new Happy Food Place (tm).  A friend recommended it for brunch this morning, and DAMN was she right.

We got there at 11:30 and the place was packed.  There was a soccer game on TV, tons of people chugging their Coronas and eating yummy egg/bean/meat/cheese dishes.  We waited about 30 minutes for a table, which isn't too bad for a Sunday brunch at that time.

Upon sitting, we ordered up some beers and coffees and got to the menu.  My friends come here a LOT and are apparently very familiar with both the menu and the staff, so they settled on food pretty quickly.  I took some more time, but when I saw two of my favorite crack-like foods on the menu (platanos & pupusas), I was set.  My friends all got egg dishes with beans, rice & tortillas.  Yum.

One of my favorite parts is the variety of breakfast foods.  Many places have a limited scope, and often it's hard to avoid wheat at breakfast.  I'm discovering the joys of Central & South American food for breakfast.  Balompie makes it easy to stick to the non-gluten foods if you, like me, have a dysfunctional digestive system.

Food is hearty and was enough for 2 meals for me.  Oh, and CHEAP.  About $40 for 4 people with some drinks.  Niiiiice.  I was stuffed in the best way possible, and a little tipsy from drinking 2 beers before my food came.  I nap now.  Mmm.

One odd part was the agua fresca of the day.  Nobody at my table ordered it, probably because it was the color of Pepto-Bismol.  When we left one of my friends asked what the drink was.  Apparently, one can make a bright pink drink out of barley.  Huh.  Who knew?
author: Polly Enmity P.

description:
I have to agree with Jonathan about this place.  I was taken there by a Salvadorian friend who pronounced the pupusas authentic.  They were far less greasy than the others that I've had, too.  

Quality pupusas with a large variety of ingredients.  They make them to order and grill instead of fry them.  If you don't know what a pupusa is, I suggest you ask them.  They'll serve you one for a steep price of 1.60 or so and you can learn for yourself.

Oh, they're friendly there, too.
author: ben y.

description:
This is a great place to get pupusas. Someone from my past introduced me to this place for brunching, but now I'm hooked on my own. 

The rest of the menu items are decent, not the highest end ingredients, but I've never been too disappointed. I'd stick to the pupusas and you can't go wrong. The coffee cups could be a little bigger though.

And the price... oh so affordable. I always leave with a full belly and still semi full wallet.
author: Ali K.

description:
Pupusas so good they make me want to start apartment hunting on Capp Street! 

I ordered the pupusa, yucca, and pastel combo. Go for the traditional pork when you order your pupusa. I haven't tried any of the others, and I doubt I ever will. The opportunity cost is too high.

Excellent service to boot.
author: Raoul D.

description:
mmmm pupusas! 

my boss introduced me to this gem on 18th and Capp and boy amd i glad she did. you know its authentic El Salvadorian food when your El Salvadorian boss takes you there, and you go in and you're the only Asian person in there. 

Bar, tvs with soccer playing and happy people eating food and drinking their fresco del dia. you gotta order the fried yucca, the beans with fresh crema, cheese and plantains and of course, pupusas! cheese or cheese and pork. if you order the ones with shrimp, my boss says, "um, that's American style," with the shaking head.

thumbs up: fresh juice of the day! pupusas! friendly service!
thumbs down: LONG wait if you don't come early ... so for lunch, be there by 11:30 AM.
author: Lauren Y.

description: the best bistek & prawns, friendly staff
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Solid Salvadorean Food, fun atmosphere with lots of group tables and cute kids. Watch futbul and get hyped for 2010!!
 The waitresses aren't really that attentive, but in this atmosphere, I don't really mind. They were busy.  
The food is yummy and has a homey feel, but if that means hair slips out of the kitchen and onto your plate they need to step up the quality control a little!  
The breakfast plates were all good looking, the tortillas are delicious. Lunch has been yummy, too.
I want to go back sometime and bust out the tunes on that jukebox by the bathrooms!
author: Melissa B.

description:
I enjoyed Balompie with  my family of four.
I search out local favorite spots that are locally owned
Crowded and friendly Balompie is smoke free 
Service on this night was outstanding
The tasty  flank steak, rice and beans  we're my choice.
Beer is available. I did not partake.
Portions were adequate and no desert was ordered.
Place is clean, local.
Noise level OK this night
Cost for 4 adults about $48
author: j t.

description: It's been awhile since my last visit and I've begun to realize that one can't really go wrong with Balompie Cafe. The pupusas are delicious and cheap, the horchata is fresh, the atmosphere is comfortable, and the service is good. For a great cheap date, I recommend it.
author: Jimmy L.

description: Best pupusas on the market. Add some beans, and you are set! They make their pupusas extra chessy, their beans extra delicious, and quick service. I love their empanadas de pollo too!
author: Claudia L.

description:
This review is coming from someone who doesn't know much about pupusas, other than the fact that I love them. 

I went here with a friend on my lunch break and ordered a bean and cheese and zuchini and cheese papusa. Both were really good and came to our table within 10 minutes of us ordering.  So delicious. The cabbage stuff they give you to put on top as well as the hot sauce really made them stand out from some other's I've had at other restaurants.

Definitely somewhere to stop by for lunch if you're into Papusas like myself.
author: Isaac W.

description: The pupusas are amazing! Great lil hole-in-the-wall
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Its hardly worth writing, its already obvious....this place rocks.

Here's my fave:

Desayuno plato (frijoles, queso, crema, patanos)
Pupusas on the side (whatever flavor you feel like)

Heaven.
author: Nancy R.

description:
Absolutely delicious.  A little slow as service goes and it's a bit chaotic once you are in doors, but the food is ace.  Maybe that's why the pupusa's are a little bit cheaper if you order to go.  

While I've had pupusa's before, I've never had Loroco (as a filling or otherwise), and I'm definitely glad to have tried this here.  Also, I never had plantains with cream, and that is definitely a good mix.

I look forward to coming back.
author: daniel m.

description:
I think they are the best PUPUSAS in the city ...
took my mom and she was amazed also..
fat and non-greasy.. filled with with good yummy stuff!!
author: Aldo V.

description: Although I was not that impressed with the pupusas, they were good for their price.  My problem with it is that it is heavily dominated with cheese and not enough filling.  The pupusa bread itself is good and the salsa that comes with it definitely enhances it.  Definitely worth my $3.50/2 pupusas but I wouldn't expect to be blown away.
author: Derrick C.

description:
The actual score is probably closer to 3 and a half stars, but they're so nice, I'm willing to give them a bump. Price/performance here is hard to beat - the pupusas are the signature, but the rest of their food is great too. 

The enchiladas in particular are great, as well as their lemon breaded chicken. If you're in the neighborhood, definitely give it a spin. Breakfast is good also.
author: Jay N.

description:
Delicious pupusas for chump change ($1.50, and so big I challenge you to finish three). Friendly staff and fast service. Melon agua was pretty good. Definitely worth stopping by for a cheap and filling dinner.

Note: eating pupusas before exercising is not a good idea. They will sit in your stomach like a rock. (But that's your own damn fault, not Balompie's.)
author: Andrew H.

description:
Yeah, definitely the best pupusas in San Francisco, and I was on a sojourn to discover the best; finally found it.

2 pork and cheese papusas with a coke, coming with a bunch of flavorful green stuff and mild sauce (wish it was spicier) for only 5 bucks?  You got to be kidding me.

I don't care about the price, I care about the flavor, and this place, in my opinion, is hands down the best for pupusas.
author: Timotheus C.

description:
My Salvadorean roommate took me here for my birthday since I've been wanting to try Salvadorean food.  So good. 

I had salpicon. My roommate ordered chicharon and yuca and two pupusas. 

I think I broke my stomach trying to get all that food in. It was so good, I didn't want to stop eating. I'm not a huge fan of thick breads but the thick tortillas here were so good, I was eating them with a little of the spicy sauce on top. 

All that deliciousness with a Blue Moon draft (done right with an orange slice) made me a very happy birthday girl.

Coming back to try the breakfast.
author: Mona M.

description: Boy are the papusas delicious and filling!  I didn't love the orchata, but the papusas (must order at least 2 for $2.50 each) more than made up for it.  I am definitely coming back if I cross through the Mission again.
author: Michelle M.

description: I ditto all the reviews saying how filling these little guys are. I shoulda read them more in depth before we ordered. The hubbs and I got a few different pupusas along with the plantains, cole slaw, rice, beans, yuccas and pastels. Whoa - way too much food! But even all that stuff was a little less than $15 per person - cheap! I would stick with 2 pupusas (their minimum order) or 1 pupusas w/ rice n beans per person. I liked the beef and cheese one best, but go figure its the 'gringa' (white girl) pupusa so i guess they know what they're talking about. This is my first Salvadorian food experience and it was a good one. We'll be back for more.
author: Audrey V.

description:
I take it this place is salvadorian since its main dish is pupusas, but they have a vibe of other latin  countries mixed in. 

Don't bother waiting to be seated because there isn't a hostess, instead dive right in on the long family style table that fits 20! At first this was awkward, because our group of four went to sit down next to this couple presumably on a date, since that was the only space available. Now the girl, sensing that four guys were about to intrude on her space, immediately got up and moved down which I was fine with because honestly they ended up being very loud talkers. What I wasn't fine with or more so distracted by was the obnoxious group sitting next to us on the other side who wanted to inquire about much of our orders from the moment  they sat down. One guy went so far as to point on multiple occasions with his excessively long arms at our plates, beer, and wanted to inquire about much of it until he got a clue we weren't gonna pay him any attention. The guy clearly was in left field when he asked if the beer was tea. 

Pupusas were amazing, best I've ever had. Rice and Beans well I've seen better. The plate didn't have as much flair as some of the other entrees that my friends got, but I believe the pupusas won out on taste alone. Fish pupusas were delightful. Prosciutto and sausage pupusas were amazing and had far better flavor to them. Horchata was good and sweet, but had a stronger hint of chocolate then it should have had. Beer well what can I say, 32oz house special is unspeakable. Portions overall are slightly smaller then a typical hispanic restaurant which can leave you wavering for more, but with still reasonable prices

The place was a lil hot and humid and on a chilly SF evening you'll end up taking your layers off. It is well decorated with a strong latin feel and probably a good place to watch futbol with the one TV blairing the local countries game. 

The pupusas were the point of the trip and well worth a trip back for.
author: Mikey B.

description:
My brother and I just scarfed down cheese and bean pupusas with lots of salsa from Balompie... hello heaven in the form of Salvadorian food.

Long wait but handmade and well worth it!
author: Mairead J.

description:
when I first suggested to hubby that we go to Balompie he was like "Capp and 18th? No freakin' way!" I sometimes forget that he grew up in the Mission and doesn't see the area merely as a hipster haven but has earmarked certain intersections to avoid from childhood memories. But one sunday night we were desperate for papusas and La Palma had already closed, so off we went to Balompie. Whatever reservations hubby might've had about the place before, he's led us back there three times in the last week.  

The tables down the center of the room are set up as one long row, so you're basically seated elbows to knees with other diners. Hearing your neighbors' conversations can get annoying, but the food is so good as to distract you from anything else. People have already rightly raved about the papusas so I"m going to rave about their garlic chicken. It is so good. You get a nice piece of boneless chicken breast smothered in a creamy yellow sauce. You also get a side of rice and beans fried together. You get enough to share, but believe me, you won't want to!
author: Kara P.

description:
Went here with a friend because she had heard that the papusas were really good--best in town. We went for lunch. Looks like a hole-in-the wall from outside. Actually fairly nice and clean inside. 

We tried several things and shared--Chicharros y Queso (Ground Pork & Cheese) papusa, Super Vegetariana (Spinach, Mushroom, Carrots & Cheese) papusa, Fried Yuca (Chicken) and Shrimp Pastel. We also ordered the plantains--the waitress said that they were really sweet that day. 

My favorites were the papusas. I don't think I had ever tried them before. They were made with corn flour and were filled. They weren't greasy and very flavorful. The Pastel was good as well. Not so excited with the Yuca but it wasn't how the restaurant cooked them. The plantains were also delicious. 

Overall we were happy with our meal. The food is very inexpensive, fresh and good. The service was also very good. The waitress was very friendly and helpful. I'd go back there again. They have so many interesting other things to try.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I give it 5-stars cause I'm Salvadorian (note, a learning opportunity. We are not El Salvadorians, just Salvadorians. Go on, use it. Impress your friends!) and this food is as close to the real thing as I've ever had. It's awesome! I can just imagine the little stout women in the back and their embroidered aprons, smacking pupusas (kinda like stuffed tortillas but way better) between their hands and smiling with silver moons on their front teeth (it's a Salvadorian thing--means you be ballin').

If you go here, you're totally safe with the usual Mexican fare but I dare you to try something you've never had before. One of my favorites--probably cause I've never had it anywhere else in the country--is the "Pan con Chumpe" which is basically the Salvadorian take on the French dip except it's roast turkey and the dipping sauce is ON HIT!!! 

They have creative pupusas as well so grub on those. Things are yummy here so knock yourself out!
author: Mario T.

description:
We checked this place out before our nearby "Killing My Lobster" show, and it did not disappoint!  While my friend thought the guacamole (or Guaca-Glow, as my dad calls it) was kind of watered down, I thought the added lime juice made it numma numma fresh.  Our waitress was extremely nice and efficient.
I ordered a few vegetable pupusas and topped 'em with the pureed salsa/sauce and they were pretty much amazing.  
I am an average girl and 2 pupusas was plenty enough for me!  Of course, I also tapped into the guacamole and some plantains, so . . . 
Affordable, fresh, and tasty--worth checking out!
author: Lacy T.

description: Not the cleanest and sometimes the friendliest place around. This is the place to be if one really likes Pupusa or any other Salvadorian food. And this is the place to be if one like soccer. Plenty of soccer fans..
author: M C.

description:
Great place to eat a Latin American style breakfast. If they served freshly cut papaya I would be in heaven. 

Highlights:

The fried plantains and pupusas! 

Lowlights:

I swear, the rice they use is Uncle Ben's. Sitting is limited, be prepared for the place to be crowded.

Ramdom obnoxious bitchy comments:

It is pupusas, ladies and gents. Not "pApusas" nor a "Papoosa" - you are not going to strap it to your back and place a little Native American child inside. Repeat after me... Pupu - yes... PUPUsa.  

Also, it is BaloNpie. NOT BaloMpie, the vampire slayer. It comes from the Spanish "Balon", meaning  "Ball" and "Pie", meaning "foot", translated to "Football Cafe" since this cafe appeals to football fans. Soccer for you Americans. If you get the time to review, take the time to spell correctly. OK? Carry on......
author: Raul A.

description:
Directions for a perfect breakfast:

1. Go to Balompie.
2. Order pupusas, platanos, huevos and anything con crema. Say, "Yes, I'd like tortillas, thank you."
3. Sit. Patiently observe the clientèle, catch an awesome futbol goal on the screen, drink 2 cups of coffee.
4. Continue to be patient, knowing it will be worth it.
5. Savor the deliciousness once it arrives. Save room for tortillas.
6. Tip generously, remembering than anywhere else breakfast this amazing would have cost you through the nose.

Love the Balompie. Thank you Balompie.
author: Sheryl L.

description: If you're looking for a place to watch the soccer game and love the sport, you need to come here. Great food and music selection. I had the ham and cheese sandwich and the ham was cooked perfectly. Husband had puposas which were good as well, even though it needed some toppings in my opinion. The guacamole is lemony and fresh which I loved. A good find in the mission. Not mind blowing but tasty.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high when I walked in...but I walked out with a 3 star Yelp rating in my head. Here's why:

1. The El Savadorean place out by El Rio is MUCH better. Fresher, tastier....

2. The waitress was really nice and the place felt like it was family run which was cool - but that didn't change my feelings about the food.

3. It's in a hmmm-it's-getting-kinda-scurry area without really being in a scary area...but still you know.

Bottom line, go somewhere else despite the hype. Maybe I should've just tried something else besides the pupusas.
author: Deann M.

description:
Best pupusas ever! Actually it's the only thing I order there. If you love pupusas this is the place to go. 

The service isn't that greatest, but the price and the taste is perfect.
author: Monica S.

description:
Such good value for money and very tasty!  Worst thing I can say is that it can get busy, in the day time especially, but the food is well worth it.  Pupusas are just wonderful!  My favourite is the Mejicana y Queso (pork, jalaenos & cheese) but they are all pretty good.  I agree they can get a bit cheesey after more than one.  Sides are fresh.  I thought the thyme in the salad adds an interesting dimention of flavour too.  Empanadas are not necessarily bad but not very empanada-like at all and quite squishy.

Put it this way, I always leave planning my next return whihc is a pretty good sign.
author: Stacey H.

description:
Excellent pupusas here... I've tried them all, and they're full of flavor and not overly greasy.  The sweet corn tamales are also a winner.  And for the price, this place can't be beat.  

The only downside we encountered was with the slow service.  At lunchtime, it took about 10 minutes to have our order taken and another 25 before we got our food.  Granted, they were busy, but certainly a restaurant should know how to manage its service a bit better.
author: Laura K.

description:
I think this place is the bomb.com! 

I went here with a group of 5 people and were seated at the long table in the center alongside two families. I kept sneaking glances at what the table next to me was eating and was salivating over everything I saw. I had a really difficult time picking out something to eat because everything I saw looked really good. I ended up being adventurous and trying the beef tongue dish even though I'd never really had beef tongue.  It was surprisingly really good, and the tongue was very tender!  I had a bite of my friends papusas and they were quite tasty, and not greasy.  I am looking forward to coming back very soon.
author: Jade L.

description:
Great Place. A local favorite for sure.
That Sunday at lunch, my friend and I were probably the 2 only non Salvadorian guys in the restaurant. It is a real experience.

It's a small place. Food was great, the staff friendly and it wasn't expensive.
I will come back.
author: Marc L.

description:
What a find!

It's a hidden little place that serves Salvadorean food with a funky restaurant name - the owner is, to say the least, a futbol fan.

Anyways, the food hits the spot.  We had the fried yucca with chicken (who wants french fries when yucca is SO much better?), plantains, and plenty of pupusas.  Everything was extremely tasty, very filling, and not particularly greasy.  Mind you, it's still comfort food, so budget some time for a siesta if you're going to finish your plate.

Definitely worth the trip!
author: Linda C.

description: This is my pupusa spot! Love this joint. I usually get the pupusa plate, which comes with two pupusas of your choice, rice, and refried beans. You get your little bowls of cortido and hot sauce on the side and then proceed to go to town. It's delicious. I love the atmosphere too. It's a family restaurant and the crowd is always a great mix of folks, young and old. The waitstaff is so friendly and welcoming, especially if you have questions about the menu. Balompie is just a warm and friendly place. I wish I could crawl inside a pupusa and eat my way out.
author: Peter S.

description: I'd give them a 4.5 if I could.  I had 3 different types of pupusas (pork and cheese, spinach, and el salvadorian vegetables).  They were all greasy and good though it was pickled cabbage and spicey carrots that added a great touch.  I also had a side of fried plantains with sour cream.  The food is quality and comforting and the atmosphere is friendly and inviting.  Also, I'm not much for sports on tv while I'm eating.  I might not return but I'd recommend it to a friend looking for good pupusas.
author: Natalie Y.

description: Cheap and delicious. Pupusas and fried yucca all the way. Also, they take credit cards!
author: Anton S.

description:
Brought friends here 3 times, and everyone's always satisfied. 

Finding new papusas to like each time, top 3:
Chorizo and Cheese 
Super Vegetarian
Shrimp and Cheese

Heard mixed reviews of the Mixed Beans and Cheese, 1 friend found it dry and kinda eh, another liked it.

Always happy with the plantains.
A side order is good to share amongst 4, it's 1 plantain per side and cut up into about 8-10 pieces ($3.75). The breakfast plantain plate is 1 plantain with beans, cheese and sour cream for dipping - for double the price of the side ($7.75).

A lot of people order the Horchata, typically a milk and cinnamon drink. I think Balompie adds a little bit of chocolate and my friend described it well as "Mexican Ovaltine" which is still good, a little different from other Horchata.
author: Jocie M.

description:
got the: Pupusa, Yuca, Pastel salvadorean sampler - a little bit of everything and it was ALL good. 

I remember the papusas being a round thing oozing of cheesy goodness. The yuca fries were the best I've ever had. Just the right amount of crispiness. 

I will be back for sure!
author: Cat T.

description:
Very simple and authentic look. 

I went there for a Sunday brunch in the Mission. Lovely atmosphere, the Latino culture meets the American one for brunch. And good food on the table.

The best touch was a friendly soccer game going on the big screen: Hamburg Juventus 3-0 . I was actually almost getting into a fight with my girlfriend so that I can watch it...Too bad I found out later it was a game from exactly one year ago.
author: Sergio D.

description:
Who needs the Red Hook Ball fields when you live near Balompie.  A charming little corner restaurant, you may be serenaded by a mirachi band if you come on the weekend.  Chill with the Latin American soccer aficionados and order some mouth watering papusas.  Mix it up!  Remember that the Loroco Flower has aphrodisiac properties, so you must get at least one of those.  

A real, down home place I never would have tried did I not live so close.  I'm not sure what the cheese is in the papusas either, but it is crack-like in its deliciousness.
author: Gibson V.

description:
From the moment I walked into Balompie, I was hooked. Their pupusas are literally OFF THE HOOK! Not too greasy and and a good proper size. The meal they have that includes 2 of them with rice and beans is a perfect portion to get your pupusa fix. 

I must admit my favorite entree is the Plato Tipico which is comparable to a sampler plate that includes a pupusa, a pastel and Yuca con Chicharron (fried chunks of pork). Although if you get this plate you have to get the fried yuca as it's AWESOME! Just imagine a french fry only bigger and made with yuca, lol! Seriously though you'll love it! After I tried this plate I had dreams about it - no lie!
author: Yolee R.

description:
This has become my new favorite place to get pupusas whenever I am in San Francisco. 

My favorite is loroco, that flower delicacy, but there's so many other tempting varieties on their menu that I always end up taking home extras.
author: alejandro p.

description:
Whenever I have friends or family visiting the Bay Area, I bring or send them here--it was my virgin Salvadoran-food experience and set the standard by which I measure all pupusas.  Plus it's chock-full of folks from older men to scampering kids to young couples strolling in for some mom-'n'-pop-style food.

I usually go for the ever-popular plato tipico #1: a pupusa revuelta; yuca frita topped by tender, juicy pieces of chicken; and a pastel de pollo, all crisp on the outside and soft and steamy inside.  For breakfast it's all about desayuno #2: casamiento (a marriage of rice and mashed beans all fried up together), huevo, queso, y crema, with fresh pan on the side.  I love the crunchy/creamy textures and the fact that it feels like down-to-earth, straightforward, just-plain-good home cooking.  And the chan!  It's made of dragon-fruit juice and is off the menu, red as cherry Kool-Aid yet much, much subtler in flavor, with tiny, pomegranate-like seeds you can suck up like boba.  

I like to come on weekend mornings when lots of families are out for breakfast, but morning or evening, the ambience is friendly and as down-to-earth as the food.  And I love their salsa music selection especially!  It plays in the background while soccer plays on the TVs.

A waitress once informed a friend and me that 'balompie' is, if I understood correctly, colloquial/Salvadoran Spanish for 'soccer'--a nod to the owners' love of the sport.
author: Trina E.

description:
THE BOMB pupusas. 

Damn, I am craving one right now.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Balompie Cafe, by far, has the best pupusas I've had. I've only had their pupusas. Even neighbors go there for pupusas. But their menu has a lot to offer for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Their regular pupusas are few cents less than other places. This includes the chicken pupusas which others do not carry. Balompie Cafe even has specialty pupusas like shrimp, fish, spinach, ground beef and prosciutto!! The only pupuseria that offers this on the menu. And I like their spicey cabbage than most other places. Finely shredded, great flavor.

I know they've been around for years. They take the crown for S.F. pupuserias!!
author: Roger S.

description: I was here today for breakfast w mom. I love coming here for their pupusas, service will be good depending what time of the day you come in.    I've waited up to 1 hr for my food On a busy day.  today was kinda fucked up, I ordered breakfast eggs casamiento, crema and tamal...w a hot cup of coffee. Sat against the wall mom was lecturing me about how much salt I was putting on my eggs when OH SHIT!!!  A roach crawled right by my head. The guy sitting Behind me whisked it away with his hand.  Where did it go?  Too busy looking down the floor when mom said, another one! On the rim of your creamer!  WTF!?   Another little fucker creeping out the edge of the table.  Where is my waitress????? Oh! She's too busy flirting with a guy in the front....ok let me try the other lady.....can I get different creamer a different table and an explanation??? what the hell is up with all the critters?  I'm so sorry we just fumigated..... wOW!!!  Didn't want to make a bid deal infront  of people at the premises. But it was a big disappointment ....needless to say I will not be going back to this spot anymore.  Food is great but cleanliness should be #1
author: Claudia E.

description:
I've been wanting to try a good pupusa since my first taste of one at a street fest last year. The one I had at the street fest was decent, but sorta greasy. 

I arrived at Balompie around 5pm on Saturday. The place was humming and nearly full, but I managed to snag a small table for myself up front. Ordered a housemade Pineapple juice and three pupusas: bean & cheese, chicharron & cheese, and chorizo & cheese. The bean and chicharron one were 2 for $5 or so I believe. The chorizo one was listed under the special pupusas category and cost more at $3.50. 

I waited patiently and finally my server brought out three small dishes with pickled cabbage, pickled veggies and hot sauce. Next arrived my plate of three pupusas. They looked amazing, sorta like thick pancakes, with some nice golden brown spots on em. All three were delicious, but my favorite was definitely the chorizo & cheese. Second favorite was the chicharron & cheese. I definitely could have just eaten two of these, but I wanted to try a few, so I stuffed myself. 

The pickled veggies were tastey, but could possibly use a bit more zip. The hot sauce was good, yet unimpressive, but it didn't matter as the pupusas were delicious enough on their own.
author: Brian J.

description:
A friend had introduced us to Salvadorian food up in Cameron Park and we have been hooked onto finding a place that could satisfy our cravings for the pupusas and soups in the bay area.  Obviously the Mission is where all the good eats are at.  

I've been wanting to try El Zocalo's for a while now, but a friend suggested coming here and I was more than happy to try it! 

We ordered an array of dishes including the pupusas/ res soup combo, fried yuca, the shrimp soup and.....more pupusas. Yummmmmmyy....... It was all really good. Suprisingly the kiddies liked the pupusas here (They aren't the biggest fans of corn tortillas).  So, I'd say that it had a texture that was soft enough for them to enjoy without it being too chewy.  And,  my husband enjoyed the slaw that comes with it.  We left super full but wanting more.
author: Angela K.

description: Go there for the fried plantains! I always struggle to find good restaurants that serve up fried plantains / plantainos maduros. Balompie is a winner just for serving that up - I usually just call in a takeout order which is ready for pickup in a few minutes!
author: Sunil K.

description: Yummy papusas, fried yuca, and their beef is to die for! Great prices toooo. We'll definitely be back. =)
author: Jasmine W.

description: Golden fried goodness.  The no. 1 combo platter is a variety of fried specialties: crispy yucca topped with tiny fried fish (you could also get shrimp, chicken, or beef), a pastelo (triangle shaped also with your choice of protein) and a pupusa (also with your choice of filling). Expect to leave with greasy lips.
author: Vanessa H.

description: I was trying to fit in as many food stops as possible one day on my bike ride so I only got to try two papusas, the pork & cheese and beans & cheese. Maybe I went too over the top with the choices since although I love cheese, I didn't feel like it went very well with the papusa. The ground pork was of an unexpected texture and consistency that wasn't the most appealing, but not bad. All in all, I think I need to keep in simple in my next visit as I'm 99% sure I will be throughly satisfied with a simple papusa with beans.
author: Peter M.

description: all of the positive yelp reviews are definitely true, your eyes and our reviews aren't deceiving you. i too had the greatest pupusa i've ever had here. i had one spinach and cheese pupusa and was really disappointed in myself for not having ordered more. now i know better. i also ordered the empanada de leche and to be honest i'm not sure if i liked it but then again maybe i was just mad about not having ordered another pupusa. the establishment is incredibly warm and friendly. as you're sitting there are people from one table are talking to those at another table, people are gossiping, and talking about how their days went. i loved it, it felt like everyone was family. the workers are all really great too, really talkative and super helpful.
author: Carla L.

description: The mixtures inside the papusas were thin and under-stated, but the wandering mariachis made up for it.
author: Rich R.

description:
I would still go to Panchitas first (just for the spinach + cheese pupusa) but Balompie's comes in at a close second. The pupusas were ... fluffy and delicious. Minus one star for having to stick my lunch date (hi christina r.!) at the end of a long table of people celebrating a birthday. We done crashed their party! 

Oh, make sure to order take out if you don't want to smell like fried food all day ...
author: Joyce S.

description:
Everything in this places is awesome. Not only their pupusas are extra excellent, they have the Best Hot Chocolate!! It's has a touch a cinnamon, perfect size, not to hot, not cold either; just perfect. 

Try casamiento rice...soooo good!
author: Shellar G.

description:
Its one of those places where all the locals go regularly and I can see why. Its a small hole in the wall place that serves pretty authentic Salvadorian food. There are so many good things to choose from its a good thing its not expensive We came with a party of 4 and had to wait a while on a Sunday morning but that is typical for anyplace I suppose.  Everyone in there seems to know everyone else, oh but low and behold in walks in one of my dads old teammates, so I guess that makes us part of the cool crowd now.  It has like a sports (soccer) bar/restaurant feel and I love it!! Not fancy shmancy...just gets down to the point! For breakfast order the platanos, or the pupusas crap just get both you will love them.

PS if you can, order in Spanish so you gain extra points with the server and she doesn't think you are just some kinda groupie...ha!
author: Andee V.

description: Two fresh out of the pan meat and cheese pupusas, crisp marinated carrot/cauliflower/onion/jalapeno salad, slaw and salsa all for under $6? This place can't be beat for pupusas and always delivers. I loves me some Balompie!
author: Ronnie S.

description:
I had pupusas for the first time!  A friend of mine lives down the block from this place and we were looking for a good warm meal on a rainy day for a girls night in with a movie...so she suggested pupusas.

We ordered 8 to go (3 different kinds: bean & cheese, veggie, and shredded pork...i think).  the meat one was my favorite.  But can i just say 8 was ambitious.  I had 2 and was STUFFED.  Pretty good for under $2/each
author: Kelly K.

description:
Pupusas de loroco - delicioso!! 
Yuca con chicharron - buenicima!
Aguas frescas - tan ricas!

One of my favorite spots for cheap eats and rebroadcast soccer in the City. Great for veggies and adventurous carnivores alike, good for families but not kid overrun, friendly staff, and almost never a wait for a table.
author: Josh C.

description: Some amazing pupusas.... And order with hot chocolate... Its the traditional way to eat them.... Its nice to kick back and watch a soccer game and have some good food...
author: Yesenia C.

description:
One of my coworkers (sorry guys, I don't remember which one of you it was, you all look the same to me, JUST KIDDING HA HA but seriously) put it best when she said, "I think Balompie is the kind of place where you just have to realize it's going to take forever." 

Let me add to that "...and where you have to ask for the check, and ask to have it returned, and ask for extra water, and maybe ask the gossiping waitresses where your food is after you've been waiting 20 minutes, not to mention that two members of your party ordered SOUP, which you assume is probably in a big vat in the back and doesn't require much preparation and the other two ordered a pupusa and plantains and a breakfast plate, which should have taken about five, maybe seven minutes, tops."

I was the breakfast orderer, because I'm frequently of the opinion that if you can order breakfast outside of normal breakfast hours, you should. My beans, crema, queso, and egg were okay, nothing special. Worth the $7 I didn't pay because my boss did (thanks Katina!).

The sad thing is that even as I sit here typing this not-so-favorable review, I know I'll probably be back as soon as the weather gets foggy and cold. It's good comfort food, I'll give it that.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
Delicious pupusas for breakfast yesterday.  One cheese and one with cheese and chicken.  A side of rice.

The pupusas were served pretty quickly, but were made to order, a rare combination in the world of pupusas.  Served with sauce and curtido (cabbage).  Hot and delicious, oozing cheese.  Filling yet I was tempted to order another.    

Prices are very reasonable.  I think the pupusas were $2.25 each.  Half the price of an "import" beer at lots of bars.

Pupusas are available for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  I dare you to eat pupusas for all 3 meals in one day!
author: Aaron T.

description:
Maybe I'm not a fan of pupusas, but I wasn't too impressed.  Tried the cheese and special fish pupusas - they came out piping hot with a refreshing side of pickled vegetables.  However, the amount of fish was very meager and the whole affair was greasy and heavy while not being tasty enough to offset the guilt.

Nice chill authentic atmosphere complete with football on the tube.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Is it me, or does "pupusa" sound kind of dirty? 

I felt kind of naughty ordering these hot little numbers, and a whole lot more naughty eating them. Fresh off the griddle, they're filled with cheese, vegetables, beans, etc. and you basically put your head down and slurp them up until there is nothing left. They come with vinegary pickled cabbage and a dish of delicious hot sauce on the side. 

And they're cheap, just the way I like my naughty snacks.
author: Angie R.

description: The food is awesome and cheap! Lunch for 4 and 6 pupusas to take home for the parentals- all under 50 bucks!!  Are you joking me?? Homerun!! My mom is from El Salvador and she loves the food..
author: scott m.

description: Had 3 pupusas here, was recommended by 7x7's "must eat" list. Had the veggie, ground pork, and spicy pork with jalapeno. Veggie was hands down the blandest, and the pork was alright, but the spicy pork with jalapeno was the most flavorful. All three were very cheesy, and were comparable to a quesadilla or arepa but less flavorful. First time having pupusas, so not sure how these lived up. They came with a red salsa and a spicy slaw which didn't exactly complement the pupusas but were still pretty good. Waitress was super nice and answered all our questions and gave great suggestions.
author: Sasha H.

description: The pupusas here were amazing, I got cheese and bean and cheese, and the service was good too. Very friendly people here, and the place itself is very clean. I'll definitely be going back here
author: Wo W.

description: Just had my first papusa at Balompie.  Blew my mind.
author: chad H.

description:
What is a pupusa?  Well, if you haven't had one before or don't know what it is, come here and try it.  Some good stuff for sure.  Love the cheesiness and love the sourness of the shredded cabbage that comes along with it.  These flavors may not be for everyone but if you've tried it at least once and figure out that it's not your thing, they have a lot of other tasty items.  Their seafood soup is also very good but you do have to know, their pupusas are their signature item.  

Go here, order some food, order some beers and watch some soccer.  Definitely a cultural experience here as well with the soccer games on and all the passionate fans that follow it.  And some great food to boot.....
author: Mark W.

description: if you don't mind waiting for super fresh food, this place is worth the wait. plus there is soooo much food with each order! enough for two meals.
author: Nicole O.

description:
Holy pupusas!  One word: Loroco.  Go get 'em!  

The slaw they make to go with these is incredible.  The salsa is good, not spicy, though, so minus one star for having to use Tapatio with my salsa.  Also, this is one of the only places I've found in the Bay Area that makes fried yuca the right way.  Yum!  I like mine plain, no toppings, but they have all kinds of other things you can top it with.

Also a bonus, this place is way affordable.
author: G R.

description:
it's the best of both worlds.  those worlds being
1. 
2.
 
Fill in the blanks man!
author: Rachel S.

description: I had 2 pupusas for lunch! Tasty. Friendly service. Will definitely come back to try more pupusas and other dishes.
author: Mark W.

description: Big, plump, delicious pupusas, friendly service, great neighborhoody ambiance. Perfection.
author: Sara M.

description: Balompie is the ONLY place I go to when I'm craving pupusas. These are made-to-order masa shaped like pancakes stuffed with combinations of melted cheese, beans, meats and then griddled. I usually order beans and cheese and beans and chicharron (shredded fried pork). Generally, on it's own, pupusas are quite dry. Top it with curtido (sour and spicy cabbage slaw) and it is magic! I especially love how they make their curtido at Balompie.  If you love pupusas, this is definitely the go to place!
author: Anna K.

description:
I discovered pupusas a year ago and subsequently went on the Great Pupusa Quest of 2006.  Balompie was my first stop, and it's still the best, outshining the other places that I tried.  I especially like the pork & beans pupusa and the shrimp w/zucchini pupusa, both when slathered with curtido.  And so amazingly cheap - less than $2 per pupusa, and I get full off 3.  My friends also recommend the plantains.  Not a big fan of the tamale, but the corn pie was good, too.

The first time I went, I learned that everything is made with olive oil which explains the lack of greasiness.  Love it, a must try for all.  Tons of selection and variety; something for everyone.
author: Melinda C.

description:
The food here was really good, although the other person I was with, we didn't try much.. Just pollo tamales, and carne deshilachada.
Cheap, busy and friendly.. but I will try to go back again soon.

Looked like a very good spot to go for pupusa's.
author: j d.

description:
Not too familiar with Salvadorian food, I walked into Balompie Cafe expecting to be able to order a few tacos, chalupas, gordidas, and maybe throw in some nachos; you know something similar to what you find on the taco bell menu.  However, the food choices at Balompie were actually very different from your average Mexican taqueria.  In fact, after consulting a map, I learned that El Salvador is not even part of Mexico.

OK so I knew beforehand that El Salvador wasn't part of Mexico and to expect a different menu than the taco bell drive thru but I had no idea what to expect in the meal.  I just added the word "pupusa" to my food ordering vocabulary a few months ago but that's about it.

If you have never tried Salvadorian food, I would highly recommend Balompie Cafe.  Try the sample plate that comes with a pupusa, pastelito, and yucca frita.  It was delicious and we also ordered a side of plantanos.  It's great food at a reasonable price.
author: Josh K.

description: I never had Salvadorean food before coming here and thanks to this place, I have a craving for pupusas at least 1x/week. Thank you Eva and Marvin! This place can get pretty packed, so expect to a wait around lunch time. They have so many different kinds of pupusas, try the shrimp ones. The pork and cheese are my fave. I'm hungry...time to go to Balompie.
author: Mary C.

description:
-love the different pupusas
-breakfast is yummy too
-order take-out
-can be busy on sundays after everyone gets out of church
-if you're patient, you can have as many as 12 people seated at one time
author: Rob N.

description: We've been eating here for a few years now, and the food is consistently good & cheap. Best pupusas in the Mission, IMO. I love their breakfasts with casamiento (rice mixed in with refried red beans). Also nice is the homemade pickled jalapeno/cauliflower/carrot garnish. I gotta have a side of that spicy, crunchy goodness with every meal. Just be sure to avoid the church crowd after 10am on Sundays or you will be waiting a while for a table. And you can't mind sharing a banquet-style table with other parties, either as space is severely limited here. Not recommended to bring snobby visitors as they will be unimpressed by the cramped space. Most importantly, if you are craving some good Salvadoran food, Balompie is the place to go.
author: Jen M.

description: If you are a fan of papusas or soccer, this place is it.  You need to make sure you eat the strange yet delicious coleslaw.
author: Nick B.

description: Balompie! how have I not yelped you yet? Balompie has the best pupusas in San Francisco (and i would know, I'm Salvadorean!). They are delicious and cheap. The place gets packed sometimes, but I've never waited more than 20 minutes. I always get the revuelta pupusas, which are cheese and pork. There's always soccer on, or some smooth salvadorean tunes playing. So go!
author: Sandi V.

description:
Went here for lunch today.  Took a long time to get our food - place was rather busy, so not a big deal for that.  Food was made fresh, pupusa's were soft.  But... Not a whole lot of flavor, to be honest.  I dunno, maybe I'm too used to really spicy food from Naan N' Curry and the Mexican food places in the area - this was a bit bland for my taste.

I liked it, don't really know much about El Salvadorian food, so I can't comment on the authenticity of it.  I won't go out of my way to go back though - too many places with tastes that make my buds sing to have bland-ish kinda food...

Before I left my home, of course I Yelped up on Balompie and I noticed that there were no pictures of the place, so I uploaded some for your viewing pleasure...
author: Jon B.

description:
Awesome, awesome, awesome pupusas!  The encurtido served with it is mediocre, but the overall quality and authenticity of the pupusas is excellent.

The shrimp cocktail I had was alright, the shrimp wasn't as fresh as it probably should have been, but I'm still alive to tell about it at least.

The atmosphere is a good one, busy, but not too loud.  And every once in a while you'll get some mariachi trios stepping in and playing for donations.

Be sure to get some beans & rice with your meal.  The red beans tasted just like the ones I came to love while I lived in Guatemala, and hadn't had since.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
"God this doesnt look like what we ordered, it looks like breakfast.."
"Oh you want the Special 3 and 7, not #3 and #7, okay, no problem."
And ten minutes later they arrived. I suspect they may have done the dishes "authentically" but I was a little overwhelmed by the heaviness of all the cornflour and pork, and a little underwhelmed by the flavors. Certainly a lively Mission crowd, plenty of soccer screens, pleasant waitresses, but not for me.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
I had never had Salvadoran food  and tried this place on a whim, with someone who had been here before. I have to say, Balompie is one of my new favorite places. I am hooked.

The food was delicious. I had the "famous" pupusas plate that comes with 2 pupusas, rice and beans. So good! They kind of reminded me of the Johnnycakes I had in Belize. Unfortunately no one here knows what Johnnycakes are, but its a pretty close resemblance, visually and taste wise. I also tried the pasteles with chicken (corn pies filled with meat). Those were good too. 

We came in on a Friday night with a party five. It took a minute for us to get seated and the food wasn't delivered to the table with lightening speed, but it was well worth the wait. Really good service. The servers are very nice and answer all of your questions about the menu. They have really good suggestions if you have no idea what to order.

It's the Mission so parking can be a pain in the ass. 

I can't wait to come back!
author: Kathleen N.

description:
With the constant talk of Pupusas from a friend, we sought out Balompie on a warm Friday night. The atmosphere was jovial, with soccer on all the TVs and an eclectic crowd. Mariachi even came to play later in the evening.

The food was rather filling and on the starch-heavy side of the food pyramid. Salvadorean tortillas are probably 5 times as thick as a Mexican tortilla and half the size. Nevertheless, the Pupusas were tastey: fluffy and cheesey. We also had Yuca, which sounds exotic but simply tastes like potatoes.

Overall, Balompie feels like a good lunch spot (dinner: not so much). It is certainly the spot for Pupusas.
author: Tim B.

description: PAPUSAS!!! It was my first time eating papusas and I'm so glad I experienced such a delightful experience at Balompie!!! The papusas were huge, fat, round, and savory. I love how the cheese oozed out while I cut the papusa with my fork. I ordered ground beef and cheese and chicken and cheese which were both a delight. I can't wait to try the ones without meat. The staff was warm and friendly which is definitely a plus. The place is small enough to make me feel at home and cozy yet it wasn't too small to make me feel claustrophobic.
author: Anette N.

description:
The food here is oh so tasty.  The pupusas are so delicious that I give them a rating of 9 on the pupusa rating scale.  They are not too greasy, not too dry, and are full of flavor.  I like that they also have other types of pupusas along with the usual bean, cheese, pork combinations.  The other stuff on menu is really good too like the yuca.  The soups are amzing too.  I once had a chicken soup from here when I was really sick, and I swear it cured me.

The place is divey looking and the service is slow.  The food is definitely worth the wait.
author: P D.

description: The best pupusas I've ever had in my life. Great price, good selection, nice location, fine people. Yes.
author: Kevin A.

description: Spent the day in SF yesterday and decided to try something new! Discovered Balompie and was attracted to it because of its intimate setting and stayed there because of their prices! Most meals were under $10 and included rice and beans and an entree! I enjoyed a delicious caldo de camaron (shrimp soup) for under $12. The caldo was full of flavor and I enjoyed all of it (even drank all of the broth because it was so good). The shrimps in the caldo were a good size and the broth and vegetables were seasoned to perfection. I would definitely recommend Balompie to anyone eating on a budget! The food was good priced and very filling.
author: Adriana P.

description: the bf and i have a thing for pupusas. we've tried a number of salvadorean restos in the city and they've all been quite good. we figured we'll give this place a try too. wednesday evening we walk in...we're the only non-local looking people. a very good sign that the food should be good. we each ordered 2 pupusas and they did not disappoint. what's more? the servers were extremely friendly and all smiles. what's even more? there's a big screen for all you sports fans!
author: Melissa Y.

description: Crappy service!  Very disappointing lunch, made the trek out to get some food from the motherland but was annoyed by the service.  Our waitress was 'out to lunch' so to speak, she took forever to bring a menu, take our order and finally bring us our food.  People that had ordered after us got their meal before us.  Also when we finally got our food it was luke warm, ugh.  The horchata had a funky taste too, my hubby thought it was rotten.  After we finally ate we then had to wait forever for our bill, we had to ask her twice to finally get it.  Now I know I need to stick to the other locations since service is better there!
author: La C.

description: Wow, as good as it gets!!!! Great food, great service, great location (don't be scared, just sit and watch the people).  Get out and get here... no disappointments in sight...
author: B M.

description:
During this time of increasing economic distress, I'm comforted by the fact that I can get a totes delicious meal at a more than reasonable price!

We made our first trip to Balompie Cafe last night and were all pleased as punch with our dinners.  My pupusas (beef & cheese and seafood & cheese) were both better than I expected and I really, really loved the beans that came with my rice.  One dining companion had the "sampler platter" that immediately had me envious and the other dining companion had some sort of breakfast extravaganza, which I think I'll try in the future.

Add to that some fried plantains and some house wine, we had a nearly perfect meal!
author: Marcus C.

description: Best pupuseria I have ever been to. I always have two pupusas rice and beans. I love the Chicharon (pork) and Cheese pupusas. The pupusas are not made with tons of dough., they are crisp on the outside and fluffy on inside. Once you split one and pick a bite up the cheese will stretch from your plate to your mouth and the pork melts in your mouth. The beans are delicious. The rice is never over cooked or under cooked and it never sticks. Other stuff I like are their platano frito (fried plantains), pastelitos (meet,chicken,shrimp,stuffed pastery). All their food is great I recommend it. Ohhhhhh and the fried yuca (starch root) is awsome.
author: Mario M.

description:
Only the Mission hipsters and those who haven't had real Salvadorean food outside of this neighborhood would give this place such a high rating. I base my ratings for any pupuseria on how well they make the revuelta. I don't really care for all the other types they make. It's not authentic. Their revuelta had way too bean, which had very little flavor. I really had to put a lot of curtido in order to really enjoy it. A pupusa should be able to stand alone on its own, in my opinion. There are much better choices around this neighborhood. I highly encourage everyone who reads this post to check others out. 

Also, the service here sucks.
author: Eric S.

description:
I visited this fine place today, I wanted to try some authentic papusas for the first time in life. Just a block a way I witnessed a crack whore on rollerskates (hilarious!), and a hand to hand drug transaction. We also saw an addict walking down the street with a greasy piece of chicken in a brown paper bag, he was offering to sell it to everyone who walked by (even more hilarious). 

When I made it inside the restaurant all was well, i was kind of disappointed they didn't have chips and salsa like most latin establishments I visit. you get used to having something to snack on while you wait for your food. After we ordered the food arrive fairly quickly, I got a chicken pupusa and a pork one. the chicken was way better, i recommend that one.

One thing I didnt like is they don't have free refills here. the waitress never came back to check on us, we had to flag her down. I'd visit again, but I wouldn't go out of my way to do so.
author: D F.

description:
My husband and I adore this restaurant.  The have the most scrumptious pupusas, and the vibe there is always great.   We've tried pupusas at two other places, but Balompie definitely made them better (nice hot and crispy!)

There is a great "family" feel to the place which draws people in to come back.  The wait staff is incredibly friendly, helpful, and patient. 

But don't limit yourself just to pupusas!  Venture out and try some of their stews, which are very flavorful and rich.  We also very much enjoyed the steamed yukas.  It's good to go in groups of up to six, so you can sample more dishes.

We also saw a few people ordering a beautiful shrimp salad, which I hope we'll try the next time we're there.  It looked like a very hearty meal and comes in a big glass goblet.
author: Natalie T.

description:
Yes I love this place. It's little and crowded and sometimes there is a wait and the bathrooms are weird but the food! ?Hecka good
Eat:
Pupusas with cheese and loroco or revuelta
Platanos
Casamiento (the best ever!!!!) Rice and beans all fried together

Drink:
Agua de Pina
32 oz Tecate

OMG I wish I was there right now.
