author: Edi B.

description:
I agree with Samantha K...I often have found that, if a place is truly phenomenal, crack IS involved.  Balompie is such an example.  The food is savory, well-cooked, and fresh.  But mainly, it has crack in it.  I had chicken, pork, and shrimp pupusas, and I spent the whole meal trying to decide which was best.

MMMMmmmmmmmmm :)
author: Daryl W.

description:
I can safely say this is the best Salvadorian meal I've ever had. Tonight's food was five stars. Minus one for the place being really loud, but then there was a large party at the next table over and they were making most of it.

Anyway, I gotta orchata (horchata) that was stronger than I was used to -- maybe it's like the other poster said, that it wasn't watered down.

My friend and I both got the Salvadorian combo platter (#1): pupusa, yuca w/meat, pastele. I ordered the loroco y queso pupusa, and my friend got the fish pupusa. Funny, we both liked both and liked each other's better and wound up swapping. I remember the first time I tried their curtido and it was way too strong for me; now I dump it on my pupusa and just scarf it up. Yummm.

The yuca (which I got steamed rather than fried) turned out to be sorta like potato only different, in a good way, under some lean chicken and over some kinda slaw that was different from the curtido. Very flavorful.

The chicken pastele, sort of a chicken turnover or pasty, was also good.

There were also some pickled veggies in vinegar as a garnish that were very good.

All told, an outstanding, flavorful meal in a slightly uncomfortable space.
author: Charles B.

description:
I wouldn't consider myself adventurous when it comes to trying new foods, but Balompie won me over immediately its pupusas: thick, corn flat breads stuffed with a variety of ingredients customized to your liking. You can choose to stuff your pupusas with beans, cheese, pork, zucchini, veggies, spinach, shrimp, fish, prosciutto, jalapenos...just about anything really. I usually order the standard pork and cheese papusas and they're excellent. They're crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside, packed with bold spices and flavors, and generously filled with cheese and meat. They're especially delicious when topped with the red sauce and lettuce-like veggie mixture they serve on the side. Best of all? They're only about $2-3 each and 2 will be more than enough to keep you full through lunch (or even dinner). Balompie's papusas are another one of the 7x7 "100 Things to Try Before You Die" and certainly for good reason. If you're a fan of Mexican food--and are looking for a dish to rival the amazing quesadillas at El Farolito--you'll love the El Salvadorian Papusas here.

Other winning dishes include the enchiladas, the fried yuca with carne, and the spaghetti with chicken. I was initially skeptical about ordering spaghetti from an El Salvadorian restaurant, but the dish turned out to be quite delicious (although very different from the spaghetti I'm used to having).

In addition to great food, Balompie has a friendly staff, plenty of seating, and low prices. Next time you're in the Mission for good Mexican food, consider switching it up and giving El Salvadorian cuisine a try. You won't be disappointed!
author: Joseph F.

description: Best Salvadorian food bar-none. This is the place to eat if you want authentic
author: Cesar H.

description: What can I say that hasn't been said already - great food, great prices, great service - pupusas and other dishes are fresh and authentic - love this place
author: R F.

description: Yummy pupusas! I had the pork and another one beans and cheese. Tastes homemade. Also our el salvadorian friend got the Regia smooth lager beer. Yum it's light and tastes good. The soup looks great - but didn't get to try. Next time!
author: Star T.

description: Twenty five years on this god forsaken planet and I had my first pupusa yesterday. I'm now on a hunt to find the best pupusa spot in SF. Right now, Balompie's has the best, pretty much by default because it is my first. I thought it was delicious though, not overly greasy or too chewy. I had the combo plate with a pastel and fried yuccas. A fried fantasy come true. By the end of the meal, my tummy could take no mas because of all the fried delights. The pastel is like a little corn breaded treat shaped like a lemon, mine filled with diced carrots, onions, other stuff, and shrimp! You can pick what kind of meat goes inside. I like the feel of the place too, just homies or family hanging out.
author: Tatiana D.

description: I don't give a lot of 5 stars here but everything people say about the papusas is spot on.  They freakin' rock!  Get the pork and cheese ones.  Yummmmmm..............
author: Jim S.

description:
2.5 stars.

i'm not quite sure what balompie is, but my imagination wildly takes over and makes me think of blimpie (the sub restaurant) and baloney making a love connection of some sort.  

i'm no expert in el salvadorean cuisine, however, a trained tongue isn't necessary in determining that the mariscada w/garlic sauce should be avoided.  the rice seems a little uncle ben-ish, the sauce a bit chicken broth-y, and the seafood seems as if it's come from a batch that has been made earlier.

...however...

the pupusas were decent, although, not overwhelmingly impressive.  regardless, at 2 for $3.50, you're getting a good deal.  we had the loroco con queso (native salvadorean vegetable and cheese) and the mexicana y queso (ground pork, jalapenos, and cheese).  just a note:  you're getting exactly what is listed as the ingredients.  no spices, no frills, just cheese, veggies, and meat.  if you're ok w/that, then you're good to go.
author: Ting A.

description:
pupusa!  say it with me. poo-poo-sa!  so fun to say.  and I'm so immature I giggle a little inside every time my inner voice says it  :)

the salvadorean pupusas here are amazingly delicious.  hot. fluffy.  filled with hot fresh cheesy goodness.  seriously, so hot you burn your palate, so be careful!!  put some of the cole-slaw-ey stuff and salsa on right before you eat it to help cool it down.  so frickin good.   They also add chicken, beans, shrimp, pork, or beef (I think) inside, along with the quesillo soft cheese.  their normal entrees are served with plain pupusas with no cheese inside.  seriously, this place is pupusa heaven.

have I said pupusa enough yet?  have I mentioned how I giggle inside whenever I read the word?  :)

THey also have a great, huge salvadorean chile relleno here, stuffed with meat, and lots of other great traditional salvadorean dishes.  in addition to their pupusas.

service is friendly, but a little lacking sometimes in its promptness--it's hard to find the waitress sometimes.  that's probably the only bad thing I can think of.  prices are of course reasonable.  oh I need to say pupusa one more time.  pupusa.  there.  all done now.  hee hee.
author: Fong L.

description:
Dang, I love this place...I need to go here again soon!
 
Their chicharron/cheese & bean/cheese pupusas don't disappoint!! I love their camarones (Prawns) dish...It's so freakn' good! 

UPDATE: I just had the #6 with platanos and Orchata a few days ago! One word...AWESOME!

I love the cute waitress! That's why I come back for more! =)
author: Marc E.

description: Delicious and fresh pupusas but that's all.  Go here for pupusas but skip the rest.  1 extra star for being clean and having a neat little Salvadorean bar feel to it.
author: Ankur P.

description: I'm sitting here DROOLING thinking about this place.....need I say more?... BEST PUPUSAS that I have ever eaten in my life!
author: Banannie E.

description: HOT DAMN!  I had a *delicious* meal here last night.  Had pupusas for the first time--cheese & bean.  SO YUMMY!  Not too greasy, just right.  I also ordered a guacamole appetizer, which was super fresh and tasty.  Also had a side of plantains, which were delish.  The woman who works at the cash register has been there for over 20 years and she is lovely--super warm, friendly and smiley.  I am a huge fan of this spot and I will definitely be back!
author: Sara W.

description: random mission drive and find...seeing crowds even late afternoon....after lunch and before dinner hours...appearance promising for dive restaurante...wanting best sampler for tasting...dos orders of platos tipico #1 and #4...traditional el salvadorea comfort food told...first being pupusa, yuca and pastel...warmth of fresh pupusa steaming...golden fried yuca...recommend for appetizer sharing....second number four....carne asada, chorizo and casamiento....well-done tasty beef "steak"...non-favorable meat cut, but working a flavorful not too tough meal...paired to looking almost homemade dos sausage links....crumbling of delicioso meat...bit dry, but liking non-greasy meat meal....rice and beans filling finding fine with piping hot plain pupusa breading....great overindulgence complete meal under $fifteen per person...
author: Hen A.

description: Best pupusas I've ever had. I had the Chichirron y queso pupusas and they were the bomb!Super friendly service. They make their ice tea to order which I thought was cool. Great food, low prices. I will be back.
author: Ryan R.

description: yummy, melty cheese and meat (and shrimp) The pupusas and plantanos con frijoles were perfectly done.  Not to firm, not too soft, not too greasy.  How can I still be drooling when I'm still so full?
author: Mabelle A.

description: Hands down -Best Pupusas I've ever had!!! I prefer plain cheese. But the meat ones are also delish! And the fried plantains/bananas are also very, very good.
author: Jenna L.

description: Great Nicaraguan breakfast especially during the World Cup.  Great vibe.
author: Jay A.

description: Best breakfast place for a hangover in my opinion. This place is so yummy and good. One of the better pupusas I have had in the city by far. Food is cheap and you get a lot for your money. I love their refried beans and thick tortillas. I highly recommend their pupusas over anything else. I tried the enchiladas (decent but too much onion and sauce was not thick enough, really tomato soup like), and the skirt steak was also decent, but I still went back to the pupusas. Come here for Sunday brunch- you will not be disappointed.
author: Kristy H.

description:
I don't think I can give the pupusas a fair review, as I had only the rice ones.  The texture was very chewy and I felt I was gnawing through too far much starch to get to the cheese.  I shouldn't have to work so hard.  The beans and the coleslaw were good, though, as was the salsa.

I'm sure the corn flour pupusas are better, but really it's the name of this place that shines.  I prefer to say "Bah-lom-pee,"  as in "I feel a little balompie after eating too many pupusas."  Balompie, Balompie, Balompie.  You say it too.
author: S P.

description: Maybe it depends on what you order, but I'm only giving three stars, because the breakfast I bought today, was Meh, I've had better.    That said, I do notice that this place has many Latino customers who are happy and loyal to this place.
author: Gregory D.

description: I came here to pick up lunch with a friend one day and we ordered the famed pupusas.  Now, I must admit, I've never had it before (shocking since I grew up practically around the corner from this place).  Overall a really solid dish but I don't have much to compare it against.  By itself, the pupusas are a-ok, but the best part, in my opinion, was when you mix it together with the salsa and shredded, pickled cabbage (?).  Now that's a party in your mouth!
author: Abby N.

description: Delicious papusas...which ARE the way to my heart. The empanadas aren't at good as Rica's, but everything else is! Best Salvadorean in town. It's festive in there also, sporty...friendly folks and today it was sunny so everyone was smiling. Made my day.
author: Colleen B.

description: I went to Balompie after Yom Kippur fast. I was DYING I tell you DYING of hunger (okay not really but come on, who wants to not eat for a day?) So I sat down in this small, noisy, but friendly restaurant. The soccer game was blaring in the background and the restaurant was full of people enjoying pupusas. I ordered Cheese and Egg and it was delicious. The pickled salad makes the dish. If you want to branch out of Mexican food I would definitely suggest hitting up Balompie.
author: Tam C.

description: I was introduced to this place about 5 years ago and it remains my favorite pupuseria. Delicious and cheap! Highly recommended.
author: Andi R.

description:
good food 
service not too great but the food is worth putting up with rude service LOL
author: Olga G.

description: so far the best salvadoran food if the mission although la santaneca is hard to beat , loroco pupusas did the job , really amazing also had a chicken stew that had an amazing sauce and i have to say they do make the best beans in the whole city if i am not mistaken , really good spot
author: NAEL K.

description: Balompie! This place is all about Football, real Football. You can tell by the men cheering at the bar. The food is delicious. The prices are reasonable. The service is good. My favorite thing about Balompie is saying the name. Go on, try it. Balompie! It's great fun.
author: Daniella C.

description:
4 adults and 1 ultra cute kid. 
We got our own wine, and they charged very minimal for corkage.
Setup is half a notch higher than a taqueria (because you sit at the table), but the food was awesome.
The pork & sausage papusas were yummy. The salvadorean vegatable one was bland. After a few, the papusas get quite cheesy though. 
Guacamole was delicious. Salsa and cabbage sides were tasty.
Garlic chicken was also nice.
author: Nilofer M.

description: Balompie was definitely on my list of places to eat in SF and it did not disappoint!! I ordered the best breakfast/lunch ever. I got the pupusa, yuca and pastel platter. Their pupusa is so stuffed, you can taste the fillings unlike some other places. I got the revuelta. The curtido could have been fermented a little longer, but that's just me. The fried yucas with a little bit of lemon was perfect. (I passed the chicharones to my bf because he loves that.) And I didn't have room for the pastel with chicken, so I took it to go. Ate it on the drive back to LA and it was the best snack!! The garlic chicken was damn good, too! It was really busy when we got here, we waited quite a bit for our food to come out, about 35 minutes. But I have no complaints :)
author: Carmen C.

description: I learned about Balompie Cafe from Patricia Unterman's excellent book, and it has become my restaurant of choice in San Francisco for Salvadorian food. I always order the combination plate--a pupusa, yucca, and a pastel--a steal at just over $7.00. You get to choose the fillings for the pupusa and pastel, and the toppings for the yucca (fried or steamed). My favorites are loroco (a delicious and mild Salvadorian vegetable) or the pork for the pupusa. And chicharron (delicious fatty, salty, crispy pork!) or pescaditos (wonderful little whole fried fish) for the other two. Order a side of plantains and sour cream, and one of their delicious aguas frescas, sit back and watch the futbol game and loosen your belt.
author: Jon L.

description: So I was first introduced to this place by an ex's family about 5 years ago. I didnt really know too much about Salvadorean cuisine, so I ordered cheese enchiladas (which were REALLY good) but after having a bite of a queso y chicarron papusa, I fell in love. That place instantly became one of my favorite restaurants. The horchata and tamarindo drinks are very tasteful and the huevos rancheros and variety of papusas are to die for. I eat til I practically have to slide off my chair. If the floor wasnt so dirty, I'd lie on it for hours til my food digested. =)
author: Christina R.

description: To be fair, I'm just rating the pupusas and the enchiladas, I'm sure the rest on the menu is just as good. I'm a stickler for customer service and I've gotta say .....Two thumbs up!
author: Ritz R.

description:
Did you all hear that? That bubbling sound emanating from my stomach? There! There it goes again. I was so excited to have lunch today at Balompie after reading so many favorable reviews by fellow Yelpsters.
The place was packed. Seemed like a really good sign. Mr. Socks and friends ordered two Loroco [Salvadoran vegi], two chicken and cheese, and two cheese and bean, Papusa combinations. The combos include rice and beans. After twenty minutes, the food arrived. I SWEAR, after we all had bites of one another's, none of us was able to distinguish one filled Papusa from the other. They were all the same. No flavor whatsoever. For 7 bucks, you get two small Papusas [albeit a block of cheese melted in rice or corn flour] with some lard-laden beans and rice. I know, I know, that's the general premise behind the Papusa. I've eaten them for years, but half the reason for consuming so much cheese are the great, flavorful fillings. Now that seven hours later, my stomach is pounding out Salvadoran Cumbias, it seems hardly worth it...and pass the Tums.
Try Panchita's No. 2. Now we're talking Papusas.
author: Mr. S.

description: The pupusas are bomb. Yes I said it.  They are warm and melt in your mouth and are such a nice treat.  Perfect place to grab a beer with a bunch of friends, sit down and relax.
author: Katie D.

description: Being an SF native, how could you live or hang out in the Mission without coming to Balompie!  I LOVE this place and have loved it since my childhood!!  The pupusas are on hit!  But my favorite is the breakfast with huevos con chorizo, casamiento and crema... and the handmade tortillas! mmmmmmmm.... I always look forward to Balompie.  I love it!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
My husband and I have tried to dine here numerous times on the weekend. Much to our dismay the lines to get in are way too long for our
grumbling stomachs so we scout around the hood in search of a lesser
wait. This past Sunday was different. We were thinking a fast taco and
all the favorite taco spots were closed for Easter. Who woulda thunk it?!
Anyway, as we were passing by Balompie the neon "OPEN"
sign was glaring at us and there was a parking space right in front and no lines out the
door so we skidded sideways into that parking space and raced for the door. The food was SOOOO good. Chicken soup with big chunks of white
breast  meat, carrots, potatoes and zucchini paired up with the hand made tortillas, it will cure anything that ails you. Papusa's!
All the other good things that have been said are true. Chicken Enchilda's-to die for. The rice and beans-fantastic. Service is a bit
awkward but the food makes up for it. I may have to become more patient so I can wait in lines to get in here again.
author: Cindy J.

description: What can I say. I love this place. This weekend I've been lucky to dine at a few 5-stars and this is definitely worthy of it. We went here for dinner and the bill for 4 was around $45 with drinks, appetizer and entrees. We ordered the pupusas. The place is authentic and the food is just awesome.
author: nik t.

description: being salvadorean i have to know where to get the best pupusas...and yes this is the spot...but i have to say i wish pupusas prices were the same as when i was a kid cuz i would order a lot more jajaja....
author: Ivan C.

description: Wow!  I love this place.  First of all, it's been a while since I"ve had pan con chumpe and it was really good.  The pupusas were a yes by my husband who is from El Salvador.  I haven't tried too many dishes yet...I am working on that...but so far I was very impressed by the pupusas, the pan con chumpe (Salvadorean turkey sandwich), the yucca was ok but  I like the fact that it was served with shrimp as a topping.  My husband had the shrimp soup.  Yummmy is all that came out while I was eating.  The service is good.  While we ordered food and waited because it was to go, we sat at the bar and the owner gave us some coffee on the house.  I just felt this place had some really friendly people.   It seems this place has a lot of the regulars.  I will go back to try many of their dishes.
author: lori c.

description: This place makes me want to go down south (I only travel to places that have good food).  Place was packed and we were lucky to snag a table for two.  I had plate #1..or 2, I forgot, but it came with three different things from the menu (papusa, yucca, and something else), and the empanada/plantains were awesome.  Service was perfect and because it's a little bit off Mission, parking wasn't too bad.
author: Mark D.

description: I can't recommend this place. Place was rather packed on a Sunday afternoon, and the locals seem to like it. Honestly, the food was bad, mostly because the ingredients were poor, and the pounds of salt used by the cook could not hide that. No reasons to go back.
author: Carlo M.

description: I really love their horchatas and cheese pupusas! Only thing I dont like is all the men that stare you down when you walk in and wait for a little too long for the food sometimes. But other than that i love the pupusas or the platanos con frijoles y queso mm mm.
author: Stephanie M.

description: pupusas were fresh and hot.  nice corn flavor, chorizo y queso; i've had better chorizo/cheese ratio in miami at el salvadorean places there, but this place is good. (got the espinaca y queso also) the curtido (cabbage) was not spicy
author: Rob C.

description: Great Salvadorean food for poco dinero. The pupusas were amazing and not greasy or heavy, which can be an issue when eating this food. Make sure you put that slaw on your pupusa. It rocks!
author: Pierre K.

description: Really enjoyed this restaurant. The pupusas were not really greasy, which is always a plus! Also love the platanos with beans and crema! Yummy! Que chivo!  Gotta have a Pilsener while there as well. You walk out full and still have lots of money to spare...
author: Michael W.

description: Simple, hearty, and delicious Salvadorean food.  I'm a huge fan of the pupusas, which literally ooze yumminess, but they also have excellent combination plates.  This morning I had the plantain breakfast combo, and my pile of golden fried sweet plantains came accompanied by sour cream, a wedge of queso fresco, casamiento (an addictive refried bean/rice mixture) and two piping-hot tortillas.  Add to this the fact that I could watch the Newcastle-Bolton match on any of the many TVs set up around the restaurant devoted to football, and I was officially in heaven.
author: Heidi D.

description: I love this place. I dream about their food all the time. Lately ive been ordering their soups. They are to die for. In fact my husband got me a soup from whole foods yesterday and didn't even finish half of it.... I kept thinking about the balompie soups. I live in soma. Tonight he is on his way to pick me up a seafood soup and just thinking about it makes my mouth water. I'm lucky that this place is in sf.
author: Solaria P.

description: Mmm, the pupusas were delicious, but the chicken enchiladas were amazing. Really different than I've had before. I can't wait to go back and try everything else!
author: Rose K.

description: Awesome, cheap, seldom crowded.  Try the pupusas revueltas.
author: Leti R.

description: The platter with 2 pupusas with rice and beans is not worth it. Better to get four pupusas for around the same price. The rice is yucky, but how Salvadoreans must like it-- minute rice flavored with instant chicken boullion. You have to be Salvadorean to like it this way. For more than $4 over the price of two 2 pupusas a la carte, Balompie gives you a dinky serving of this minute rice with a dinky serving of refried beans. My bean and cheese pupusa had a hole in it too.
author: E. M.

description:
This is my first review...why?
Because Balompie is THE BEST PLACE EVER.
If I were to ever go on "Check Please", this would be my restaurant of choice, hands down.

Conveniently located downstairs from my boy's house, I can easily order some yummy chicken pasteles or breaded chicken [my two top picks], and within 20 minutes every time, my order is ready for pick-up.Oh! and do not forget the rice and beans...mmmmmm, so yummy. Ask for extra salsa, mild but oh so good.
My buddies are fans of the melt-in-your-mouth pupusas. Awesome, any of 'em. Go ahead, try 'em all.

If you're feeling like something out of the ordinary, get the whole fried fish. A winner indeed.

What can I say? Fresh food, sweet staff, good atmosphere.

I love you, Balompie. In fact, I don't think I want to know life without you.
author: V M.

description: Clean. and delicous.  A bit more pricey than Rinconcito which is just a few steps away. However this place does have more space,, english speakers, creative menu ideas, and more menu options.
author: R C.

description: yum Yum YUMMIE! I love  the Pupussas there :) About 15 years back when my 2nd husband n I were together...I would go to his family's house on Sundays for what they would cal Picaritas... and I always loved them.... then at some street fairs a few years back I came across the vendors selling Pupussas and would look forward to them whenever there was a street fair :) Then around 5 years ago my 5th husband came across this place Balompie and we went there for pupussas and they were YUM! Hadn't been there in a while and went there this past weekend with a friend... reminded me what I was missing.... PAPUSSAS! YUM! Okei, I need to go back more often...and they're so cheep too! Yum n cheep, whay mor can I ask for????
author: Rick B.

description:
i love this place b.c. it's really authenic food, comfortable clean atmosphere and combos on the menu.  

great for lunch
author: Erika Y.

description: Balompie has bangin' cheese pupusas and platanos fritos con crema y frijoles. Translation: fried yum and a plate of more yum, with a side of beans and cream. I can't handle how good. I'm like gushing here, or I should be. Yum. Pupusas should be eaten often and introduced to friends so that you can collect a cadre of more people to eat pupusas with you.
author: reb f.

description:
thanks yelp!!!   my 1st salvadorean restaurant & perhaps our regular salvadorean spot now........  we weren't disappointed.......  the pupusas were delish!!! i had the laroco/cheese & zucchini/cheese while my hub had the revueltas/cheese & chicken/cheese w/rice & beans on the side.............   great prices, good size portions............but tooo good, meant to get a cone of salted caramel / ritual coffee toffee @ bi-rite ........but was sooooo full, i just sadly looked out the window as we drove by bi-rite !!! its been 2 1/2 hours since we ate & i'm still sooooooo full, its just totally sitting there!!!! .........its a good thing, but next time -- i need to strategize -- eat only 1 pupusa, so i can get my bi-rite cone! 

nice, casual, family restaurant feel in the mission (the less gentrified part of the mission, too), really nice friendly service.  our waitress was sweet!!   i soooo stood out -- i was the asian woman with the big wide smile happily/excitedly chowing down my pupusas
author: Cindi N.

description: I had never heard of a papusa before a friend introduced me to Balompie. But now I would like to eat nothing else. Yum-my.
author: Lara F.

description: OK... So, I love pupusas. My girlfriend, who's Salvadorian, and I have spent many a weekend afternoon in the Mission over-enduldging in pupusas and platanos. I've had good, not so good,  I've actually gone as far as to made them myself (much to my understanding girlfriends chagrin) and I have to say Balompie has yet to be topped. The masa is perfect and soooo soft. The queso/loroco pupusas are the best I've had. Revueltas to die for. And much to my surprise, the camarones/queso pupusas rock. Their curtido is the best I've had to date as well. Balompie is a must  if your love for pupusas is a deep and complex as mine. They also play one song really loud, every 20 min or so. Odd. 5 stars. Cheers!
author: Natas N.

description: Having seen Balompie Cafe both on 7x7 Big Eats and Cheap Eats lists, I couldn't stand the suspense any longer and decided that there were pupusas to be had. Tim V. and I stopped by at the Mission location a bit before 6 and grabbed a seat easily. I ordered two pupusas and fried rice & beans (one pupusa was chicharrones y queso and the one had cheese and a native Salvadorean veggie of some sort). Tim opted for steak, sausage, and the same fried rice. The food arrived quickly and we dug in. The side dish tasted more like refried beans mixed together with rice and fried a bit and was pretty good. The pupusas were filled with plenty of cheese. In fact, I think there was a bit too much cheese in relation to the other ingredient and I could barely taste the pork and the veggie. I wish I could take away half a star for that. I also enjoyed the little plates of pickled veggies that came with dinner - the pickled cabbage with rosemary was quite interesting. Overall, I liked Balompie and will visit it again. Hopefully, they'll figure a better balance between ingredients though.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
WOW!
yes, this isn't a ritzy establishment, BUT the food is delish!
The pupusas were hot and freshly made, the plantains were good too. 
SF needs more places like this; cheap and tasty!
Will return again sooner than later!
author: Dre X.

description: I'm no expert but i love the papusa's from here.  They have alot of filling in them and are very tasty.  They do take a while to make so be patient.  If your there on Sunday morning nursing a hang over that wait can be brutal but its worth it.
author: Kevin M.

description: I was craving papusa's like whoa, so I asked some dude on the street which place had the best ones. He told me about Balompie, and when he told me the location, I was stoked. Its only 3 blocks from my house! I ordered a bean and cheese, and a pork and cheese. I was super impressed by the bean and cheese, it was heavenly. The pork and cheese was pretty good too. Everyone should go and get down on some papusas!!!!!!!
author: Brittany B.

description: Mmmhmmm. Really delicious papusas. Not too greasy, filled with wonderful cheese and loroco.  Cool communal type place with a TV in literally every corner so you can get your telemundo soccer matches on. Dinner cost 15 dollars for two - Yea!
author: amy b.

description: This place is one of the best South American food spots in the city by far. The Pupusas are the best i have ever tried in North America, my most favorite is the cheese and spinach. The Yuca is great steamed or deep fried. We like the steamed yuca with the pork. make sure you have worked out the day you order as the pork is deep deep fried, however delicious it will make you feel guilty. I usually order the chick stew and chick soup. The sauce with the chicken stew is so good and authentic! Jen my wife's favorite is the lemon chicken with the caso pupusas. When we have finished our meal we usually order two more entrees and pupusas to go for the nest day or midnight snacks. This friday we ordered six pupusas and five entrees, one beer and a coke. One of the entrees was the calamari, my wife claims it was the best calamari in the city, fresh, super crunchy and a great yogurt and cream sauce on the side.The total was under $55.00 So the value is excellent there too. Let me also say the portions are a good size. If you are on the hop you can easily share and be filled. The service is very prompt from Maria she has a gold toothed smile. Balompie Cafe has football played on the flat screen while you eat, European, South American and US. icy cold beer, good food, football, these are good times!!
author: Andrew S.

description: As other yelpers have mentioned, perhaps there are better pupusas out there.  Perhaps.  But I am not writing this review about the pupusas (which are delicious).  I am writing this review about breakfast special #1, which is what I order almost ever time I walk in.  Plantains, beans, queso fresca, crema, torillas (extra thick), and coffee all for $7.25.  Man those tortillas are thick!  Man do I need a nap at 10 am!
author: Richard N.

description: This place is great.  The people are very friendly and the food is very tasty. I too had the same combo plate as jonathan and I highly recommend it - with a side of plantains of course.
author: Ky W.

description: While I know of no other place where I could get a shrimp papussa, and I love their calamari, I was disgusted when all of our plates had strands of hair on it.  We had started coming here quite frequently and that was the last time.  To top it off we were pissed off cuz that women replied to my mom, "well your hair is black."  I looked back at the cook and she was not wearing a hair net.  I was quite pissed off at the fact that she was f-ing accusing us of tampering with our food for a discount. Bitch, the shit is already cheap.
author: sonia m.

description: I'm not one to usually care one way or the other about interior design, but this spot is so chill. SF has lots of great places to eat papusas but this place goes the extra distance for delivering great food in a great location.
author: Paul J.

description: Delicious pupusas.  Cool vibe.  Good prices.  Don't hesitate to check it out.
author: Scott L.

description: This place is awesome!  Love their pupusas, especially the bean and cheese and seafood varieties.  The salsa they serve with the pupusas are out of this world!  Add in a few good beers on tap and futbol games on all the screens, and you've got yourself a winning combo!
author: Chris C.

description: I love, love, love pupusas!!! Perfection!!  Back in Marin, we had a husband/wife duo that would set up shop at our soccer games and churn out pupusa goodness. When we won, the coach would pick up the tab for the whole team. Now, Balompie trumps any and all pupusas I have had in my life. Maybe it's the ambiance, with soccer memorabilia from all over the map, even my favorite, Saprissa from Costa Rica.  Maybe it's the Salvadoran Spanish accents filling the room and the women in back throwing down on some masa dough. Ultimately, it comes down to the Pupusas con queso y  loroco (a Salvadorian flower bud) and the boiled yucca that have me sold. Always hot and enough "curtido" and salsa to smother all over the top of your meal.  Definitely a must-try spot right off "La Mission".
author: Jason H.

description:
why, why, Balompie, why!?! I heard about you a few months ago and have been dying to try your pupusas for weeks. I had been forewarned as to the food waiting time, but didn't think it would be that bad. 

I visited not too long ago and ordered the breaded pescado with garlic sauce -- waaaaaaay too salty and swimming in broth.  I also ordered the much-hyped pupusas (oh so yum, and only $2.25 each). My man had the combination plate #5, full of meat and beans. A little salty for me, but my man dug it.

At 8:00 were ready to leave completely satiated until we ordered two pupusas to go.  It took 50 minutes for them to arrive!   Geez, the least you could have done was WARN me!  When they handed us the bill, it was higher than anticipated. Apparently they had included a service charge for TWO people, and charged us the dine-in price instead of the take-out price for the take-out (the take-out price is cheaper).

Screw it. I threw the exact change on the table and left.  Don't get me wrong, the food was cheap and more than edible, but the service was slow and the bill was higher than it really should be.  Who includes a service charge for just two people!?

Balompie, Balompie.  Why, Balompie, why? The next time I return let ME figure out the tip.  Then I'll bump you up to four stars.
author: Charrylenne S.

description:
Dear Jesus how have I not been here before?

This is a no thrills, yummy, affordable food place. Just how I like 'em
Went with my friend the other day. I had the ham and cheese omelet and she had the papusas (sp?).  It was so good. It was so so ridiculously good. I don't know what cheese they are using, but I think it's my new crack.  

And our bill was $21. Can't get any better than that.
author: A K.

description: Well... I do like to go there for the pupusa's, they are really yummy, but the only thing that i dont like is that they take FOREVER to serve your order. So make sure if you go, to have alot of time to wait for your food.
author: Dalia C.

description:
After reading the reviews, we wanted to try and see what the fuss is about. 

My friend had Agua fresca Pina & Pupusas (Mexicana y Italiana). And I had
Agua fresca Melon & Pupusas (chicharon y queso, frijoles y queso). 

NOTHING SPECIAL. 

Well, actually it's worse than I thought. 
The other table ordered the same agua fresca but the size of a glass is different size, bigger.
Why?? It's obvious that the service was different.
The flavor of agua fresca was below average. It's just not worth $2.75. 
Pupusas were also overpriced. I couldn't taste chicharon at all. 
I'm a huge fun of the cabbage and the salsa that come with pupusas, 
but this place sucks, not to mention they bring how small...

We both did not understand why this place has 4 stars overall. 

El Salvador Restaurant that I reviewed the last time was better. 
But my favorite place to have pupusas is still El Espiga de Oro, which I haven't reviewed yet. 
but I will later on. And you'll know why. 

We will not go back to this place. No vale la pena!!
author: T. S.

description: My new favorite obsession - Balompie!  One of the best spots in SF if you want home cooked Salvadorean food.  A simple plate of pupusas, beans and rice is my favorite dish.  Their pickled vegetables, salsa and the cole slaw are yummy accompaniments to your meal.  The staff is friendly and the wait times are not too long if you don't come after the Sunday church crowd.
author: Jennifer K.

description: delicious chile relleno and yummy pupusas (make sure you get it with rice and beans). awful service esp when they're busy
author: Joy X.

description: The pupusas and the pickled slaw are great. I have only tried the pupusas, but that was enough for me to come back again.. There is a wide selection, and many options for vegetarians as well. For $10 you can eat yourself full, have a beer and watch a soccer game.
author: Yolanda T.

description:
THE best food! Love love love the combination platter w/ pupusa, pastele *and* yucca. Their brunch rules ALL as well; be sure to get a cocoa, too! And save room for the empanadas con crema-- to DIE for!!

:P  mmmm!
author: abby c.

description: cheap wonderful papusa heaven. yesyesyes.
author: who k.

description: Love the food and the hand made tortillas . . . got to have the fried bananas thought.
author: Jane D.

description:
I have to say their food is good and not expensive. However, the service is BAD !!!
I do speak spanish, but I feel that sometime the staff are very rude to others that do not speak the language and seem annoy if they have to given explanation about the food.
One time I went with a group of people, all of us ordered pupusas, however, some of them have different ingredients. When the waitress approaches to our table with the plates we asked her which one's were cheese and wich one's were the pork ...she said " well.....you should know what you order". I think her answer was so rude.  

I haven't gone back...If you want a good service, and good food i will recommen Montecristo Restaurant.
author: Heidi A.

description: pupusas. what a great word for a great dish. when i come to balompie, i make sure to get the one with chicharron (yummy gristly pork!) and their platanos which are sweet and a little gooey, caramelized just like i like my plantains.  the pupusas here are so good that when other people get their orders and start digging in, i feel so sad and bereft... like a "have-not" among so many "haves" just stuffing their greedy faces.  and then my own plate of pupusas comes and i cease to pay attention to anything outside of the 8-inch diameter that is my meal.
author: Dao H.

description: Decent food.  Though I lived in SJ, have been to this place three times, and will be back again.  Beef tongue is tasty. rice with mint also good.
author: sophie c.

description: The best PUPUSAS I've had. The cheese and pork papusa is very tasty and not greasy.
author: Abby S.

description: This is such a great neighborhood restaurant!  It makes me want to move to the mission.  When I went, there was great music playing, soccer on TV, and a bustling restaurant full of locals enjoying a nice Saturday lunch with their friends and families.  The food, the waitstaff, the restaurant itself and the clientele oozes "friendly neighborhood joint" to me.  It just felt so nice and warm and cozy in there, i just wanted to keep eating fried platanos all day long.  Speaking of the food, everything I tried was great.  I had a plate of the platanos, which as platanos go, were quite delicious.  They were a bit meatier than most places, the slices were really thick and you could really taste the sweetness of the plantains.  I also tried the sampler plate that comes with 1 pupusa (chose the Salvadoran veggies and cheese), one pastel (chose the one stuffed with chicken), and this other dish with yucca and fried pork (looked really dry but was so flavorful and had great texture!).  Everything was really delicious and the meal came with salsa, pickles and a slaw.  It seems like a great place to have a nice drink and watch a soccer game with fun people if you're into that kind of thing.
author: Linh N.

description: This place is amazing.  Love the local, casual, soccer fanatic ambiance.  The papusas were incredible - especially the bean and cheese and the chorizo papusas.  Also loved the fried plantains.  They also serve refreshing Salvadorian beer, which you can't find most places.  Parking is tough in the area, but it's worth it.  You are in for a treat.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: yummy cheap eats!  all you need to bring is your appetite and about $10.  30 minutes later, you walk out with a pupusa filled tummy and pineapple juice to wash it down with...who wouldn't be a happy camper?!
author: Nancy T.

description: i eat here about twice a month, always on Tuesdays, always right around 4:30, 4:45 in the evening. love the endless football on television, love the pickled cabbage, love pretty much ALL the filling options to the pupusas. but the best thing here is the thin, light red sauce that accompanies pretty much whatever i order here ... i swear to freakin' God there's crack in that sauce because THAT'S what keeps me coming back.
author: Kevin M.

description: I really love this Salvadoran spot. The pupusas always hit the spot and the plantains make my heart & tummy happy. Great food for a reasonable price, without any pretense. The staff is very friendly and eager to accommodate. I always leave happy and stuffed as I tend to over-eat when there.
author: Happy N.

description: despite the wait, Balompie serves some of the best pupusas in town. and not only that, the salad that comes with it rocks too. i tend to favor ordering food to go since it does get to be hopping and uber busy in the restaurant - what with the locals coming in droves (a good sign, no?).
author: ray e.

description: Being married to a Salvadorian I have gotten my fair share of pupusa's.  I even learned how to make them from his Mom in El SAlvador.  Balompie has the best in the city.  they are the closest to what you get in El Salvador.  plus the other menu items are great as well.  the staff is alsways friendly even though it can get very busy it is definatly worth it.
author: Joy L.

description: This place is yummy.  I am not a 5-star-giver, so getting 4 stars is a great rating from me.  All of my food was delicious. The place was packed and everyone seemed to be enjoying their food too.  The staff was friendly and my waitress was very helpful with recommendations for this novice. I want to go back again and again.  Happy yummy comfort food and great prices to boot.
author: Amy H.

description: i walk by this place almost every time i head to my friend's in the mission and had never really thought to walk in. i'm so glad i did! first, the help was phenomenal. i was a little intimidated by the fact that i was the only non-spanish speaking person in there, not to mention the only female and the only person under 30. i was immediately greeted and offered a menu by the man at the register and he made me feel at home right away. he gave me some great recommendations and told me the food would take 15 minutes. because they make the pupusas to order it does take all of the 15 minutes but they are worth the wait. the price for pupusas is very reasonable and i would recommend to stick with these because we tried a shrimp pastry that wasn't quite as tasty as the three pupusas we got: pork (amazing), loroco (SO good, even if you don't know what it is :)) and shrimp (okay, stick with the other two). the steamed yucca was delicious too!!! Juan, who was the man who helped me, also gave me some horchata on the house while i waited. i will definitely be back here!!! thanks juan for such a great experience :)
author: theresa v.
